PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution: Proposed Changes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectively showeth:

that while having some reservations on individual aspects of the Constitution Alteration (Electors Initiative) Bill 1987 your petitioners wish to express our strong support for the concept of people's democracy implied in that Bill of citizen initiated constitutional and legislative referenda and voters' veto.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will pass said bill so that a national referendum can be held on this matter with the intention of passing legislation granting such facilities to your petitioners during the Bicentennial year.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: War Crimes Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

The Australian Government's proposed War Crimes Amendment Bill is seriously deficient. It is discriminatory. The attention of the Bill is focused exclusively on political refugees from the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe and Yugoslavia. It is bound to result in hostile political stereotyping of refugees from Communist countries and will be profoundly destructive of Australia's multi-cultural society.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that, if the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled are minded to support the War Crimes Amendment Bill, the following provisions be guaranteed:
1. That Soviet, Yugoslav or other similar evidence should be totally disregarded unless corroborated by independent evidence clearly beyond Soviet (or similar) control.
2. That the defendant should have adequate and equal access to archives and site visits, as well as the right to select and interview witnesses from overseas, in the preparation of his defence.
3. No affidavits, videotapes or audiotapes to be admissible as evidence. Witnesses to appear in person and be cross-examined before an Australian jury.
4. The word ``Omission'' to be deleted from s.6 (1) (k) (III) and s.6 (5).
5. No extradition to occur before trial or after verdict.
6. Entitlement to legal assistance for the defendant so that he can conduct a proper defence.
7. Financial compensation to any person cleared of war crimes allegations.

PETITION.TITLE: How to Vote Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

millions of dollars of taxpayers money is spent at each Federal election in Australia in the drafting, production and distribution of How-to-Vote cards which are unnecessary and pollutant and that this waste is not desirable or essential in assisting the electorate to vote informatively for their parliamentarians.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:

urge the Government to introduce legislation which requires that the registered How-to-Vote cards of all political parties and candidates for political office must be placed under glass in every polling booth within obvious sight of all voters, thus making it unnecessary for How-to-Vote cards to be distributed at future federal elections.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions and Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

We are gravely concerned at the Government's proposal to reduce significantly the pension and access to fringe benefits of persons who in good faith bought market linked insurance bonds, friendly society bonds, approved deposit funds, deferred annuities and unit trusts to protect their savings.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, amend the proposed legislation to ensure that it will not apply retrospectively and that provision is made to protect savings against inflation.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out that aged and disabled people who require accommodation and support in nursing homes are entitled to the highest possible standard and quality of nursing care.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should ensure that provision of funds for nursing homes in Victoria is sustained at least at a level sufficient to maintain the high standard of care now available in nursing homes in this State.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sporting, Cultural and Community Groups: Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned,
(i) are alarmed that many sporting, cultural and community groups have been made to feel that they can attract sponsorship only from promoters of unhealthy products;
(ii) call for a National Health Promotion Foundation to be established through an increase in tobacco excise of 10 cents per packet; and

(iii) urge that the National Health Promotion Foundation provide national sporting, cultural and community groups with alternative sponsorship funding so that these groups can flourish without the taint of accepting money from tobacco companies and assisting in the promotion of their unhealthy products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat, and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should heed the above.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Coinage
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate. The petition of certain citizens showeth that:

The introduction of the new two dollar coin, the introduction of the Bi-Centennial Ten Dollar Note and the possible introduction of other coins is being done by Treasury without the direct consent of the majority of people in Australia.

The disabled and aged members of the community are having great difficulty identifying the present one dollar coin, introduced in nineteen eighty four, and express their concern of not being able to tell the difference between the new two dollar coin and the two cent piece.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honoured house urge the government to:

Investigate as a matter of urgency, means by which all persons in the community may have access to changes relating to currency, and changes only take place after due time has been given for all Australians to view the new currency.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, five sitting days hence, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) (a) That a Standing Committee of the Senate, to be known as the Standing Committee on Treaties, be appointed to consider all treaties laid before the Senate, and any other treaties to which the Committee may have access, and to report in respect of each such treaty:
(i) whether Australia should undertake to be bound by that treaty if that treaty is not already binding upon Australia, and
(ii) the effect which Australia's being bound by that treaty has or would have upon the legislative powers and responsibilities of the Australian States; and
(b) that, for the purposes of this Resolution:

``treaty`` means any agreement or proposed agreement in writing between 2 or more countries which imposes or would impose rights and obligations upon those countries and which is or is intended to be binding upon those countries; and

``undertake to be bound'' in relation to a treaty refers to any action which would have the effect of making that treaty binding upon Australia, including the signing of documents, the ratification of that treaty or adherence or accession to that treaty.

(2) (a) That the Committee consist of 8 Senators, 4 nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 2 nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, and one Independent Senator;
(b) that, of the Senators appointed to the Committee pursuant to sub-paragraph (2) (a), there shall be at least one Senator for each State; and

(c) that, if nominations made under sub-paragraph (2) (a) are such that appointments to the Committee in accordance with those nominations would not comply with sub-paragraph (2) (b), the President shall notify the Senate accordingly and ask for fresh nominations, and if those fresh nominations are such that appointments to the Committee in accordance with them would not comply with sub-paragraph (2) (b), the President shall notify the Senate accordingly and the Senate shall determine the appointments to the Committee in accordance with this paragraph so far as is practicable.
(3) That the Committee may proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4) That the quorum of the Committee be 4.

(5) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of 3 or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the Committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub-committee be 2 Senators.
(6) That the Committee elect a member nominated by the Leader of the Government as Chairman.

(7) That the Chairman may, from time to time, appoint a member of the Committee to be Deputy-Chairman and the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(8) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(9) That a Senator, though not a member of the Committee, may participate in its public sessions and question witnesses, unless the Committee orders otherwise, but shall not vote.

(10) That the Committee or any sub-committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, and to meet and transact business in public or private session and notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.

(11) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and that a daily Hansard be published of such proceeding of the Committee as take place in public.

(12) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint counsel to advise the Committee, and other persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee, with the approval of the President.
(13) That the Committee have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such recommendations as it may deem fit, and make regular reports on its deliberations.
(14) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

DEBATE.TITLE: NAVIGATION AMENDMENT (DEREGULATION OF COASTING TRADE) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the following Bill be introduced:

A Bill for an Act to repeal Part VI of the Navigation Act 1912, so as to remove the obligation for ships to obtain a licence or a permit to engage in the coasting trade, and to repeal other sections of the Act which relate only to the coasting trade.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill proposes to repeal Part VI of the Navigation Act.

This Bill was first introduced into the Senate just over two years ago to expose the unnecessarily high costs of coastal shipping in Australia as the result of monopoly control and the excessively high standards and conditions enjoyed by Australian seamen which are a major contributing factor to these high costs.

Earlier this year, the Industries Assistance Commission, at the behest of the Government, produced a draft report on Coastal Shipping which substantiated and amplified my claims of two years ago. That report was a devastating indictment of the state of our coastal shipping and our port handling facilities.
Let me remind Honourable Senators of the findings of this Draft Report on Coastal Shipping:
Coastal shipping in Australia is uncompetitive and inefficient.

High costs and a poor record of service have progressively reduced the industry to a position where the only goods currently shipped around the coast tend to be those for which alternative transport modes are either not available, or are not a realistic proposition.

Whilst this must be of concern to the industry itself, the real issue for the Australian community is that inefficient coastal shipping services jeopardise growth and employment opportunities in the rest of the economy.

In July of this year the Commission brought down their final report which is still on the papers list for discussion in this Chamber and which, despite the attempted sabotage by the Government, comes up with the same findings as the Draft Report.

Both the draft and the final Reports conclude that any reforms resulting from the Crawford and Maritime Industry Development Committees within the coastal shipping industry are taking place too slowly and that major inefficiencies (both on-board and on-shore) manifest themselves in the form of excessive costs and avoidable delays which erode the international competitiveness of Australian industries.

For these reasons and because of the appalling state of the whole shipping and waterfront industry in the past twelve months which have seen delays in the movement of cargoes, which have crippled many businesses and have had a disastrous effect on our exports and confirmed our reputation abroad as an unreliable supplier of urgently needed goods, I have decided to introduce the Navigation (Deregulation of Coasting Trade) Bill 1988, which is only very slightly changed from the Bill which I introduced in April 1986.
As I said at the outset this Bill proposes to repeal Part VI of the Navigation Act to open up coastal shipping to competition and thereby improve its cost-effectiveness and efficiency.
Let me remind the Senate what I said in this Chamber two years ago. I began by summarising the substance of Part VI.

Part VI comprises a set of rules which apply separately to interstate shipping, making coastal shipping separate and distinct from overseas shipping. Under this part of the Act, interstate trade can only be undertaken by ships registered in Australia or by a foreign ship operating with similar crew numbers and similar crew conditions to those applying to Australian ships.

The only situation in which a foreign ship may obtain a permit to operate in the coasting trade without meeting the stringent Australian crew requirements is for a single voyage where no suitable Australian ship is available for that particular freight movement.

To ensure that only Australian ships or foreign ships meeting the Australian crew requirements operate in the coasting trade, a licence or permit is issued for ships to operate this trade and no ship can operate in the coasting trade without this licence or permit.

The point of my Navigation Amendment Bill two years ago was to repeal the onerous and iniquitous requirement for a licence to operate in the interstate trade of Australia. For what Part VI has achieved is a monopoly over the coasting trade, a rort for the seagoing unions in Australia and a high cost service for which all Australians have been paying dearly for since 1921.
Two years ago I asked: `Why do we have a Navigation Act and what were the original intentions of the Act?' And today, I intend to remind Honourable Senators of the history of that Act.

The Australian Navigation Act came into being in 1912. It was based on the British Merchant Shipping Act of 1894 adapted to Australian conditions. The provisions of the Act underpin almost all aspects of the conduct of Australian merchant shipping. The primary objective was to build up an Australian Mercantile Marine, but in the context of an `even-handed attitude' towards shipping.
This `even-handed attitude' was made quite clear by the Attorney-General of the time, Billy Hughes, when he said:

The shipping industry must not be treated differently from any other. We have to consider how far our policy can be applied without materially interfering with our commerce and the convenience of our travelling public or without attempting a policy of differential treatment towards the various maritime nations.

The first Navigation Bill in Australia was debated from September 1910 until the Bill finally passed both Houses in December 1912. Both Houses were divided on the question of the coasting trade, as it was called at that time. The arguments for the protection of the coastal trade will be familiar:
It is of vital importance that Australia build up its own Mercantile Marine and thereby have a maritime presence in the Pacific area.
Australia has the highest standard of wages and living conditions in the world-
remember that this was 1910; we are now fourteenth and dropping in the world list-
These standards must be maintained at all costs.
Foreign vessels in competition with our own are heavily subsidized by their own Governments.
Most other countries also protect their coastal trade.
One other argument not so relevant or familiar today may evoke memories for some of us:
Crews operating in the coastal trade should be white and not coloured, because coloured crews are not treated with the same wages and conditions as white crews.
But there were also some visionaries in the Parliament at that time and the counter arguments ran as follows:
Protection of the coastal trade will increase the working cost of shipping around Australia.

The community will suffer, because if you increase the expenditure of shipowners, they will have to charge higher rates for passenger fares and the carriage of goods, until the increase comes home to every consumer.
Parliamentary interference with the laws of political economy hit back in boomerang fashion upon those responsible for it.
And to quote more fully from a speech in 1912 by Mr William James McWilliams from Tasmania:

Personally I regard the Shipping Federation of Australia as the greatest monopoly in Australia; and I believe the whole basis of this Bill is to still further strengthen and buttress that monopoly, and wherever the monopoly does not exist already, to make it a sure and certain chain round the whole Australian coast.

He went on to forecast that the Shipping Federation and the labour unions would make cosy deals between themselves-the former to have an entire monopoly without competition on the Australian coast and the latter to have such rates of pay and conditions as they demanded-and the public take the hindmost.
He concluded his speech by saying:

This Bill strikes at the very root of commerce. It is based on a law which has created, and always will create, monopoly, and which will always hand over the public to two factors-the Shipping Federation and the great organized trades unions . . .

By shutting out competition we shall throw the people body and soul into the hands of the Shipping Combine. Under this Bill there will be built up a huge monopoly which will suck the very life blood from the people of Australia who are largely dependent on commerce by sea. We shall be hampering enormously the primary producer by making him pay increased freights and charges.
Sadly he was absolutely right about the `huge monopoly' and the `great organized trades unions', and his Cassandra-like prophecies haunt us today.

Although the Navigation Bill passed both Houses in 1912, it was not proclaimed until 1920-and then only in part. Fifty-two clauses and two schedules were proclaimed to come into operation from 2 March 1920, but that proclamation was repealed and the Act did not come into full operation until 1921.

Part VI dealing with the Coasting Trade came into force also in 1921, but it was proclaimed in a web of dishonest publicity: it was said that this was legislation which supported competition in the coastal trade. `Any ship-Australian or foreign-could be licensed to engage in the coasting trade provided that it complied with certain conditions.' Certainly, the cost of the licence itself was no bar for a foreign ship. The licence is issued for a nominal fee. Today the licence costs a mere $16.
What, then, was the crippling and unacceptable bar to foreign ships in the coasting trade? It was the set of conditions attached to the licence:
- Seamen had to be paid at the current rates of pay operating in Australia;
- Ships had to operate with Australian manning levels and Australian conditions and accommodation requirements;
- If a library was provided for passengers on board, the seamen had to be permitted to use the library as well.

These conditions still apply today-sixty-eight years later-to our cost. Australian coastal shipping has to be operated at Australian award rates, with Australian manning levels and Australian conditions of crew accommodation. Unless these conditions are met a licence will not be issued to a foreign ship to operate in the coastal trade.

As all honourable senators will guess, no foreign ship-owner is mad enough to supply two crews for every ship, or carry in some cases almost double the number of crew required to run a ship efficiently, or provide Australian standards of food and accommodation far above those provided by any other country in the world, including countries such as Sweden or the Federal Republic of Germany with far higher standards of living than ours. It is no wonder that a library is needed to occupy Australian crews on board, since their duties, especially on the older ships in the Australian coastal fleet, include almost no ship maintenance or repairs. Many Australian ships spend costly additional time in dockyard hands to do maintenance tasks which are done as a matter of course by the crews of other nations' ships. These are the conditions which have successfully reserved for the last 68 years the coastal trade almost exclusively for Australian-owned, Australian-registered or chartered vessels and Australian crews.

There is one exception, as I mentioned earlier, to the licence conditions for the coastal trade in Australia. The requirement for Australian conditions and manning levels can be waived for the issuing of a single voyage permit. The Minister for Transport may issue a single voyage permit to an unlicensed ship when a suitable licensed ship is not available and `it is in the public interest to issue a permit'. These permits are now fairly rare-26 were issued last year to convey mostly phosphate, caustic soda, sulphuric acid, aqua ammonia, and some LPG.

TALK.START.PARA: —As can be seen from the Table the number of shipments for LPG has dropped from 66 in 1981/82 to six in the last financial year, and the total number of shipments per year has dropped from 106 in 1981/82 to 26 in the latest year for which there are figures currently available. The average over the last four years has been 29 shipments per year, and perhaps that is the average in the years to come, unless action is taken to deregulate the coastal trade.

SPEECH.PARA: One solution, as against full deregulation of coastal shipping, that has been suggested to me is the revamping of the Single Voyage Permit system (SVP). As the proposal was put to me, the Single Voyage Permit system might be modified to introduce a substantial element of competition into the coastal trade without `throwing the baby out with the bath water'. An appropriate body could meet once a year to grant a limited number of SVPs to each shipowner and coastal shipper on an appropriate tonne-kilometre determination for use at the operational dictates of the company as and when they were needed without further bureaucratic control or delay.

This would be similar to but different from a quota system in that there would be annual public accounting of the use and need of SVPs, with no quota or permit to be sold from one party to another, either overtly or covertly.

This is certainly an attractive idea, but it will require a different kind of amendment to the Navigation Act to make that possible. In the meantime the available evidence from the Department of Transport seems to indicate that the Department is making every effort to reduce rather than extend the number of SVPs each year. At present the availability of alternative road-rail transport is a factor to be considered in the issue of cargo SVPs on the grounds of `public interest', and the question of price differential has never been a consideration used to determine whether or not an SVP will be issued. However, I think that the Government should seriously consider the possibility in the future of issuing a limited number of SVPs in the way I have just outlined.

When Part VI of the Navigation Act was finally ratified in 1921, there was very little competition from other forms of transport, such as road and rail. At that time rail was not used for any purposes other than intrastate, and this situation lasted until World War II; by 1962 a standard gauge made rail for the first time a viable option between Victoria and New South Wales.

In 1921, there was also no competition from road transport-the roads either did not exist, or were not good enough to take heavy traffic safely and quickly between states. After 1954, the Hughes and Vale decision had the effect of eliminating state taxes on road transport and as the highways were improved, road began to be a viable interstate option to shipping.

But in the 1920s there was no competition to the shipping of goods and people between States by sea. Shipowners, at that time, could and did pass the extra costs imposed by the Australian conditions and manning levels in coastal shipping on to the consumers and the users of coastal ships.

By the 1970s coastal shipping services were declining rapidly and this downward move has continued ever since; at the same time there has been a steady increase year by year in the transporting of goods between States by rail and road.

Why has there been this disastrous decline in coastal shipping? As the Industries Assistance Commission pointed out in their Final Report, users of freight services choose between different modes of transport, not only on the basis of cost from door to door, but also on time, reliability and security. For most bulk cargoes, such as iron ore, bauxite, crude oil and petroleum products, shipping is still the preferred option, but coastal shipping is now a poor competitor for non-bulk cargoes and today it accounts for a very small proportion of the market, except for the captive freight movements across Bass Strait.

Two years ago I asked the question: What went wrong with Australian coastal shipping? And two years ago I pointed to Part VI of the Navigation Act for the answer: The terms of Part VI of the Navigation Act gave a monopoly to Australian shipowners (and, de facto, to Australian maritime unions) in the coastal trade of Australia. There was no competition from cheaper overseas shipping. Shipowners have had little or no control over costs-the unions demanded and, by and large, obtained everything they asked for; the unions had to be bought off again and again. It was the classic case of a union monopoly and it has resulted in the highest cost shipping service in the world.
Two years later the Industries Assistance Commission now states in its Report:

Advantages enjoyed by Australian seamen relative to seamen of other comparable nations are, in the main, the outcome of negotiation between shipowners and sea-going unions which have been incorporated into award conditions. Such negotiations have occurred in an environment established by the Navigation Act-which places the sea-going unions in a position of considerable negotiating power (by denying ship operators and users access to alternate shipping services).

After 1921 the cost of labour escalated beyond the means of shipowners and shippers, so as new technology has become available since the 1970s, it has proved too expensive to introduce or has been outlawed by the maritime unions. For instance, when the rest of the world was using more efficient drive-on-drive-off ferries, the ANL was, and still is, running vehicle-deck ships which need specialised equipment to straddle vehicles off and on board. The cost of loading and unloading these vehicles has been estimated to be 40 per cent higher than they would otherwise be on some sort of RORO vessel. The ANL now manages a RORO vessel for Ocean Freeway Pty Ltd in Western Australian waters, and provides officers for Transport Tasmania's Bass Strait ferry, also a RORO vessel, the Abel Tasman.

As I have said, except for the Bass Strait trade and some bulk cargo movements, coastal shipping in Australia is dying. The practical effect of the de facto monopoly provision of the Part VI of the Navigation Act has been to reduce the Australian coastal trade to an `irreducible minimum' to use the words of Captain William Bolitho, the Chairman of the Australian National Maritime Association, which he explains as `that cargo which cannot reasonably be carried by road or rail'.

True, BHP has three newer ships in its service with reduced manning levels, but its shipping costs are still high in comparison with OECD ships if they could be used on similar runs. In addition, BHP has the ability to integrate overseas and coastal shipping to offset some of its high costs; for instance its new ships are used on the coast for only one leg of a triangular run between Australia and Japan.

Who bears the high cost of Australian coastal shipping? In the beginning, the high cost of Australian coastal shipping was passed on directly to the consumer by the shipowner. Nowadays the costs are borne by the shipowner in part, the shipper in part, but ultimately the cost is borne by the consumer and the taxpayer. The consumer and the taxpayer pay for the higher price of steel from BHP, the higher price of goods which are shipped from State to State, the cost of industrial disputes, the subsidies paid to Tasmania in the Freight Equalisation Scheme, and so on.

I keep harping on the high cost of coastal shipping to the community. Let me give you some examples of these high costs and explain how they might have been avoided. Up until 1983 LPG was conveyed to Tasmania in foreign ships by single voyage permit. Since 1983, LPG has been carried in an Australian flag carrier with disastrous results for Tasmania.

LPG is handled by three firms in Tasmania: CIG Energy, Boral and Mobil. Early in 1983 Boral began to use an Australian vessel, the Island Gas, as a carrier for LPG on the Tasmanian run. This vessel at 6,033 dwt is larger than the foreign vessels previously used-with a larger crew of 23 (and, of course, two crews a year) as opposed to less than 16 on the foreign vessels.

Because LPG is a bulk cargo, transporting LPG does not qualify for any subsidy under the scheme of equalising the cost of transport fuels throughout Australia. Since the introduction of the Australian flag ship into the Tasmanian LPG run, the new shipping arrangements have increased the cost of transporting LPG to Hobart by 75 per cent: the cost of this transport has risen from $80 to $140 per tonne, or from 4 cents a litre to 7 cents a litre. And there is no prize for guessing that the consumer pays this added transport cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —The relevant increase in the price is that between January 1983 and June 1983. This was a rise of 55.5 per cent wholly contributable to the increase in shipping costs. At the same time on the mainland, there was also a rise in the price of LPG, but that rise was of the order of 28 per cent-nothing like the enormous price hike of 55.5 per cent in Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: Two years ago I gave the Senate another example of a high cost commodity because of coastal shipping costs-iron ore and steel.

The Industries Assistance Commission estimated in 1981, in their draft report on the Iron and Steel Industry, that BHP's coastal shipping operating costs were between $20m and $25m higher each year than if BHP had been free to use foreign flag vessels from Japan and even higher each year if they had been free to use foreign flag vessels from Europe, say, Sweden or the German Federal Republic.
The same report revealed that the freight cost per tonne of iron ore shipped from Port Hedland to Japan was about half the cost per tonne of the same ore shipped from Port Hedland to Port Kembla.

Sea transport constituted, at that time, about 8 per cent of the total costs of BHP's Steel Division. If these shipping costs could have been halved by using an overseas shipping company from Sweden or the German Federal Republic, the total production costs for producing steel by BHP could have been reduced by about 4 per cent. Since relative figures would be much the same today, think what that would mean to the cost of Australian steel in this country!

Furthermore the unit cost of steel transported from Port Kembla to Perth is still 44 per cent higher than from Japan to Perth. It makes it difficult to want to `Buy Australian', no matter how patriotic you are.

Two years ago I also spoke of the iniquitous and totally unnecessary high cost of Christmas Island phosphate caused by the high cost of Australian shipping once it was deemed that Christmas Island was to be considered as part of the coast of Australia. The IAC in its Final Report also gives Christmas Island phosphate as an example of abnormal freight rates caused by the high cost of Australian shipping:

On the issue of phosphate freight rates, the Phosphate Mining Corporation of Christmas Island suggested that freight charges from Christmas Island to any Australian port are more than double those which would be obtainable on the world market. Reasons advanced for this situation were the high cost of operating Australian ships compared with their world counterparts, and the absence of opportunities for Australian ships to offset northbound ballasting costs (apart from the relatively small quantity of stores shipped to the island from Australia).

What is the result? An exorbitant addition to the cost of phosphate extraction and transport. It must be enough to make an Australian farmer weep when Christmas Island phosphate can be shipped to New Zealand for almost half the cost that it comes to him.

Who pays this double or treble cost for shipping phosphate from one part of Australia to another? The manufacturer, in the first instance, the farmer in the second, and the Australian public in the end. What is the solution for Christmas Island phosphate? It would regain its competitive edge if it were shipped at world freight rates. At least then it would be able to compete with a world supplier such as Florida.

There are, of course, a great many similar examples of the effects of the high price of coastal shipping. The IAC also cites CRA's claims that it is less expensive to move aluminium between Burnie in Tasmania and any Asian port, such as Jakarta, Singapore, or Bangkok, than it is to ship the same aluminium to Sydney. The rate for carrying milk powder from Tasmania to Taiwan is $72 per tonne, but from Tasmania to Melbourne the rate is an exorbitant $82 per tonne-an extra $10 a tonne to take the milk powder to Melbourne rather than Taiwan.

I could go on and on with examples like this which show that freight rates for coastal cargo are ridiculously high in comparison with overseas cargo and that most of these unnecessarily high costs are attributable to overmanning and ridiculous conditions in Australian ships. But manning and on-board conditions are not the only problems for coastal shipping or, in fact, for any shipping in Australia. There is another problem which requires urgent consideration and immediate action and that is the high cost of loading and unloading at ports in comparison with end-handling for road and rail.
`You should not underestimate the gross inefficiency of our waterfront and the damage it does to our economy', is the warning from the Chairman of the Australian National Maritime Association.

Coastal shipping companies suffer from appallingly low productivity at Australian ports, which have the hard-won but unenviable reputation of being the slowest in the world. It takes two days to load or unload 300 containers in an Australian port-it takes four hours using identical equipment to handle 300 containers in Hong Kong, six hours in Singapore and never longer than one day in a European port. This is a problem for both our coastal and overseas shipping, and it is one we must urgently solve if we are to become competitive in a world which does not owe us a living.

To emphasise the absurdity of our present waterfront situation, let me tell you that if deregulation of the coastal shipping trade were to take place, it might seem to the innocent to be feasible to take advantage of an overseas vessel for backloading empty containers from Sydney to Perth or Sydney to Brisbane at backloading rates instead of sending empty containers around this country by rail. But if a container vessel unloads containers at Sydney and next requires them in Brisbane, it costs $280 per container to reposition the empty containers by rail from Sydney to Brisbane. But to carry the same empty containers in one's own ship between Sydney and Brisbane costs $572 per container. Why? Because it costs $236 to load each container back onto the ship at Sydney and another $236 to unload the container at Brisbane. This is an absurd distortion of the economic use of our transport facilities.

It is obvious that coastal shipping is in an appalling state. Honourable senators should take the time to read the last available report of the Australian National Line and they would find constant references to problems for Australian coastal shipping and for Australian shipping in general. Most of these problems, of course, result from intransigent unions and inflexible work practices. To quote one or two passages from the 1986/87 Report:

The viability of the coastal shipping industry in general, and ANL's participation in particular, came under serious doubt during the year, as the combination of severe competition (i.e. from road and rail), industrial stoppages, rising costs and static, or declining, real-term freight rates made the rationalisation of services the only alternative to outright withdrawal.
During 1986/87 112 ship operating days were lost to ANL vessels through industrial disputes while an additional 84 operating days were lost to other vessels being worked by ANL terminals.

Something drastic has to happen and it has to happen quickly. So what is the solution for Australian coastal shipping? Most people who are truly concerned about the high cost structure of Australian coastal shipping strongly advocate complete deregulation of coastal shipping, permitting foreign vessels to carry coastal cargoes without the requirements of Australian standards of manning and conditions.

The Business Council of Australia has just released a Coastal Shipping Action Plan designed to boost the competitiveness of Australian shipping deregulating the market and phasing in foreign competition.

The introduction of competition from foreign-flag vessels is a fundamental element of any plan to encourage and maintain a competitive Australian industry, and must be supported with removal of cost impediments unique to Australian shipping.

Even the latest Report of the Australian National Line, while advocating a strong Australian shipping industry, admits that `there is a limit to what can be achieved by corporate economies and internal efficiencies and that further corrective action is now inhibited by the institutional rigidities in Australia of the industry itself and the competitive environment within which it is carried on'.

The IAC Report, as I mentioned before, has clearly stated that, despite the initiatives of the Crawford and the Maritime Industry Development Committee, reform is too slow and leaves us still constantly behind our competitors, because while we improve at our very slow pace in manning levels and technical efficiencies, our competitors are also improving, but more swiftly and more effectively. And I stress again that by `competitors' I mean those OECD nations with standards of living similar to or higher than ours.
What would be the gains to Australia if Australia adopted an `open seas' policy by which any user of coastal shipping would be free to purchase the services of a shipping operator of their choice?
Let me emphasise that there is no doubt that the gains to all Australians would be enormous.

First, there would be savings in subsidies. Australian coastal liner services could not possibly survive without subsidies, especially the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation subsidy. These subsidies cost Australia $27.5m in 1986/87. If coastal shipping were opened up to all comers, it is certain that Australia's coastal general cargo services would have to become rapidly more efficient and less costly to survive. And if overseas shipping picked up these services and performed them at a cheaper rate, the gain to Australia would be the price of the subsidies, which is the only inducement at present for ANL to maintain a general cargo coastal service. The result would be a saving to Australia of at least $30m per year.

Administrative costs might also be further reduced in face of competition from overseas ships. Every ANL report indicates that the managerial staff levels are too high, but I have been delighted to see that there have been strenuous efforts to make reductions in administrative staff; I am also convinced that there has also been every effort made to reduce and rationalise seagoing personnel, with little result on the older ships in the ANL fleet, but with some hope for the future of the newer ships and among the younger newly trained seamen.

There would also be some saving in fuel costs as Australian ships moved to compete with the more fuel efficient overseas vessels. There is already some progress in Australia towards replacing existing tonnage from the older and less fuel efficient ships to newer, smaller and more efficient ships, but ANL still has a number of the less efficient and therefore more costly ships on the coastal run.

There is also a possibility of cost savings through greater flexibility in the use of ships, which is likely to occur through competition from overseas ships. For instance, it is possible that Australian coastal ships might adopt the flexibility of the ABC Containerline vessels which carry bulk cargoes and containers in combination. Many bulk carriers operating around the Australian coast at present often operate with certain legs of their voyage in ballast. By the combination system, they could operate bulk on some legs and container on others. This could have enormous potential for Australian overseas trade, because it is eminently suitable for Australian ships to concentrate on bulk cargoes on outward voyages and on containers on inward legs.

But the biggest savings would undoubtedly come in the excessively high cost area in Australian shipping-manning and conditions. There would have to be a speeding up of the present glacially slow progress in crew reductions. Remember that the cost of manning and running an Australian ship is about twice the cost of running a Swedish or a German ship, and remember that Australia runs two complete crews for every one of its ships. The latest estimated cost for Australian crews is $100,000 per year per crew member. Therefore every crew member saved per year is a saving of $100,000 per year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Immediate cost savings can be achieved even now on Australian ships if certain services on board ship are radically altered; bedmaking services could be dispensed with, cafeteria style catering could be introduced without reducing living standards on board ship, and the incredible waste of food might be avoided by eliminating the requirement for two choices of hot dishes to be cooked for all crew even if most of them are ashore during a port stop. The result would be a saving in the cost of steward services for the crew and a large reduction in the very high cost of victualling. In a total crew of between 31 and 37 on an Australian ship, cooks, stewards and crew attendants account for 8 of these crew. If this number were reduced by at least two or three, in line with the number of service crew on a Swedish or a German ship, that would represent a saving of $200,000 or $300,000 per ship per year.

SPEECH.PARA: Two things have to be considered in this high cost area of Australian manning. First, existing ships in the Australian fleet, which is the majority of the total Australian fleet, have always operated at historically high manning levels, dating from the very beginning of the Navigation Act back in 1911. And historically it has proved almost impossible to reduce the crew levels on these ships. I incorporate a table which will show the crew levels for all Australian ships at the present time.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Honourable Senators will observe, the ships marked with an asterisk have had no reduction in crew numbers despite the Crawford recommendations nor all the stated aims of Captain Bolitho of the ANL. And remember that even a reduction of one crew member represents a saving of $100,000 per year.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, newer ships have been introduced into the Australian coastal run, such as the three most recent ships for BHP, and these are now manned with smaller crews, roughly 26 for each ship-or that is 52 a year for each ship-and that does represent a reduction of about six to eight crew members for each ship. As shipping tonnage is replaced there is no doubt that there will be some reduction in crew numbers with the result of a considerable cost saving for every ship.

But in both the case of the older ships and the newer ships, we still have to provide 2.2 seamen for every crew billet. This is because our seamen get six months leave a year on a six weeks on, six weeks off basis. This figure of 338 days leave for each year's work for an Australian should be compared to 226 days for a Frenchman, 216 for an American, 174 for a West German and 141 for a Norwegian. TALK.START.PARA: —Apart from these leave entitlements, which are the most generous in the world, Australian maritime unions have also fought for and won outrageous sick leave reimbursements. A seaman who has been sick for more than seven days is entitled to seven days' wages after he has recovered. Many unfit and useless seamen are reluctantly kept in the work force because of the very generous conditions obtained under the Seamen's Compensation Act. It is cheaper to keep a totally useless sailor in the Seamen's Engagement System or on board a ship than to try to retire him because of the over-generous benefits to be gained under the Seamen's Compensation Act. The average age of Australian seamen is over 50 and there is obviously an urgent need for a fair and proper retirement scheme for older seamen-not another rort or racket such as the retirement scheme in operation on the waterfront, but a fair and proper scheme to benefit seamen who have spent the greater part of their working lives on board Australian ships, and to enable shipowners to employ younger seamen without the crippling costs incurred under the present Seamen's Compensation Act.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, Honourable Senators should know that Australian crew members have to be provided with first class accommodation and air travel when they are joining or leaving their vessel. Very few employees in the Australian work force enjoy this privilege. In addition, crew members are paid award rates for time spent travelling to and from the ship. These travel and accommodation costs are further inflated because of inflexibilities in the crew roster system which dictates that crew changes for many ships take place at six week intervals, regardless of the location of the vessel in Australia. All of these high cost rorts have been won by unions in a monopoly situation created by the provisions of Part VI of the Navigation Act.

Every available report and document dealing with coastal shipping in Australia arrives at one conclusion: `There is no doubt that if cabotage were abandoned in Australia coastal shipping, major savings in the cost of domestic sea transport could be realised'. And the greatest area of savings are to be achieved in manning. I cannot repeat too often, that a saving of one crew member represents a saving of $100,000 per year.

In addition, if any user of coastal shipping were free to purchase the services of a shipping operator of his choice, oil companies would be able to reduce their costs by integrating their Australian vessels into their own overseas fleets and operate them under a foreign flag. As a result, Tasmania could have cheaper LPG as in the years before 1983. Some overseas flag vessels would probably enter the coastal bulk ore trade, and BHP could take advantage of that to reduce their steel costs. It is also possible that some Australian companies would purchase an interest in overseas shipping companies to maintain their own carrying capacity on the coast and reap the benefits of the lower cost overseas carriers.

At last the Australian maritime unions would be forced to do something about a real reduction in manning levels and crew costs. Despite all the rhetoric of the Crawford Report and the various Labor Ministers for Transport, there has been no substantial reduction in the number of seamen and the manning costs for the majority of the ships in the Australian fleet, i.e. all the ships commissioned before 1986.

Technical changes in ship construction and operation in other parts of the world have produced very large bulk carriers with manning levels of 50% of what they were a few years ago. There is also a variety of new efficient cargo carriers as well as container vessels operating with reduced crews. But what are we doing?

There is no doubt that there has been extensive negotiation between the ANL management and the five maritime unions which represent the seagoing 58% of the ANL work force-now reduced to three, I am glad to say-and the unions did concede to reduce ship manning levels by a total of 81 berths across the fleet. But what were the terms of this negotiation? `No further manning reductions to take place on current ANL vessels after the reduction of 81'. So the original Crawford proposals achieved very little-as I long suspected and have constantly stated here in this Parliament. The unions agreed only to a minimal reduction in crew levels, so that they could stand back and say: `Look, what good fellows we are!'. But after that, it is `hands off' further reductions on existing ships. Further legislation was required to enforce lower manning levels on new ships in the Australian fleet, but these levels which are still above the rest of comparable OECD ships. So the rest of the world goes on producing efficient ships efficiently run with small and highly productive crews and we look on with our large crews-and two of them for every ship-and have no hope of competing-and the community has to go on paying for this incompetence and union greed.

One problem of deregulation is the possibility of entry into the coastal service of Flag of Convenience (FOC) ships. But is that really a problem? By and large the less desirable FOC ships-the so-called `rust buckets'-do not attempt to come to Australian ports, because it is well known that Australia imposes stringent safety regulations on any ship entering Australian ports. In the latest Annual Report of the Department of Transport, seven instances of sub-standard ships in Australian ports were notified to the International Maritime Organisation during 1986/7; the deficiencies were serious in two cases and the Master of a Chinese ship was prosecuted and fined. Australian overseas shipping regulations also demand that ships entering Australian ports have crews manned and paid according to minimum ITF rates.

However, flag of convenience or open registry ships form about a third of the world's cargo fleet, and they have proved to be very important in cost reduction; they provide an economic and efficient means of transport through the operation of free markets in charter shipping.
Even the Department of Transport has had to admit the value of FOC shipping services to Australia. In 1981 the Department stated:
These vessels, which operate on the spot charter market, of necessity offer lower freight rates and in consequence have been an important factor in holding down rates in the bulk trades.

The Industry Task Force Review of Australia's Overseas Liner Shipping Legislation also reported that `low cost shipping had contributed to providing important competitive advantages to Australian Shippers'.

By far the most important open registries at this time are Liberia, Panama, Singapore and Cyprus, and others include the Bahamas, Bermuda, the Seychelles, Cayman Island, Barbados, Somalia, Morocco, Honduras, Costa Rica, Lebanon, San Marino, Haiti, Malta, Vanuatu, Nigeria, Sri Lanka and Sierra Leone. These ships are very important in Australian overseas shipping. For instance, in the two middle quarters of last year 6,156 ships used Australian ports for the purpose of conveying cargo to and/or from Australia. Of these only 380 were our own Australian Ships, but 399 were from Liberia and 1,095 were from Panama. These are the ships which have permitted Australian shippers to have some bargaining leverage in overseas trades. But the unions have made many attempts to bar these and other overseas ships from Australian trades. Already Newcastle is a closed port to FOC vessels, although this is an entirely illegal action taken by unions without the sanction of law.

What will stop the unions from banning other ports to FOC vessels or other overseas vessels conveying coastal trade? Section 45d of the Trade Practices Act is the only piece of legislation which specifically prevents trade unions taking boycotting action against overseas vessels which may in the future choose to take on coastal trade activities in Australia. The Columbus Line from Germany, a highly respected flag line, has been picketed by trade unions over a period of years simply because it is a foreign shipping line, but Section 45d has prevented the unions from actually banning the Columbus ships from entering and leaving Australian ports. And, given a firm government will, the same act can be used to prevent the selfish denial of shipping services which would benefit the whole community.

For, in the end, the only way to force down the cost of coastal shipping in Australia may be to widen the competition to include vessels with a lower cost structure than Australia. There is absolutely no doubt that Australia has the highest cost structure in the world for shipping. The unit cost of transporting coal from Newcastle to Port Hedland would be drastically reduced if the coal were carried in a Japanese ship at Japanese standards of manning and conditions, and the unit cost would be halved if the coal were carried in a Swedish ship, Belgian ship or a German ship at European standards of manning and conditions.

In the end, competition is the only way to reduce Australian costs in shipping. All the consensuses, or consultations or Accords that this Government or any other government can ever dream up will never achieve cheaper shipping in Australia. The only way to achieve it is by competition.

Some people will argue that introducing overseas ships into the coastal trade is the same thing as employing cheap labour from a developing nation to drive the buses in Australian cities, or permitting the Koreans to set up a steel works in Australia with cheaper Korean labour and Korean standards of wages and conditions. The analogy is false and misleading. What Australia does do is import a wide range of goods from the Third World, especially Pacific countries, such as textiles, craft works and clothing, reaping the benefit of the cheaper labour content of these goods. By doing so, we introduce competition in Australia for similar goods and the lower price of the imported goods are a benefit to the consumer; these goods are also important because they assist to hedge inflation and increase competition in the domestic economy.

The present coastal shipping situation is economically untenable-bulk goods will continue to be carried around the coast in ships, but other goods will more and more resort to the uneconomic transport facilities provided by road and rail, unless a cheaper form of shipping can be provided on the Australian coast. Non-bulk shipping on the coast will gradually die, to the great loss of the Australian economy.

As Mr McWilliams so correctly predicted in 1912, Part VI of the Navigation Act has become a monster-`a sure and certain chain round the whole Australian coast'. And it was this Federal Parliament which put this monster into place. This Parliament endowed Australia with a union monopoly which has resulted in the most expensive shipping service in the world.

Even in 1924-just three years after Part VI came into force, there was an urgent public plea for the repeal of Part VI. The Report of the Royal Commission on the Navigation Act in 1924 was quite definite and precise: `the Navigation Act has failed in its purpose to build up an Australian Mercantile Marine'. The Report concluded: `The only recommendation which your Commissioners desire to make is one which will remove most of the grounds for complaint before your Commissioners, and that recommendation is that Part VI (the Coastal Trade) of the Act be repealed'.
With that recommendation I heartily concur. It has long been Liberal Party policy to repeal protective provisions in the Navigation Act.

I think that this Parliament should pass this Bill to deregulate coastal shipping, but not proclaim it. We should pass it to keep it in reserve. There have been in the last two years, since I first introduced this Bill, some slight improvements in crewing arrangements on new ships commissioned since 1986. Integrated training has eliminated the distinction between deck hands and engine room hands, mess arrangements have been rationalised and some officers' positions, such as the radio officer, will become redundant in the next decade. However, that is not enough to ensure the viability of a flourishing coastal shipping industry. I emphasise `flourishing', because at the moment, with the best will in the world, all that conciliation and consultation with the unions is achieving is just keeping coastal shipping afloat in those areas where there is no competition at all-the Tasmanian trade and the bulk goods which cannot conveniently be conveyed by rail or road. The rest is dying, and unless more drastic measures are taken we will not reverse this trend.

We must have a carrot as well as a stick. We should keep this Bill in reserve. If the unions will co-operate to save a dying industry, if they will agree to accommodation standards and on-board conditions that are comparable to OECD ships, if they will agree to reduced manning levels-not just token reductions, but real reductions in line with other OECD ships, if they will co-operate to perform more maintenance and repair work on board ship to prevent unnecessary delays in dry dock, if they will co-operate to bring down total crew costs on Australian ships, if they will agree to leave entitlements that are in line with OECD countries, if they will accept revisions to the Seamen's Compensation Act so that it is no longer uneconomic to sack useless seamen, if they will agree to sensible victualling and the same travel and accommodation arrangements as the majority of the Australian work force, if they will agree to a fair and proper retirement scheme to allow younger seamen to be engaged-if the unions would agree to all these arrangements, then the Government will be able to do everything in its power to expand and encourage the carriage of goods in Australian ships around the coast. Then the day will come when Australian ships will again be able to profitably engage in not only the coastal shipping market in competition with road and rail, but also more competitively in the overseas shipping industry as well, instead of the present situation where only 4% of our trade is carried in Australian ships.

As I have just said, we should pass this Bill, so that it is in place to be used if the unions will not co-operate to prevent the demise of their own industry. If the present trend of an ever reducing coastal fleet and very high costs on the older ships continues, then this Parliament would have no other alternative than to proclaim the Act and open up coastal shipping to foreign competition.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robert Ray) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Sessional Orders, and unless otherwise ordered, the routine of business on Thursday, 13 October 1988, be as follows:
That the following Bill be introduced:

A Bill for an Act to regulate the use of certain substances that can significantly deplete or otherwise modify the ozone layer in a manner that is likely to have adverse effects on human health and the environment, and for related purposes.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.
SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill updates and extends the Ozone Depleting Substances Regulation Bill 1988 which I introduced on 15 April 1988. It incorporates several suggested amendments and this speech canvasses in more detail two important issues: recycling v substitution and pharmaceutical uses of chlorofluorcarbons.

Probably no threat to the global environment involves such wide spread, serious and long lasting damage as the reduction in stratospheric ozone being brought about by the release of chlorofluorcarbons (CFCs) or freons. CFCs are a class of hydrocarbon chemicals in which some or all of the hydrogen atoms have been replaced with chlorine and fluorine. I incorporate in Hansard a table relating to this matter.
TABLE 1
Freon 11 ...
CFCl3
Freon 12 ...
CF2Cl2
Freon 22 ...
CHF2Cl
Freon 113 ...
C2F3Cl3
Freon 114 ...
C2F4Cl2
Freon 115 ...
C2F5Cl
History

TALK.START.PARA: —CFCs were first synthesised in 1928 and came into use as refrigerant gases. They had an advantage over earlier gases being less toxic, non-flammable and apparently inert. In 1974 two US chemists, Molina and Rowland posed a simple question, `What had happened to the millions of tons of CFC which had been released in the previous 46 years?' The only `sink' they could hypothesise was the stratosphere were these otherwise stable compounds would be bombarded and degraded by the intense short wave ultra-violet (UV) light which comes from the sun. They quickly realised that if they were right, stratospheric breakdown of CFCs by UV would release atomic chlorine which would catalyse the destruction of ozone.

SPEECH.PARA: Ozone or O3 is the gas which protects the lower atmosphere and earth's surface from very damaging short wave UV. Rowland and Molina warned that this hypothetical model should be checked out, for if correct, the consequences for life on earth would be serious indeed.

Studies were done and by 1976 the US National Academy of Science (NAS) was confirming these earlier predictions and recommending restrictions on the use of CFCs. In 1979 CFCs, which by then had come into very widespread use as pressure pack propellants, were banned from this application in the US, Canada, Sweden and Norway. Other countries, including Australia, continued to allow their use for this purpose. As well as continuing in use as refrigerant gases, throughout the 70s and 80s CFCs were used increasingly as the expanding gases in the manufacture of both rigid and soft plastic foams. Most recently CFCs have been extensively used as solvents for degreasing electronic chips.
Ozone Formation

The primitive earth's atmosphere contained large amounts of carbon dioxide and was reducing rather than oxidising. Consequently the earth's surface was not protected from short wave UV by a stratospheric ozone layer. Indeed, life possibly began through the action of UV light on molecules in a reducing environment. Thus life evolved in and remained in the seas for a long period. Water protected it from the sun's lethal UV radiation. Not until green plants produced oxygen by photosynthesis and some of this oxygen formed ozone in the stratosphere could plants and animals survive on dry land. The oxygen to ozone conversion occurs in the stratosphere and is also caused by UV.
Long Term Damage to Ozone

CFCs released at the earth's surface take about 5 years to rise through the atmosphere to the stratosphere where they catalyse ozone destruction. Once there the two freons in widest use (F11 and F12) remain in the stratosphere for between 75 and 150 years before being degraded and removed. The best available evidence shows between a 1% and 3% reduction in global stratospheric ozone in the last 10 years, lower reductions near the equator, greater near the poles (Cicerone, 1987). In this 10 years ozone has been cut by 50% over the south pole during spring.

In 1987 research in the Antarctic confirmed the presence of chlorine oxide, and active intermediate in the catalysts of ozone, and it is now widely accepted that the most probable cause of the Antarctic ozone hole is release of CFCs to the atmosphere.
While a number of chemical pathways have been hypothesised and many intermediates detected the major catalytic path may be summarised as:
Cl + O3 ClO + O2
ClO + O3 Cl + 2O2
Eventually chlorine is washed out by conversion to hydrochloric acid:
2Cl + H2O 2HClO 2HCl + O2

The enhanced ozone depletion in the Antarctic spring may be due to reactions involving chlorine nitrate and hydrochloric acid, catalysed by the presence of ice and nitric acid crystals in the stratosphere (Molina et al, 1987 and Tolbert et al, 1987).
Consequences

Short wave UV is destructive to all living cells causing damage to both DNA and proteins. It increases skin cancers and cataracts, changes immune responses and damages the lavel forms of sea life that spend time in the top few millimetres of the seas. These organisms form the base of most aquatic food chains. Their destruction has the most serious consequences for all marine and fresh-water life. All other species suffer variable damage. A quantitative indication of consequences is given by the following: a 3% reduction in ozone gives about a 6% increase in relevant short wave UV which gives about a 12% increase in skin cancer (see numerous references in USEPA, UNEP Vol 1 Overview, 1986).

Ozone is a very selective filter of shorter wave UV, ie., the most biologically active. A 10% reduction in stratospheric ozone gives a 20% increase in UV penetration of 305 nm, a 250% increase at 290 nm and a 500% increase at 287 nm. DNA and proteins absorb maximally at about 260 nm and 280 nm respectively. Frequencies in this region are particularly damaging (nm=nanometre, a measure of wavelength). (See Figure 1).

Because of CFC's long residence time in the stratosphere Hoffman of the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has calculated that ozone will continue to disappear unless CFC release is cut by 85% immediately and this 15% level or less is then maintained. This conclusion has been generally accepted by the scientific community. Figures 2 & 3 are from Hoffman's paper in USEPA, UNEP Volume 1, Overview, 1986.

Although UV increase as a consequence of ozone destruction is the most immediate concern it should not be forgotten that CFSs are also very effective greenhouse gases, far more effective than carbon dioxide. Their role as greenhouse gases is only overshadowed by carbon dioxide because of the latter's much higher concentration in the atmosphere. Nonetheless while carbon dioxide will provide about 47% of the greenhouse warming between 1980 and 2030, CFCs will contribute as much as 27%. Moreover, while the atmospheric concentration of carbon dioxide is increasing at about 0.5% p.a., CFC 11 and 12 are increasing at 5 and 7% p.a. respectively. As shown in Figure 4, under the conditions of the Montreal Protocol, if all nations limit their production to 0.3 kg/head (and limit population to its present size) CFC 11 and 12 in the atmosphere would still increase sixfold over the next two centuries. (See Figure 4).
The Vienna Convention and the Montreal Protocol

For several years the United Nations Environment Program (UNEP) has been bringing nations together to discuss this threat to the global ozone, the most recent meeting being in Montreal in late 1987. It was there agreed that a protocol will come into force on 1 January 1989. Six months later nations are to set CFC consumption at 1986 levels, between 1993 and 94 to cut consumption by 20% and by 1999 by 50%.
The 1986 production is calculated by multiplying the actual production of each freon by its Ozone Depleting Potential (ODP) and totalling the resulting figures.

Developing countries whose consumption of `controlled substances' (the term used in the protocol) is less than 0.3 kg per capita per year may delay their compliance with the control measures for up to 10 years provided their annual consumption does not exceed 0.3 kg per capita. For comparison, Australia's 1986 consumption was about 1.1 kg per capita.
Table 2 compares the US, Australian and Chinese absolute and per capita consumption of CFCs 11 and 12:

These figures underscore two important points:
1. An average Australian uses CFC at 45 times the rate of an average Chinese. This places a heavy personal responsibility on individual Australians to reduce their use of CFCs.

2. On the other hand China's population is very large and the absolute impact which China would have on the earth's ozone were she to adopt the pattern of CFC use found in the US and Australia would be enormous. It is therefore imperative that alternative technologies be found and implemented quickly.

Extending the Chinese example it should be noted that 1986 production/release was approximately 0.16 kg/head averaged over the whole planet. Bringing all people to 0.3 kg/year consumption, while cutting industrial countries' production by 70-80% would, nonetheless, mean a doubling of global production. (See Figure 4).
