1. CFC 11 and 12 contributed 13,100 (74%) of Australia's 1986 ozone depleting potential.
2. CFC 22 use in refrigerators and air conditioners was 26% of all CFCs used in refrigeration. The ODP of CFC 22 is very low.

3. Contribution by sector to Australia's 1986 ozone depleting potential: Aerosols 29%, Refrigeration and air-conditioning 25%, Foams 19%, Solvent 4%, Halons 22% (the actual release of halons only contributed 2%).

4. Considering CFC alone the removal of CFCs from pressure packs, the exclusive use of CFC 22 in refrigerators and an 85% recycling of CFC used in foam manufacture and as solvents could cut the ozone depleting potential by 96.5%.

TALK.START.PARA: —As of April 1988 only the US and Mexico have ratified the Montreal Protocol.

SPEECH.PARA: Halons 1211 and 1301 are CF2BrC1 and CF3Br respectively. They are widely used in fire extinguishers. The provision of an extinguisher is a precaution one hopes will never be needed. Therefore most of these halons will never be used. It is estimated that in 1986 only 30t of halons were actually released to the atmosphere. However in the absence from Australia of a high temperature incinerator to dispose safely of these stable and persistent chemicals and in view of their very high ozone depleting potential the halons must also be rapidly phased out of use. By the very nature of their application they cannot be recycled.
Recycling v Substitution

A great deal of prominence has been given to the replacement of CFC 11 and 12 with substitutes which are much less damaging to stratospheric ozone and an impression has been given that this substitution will solve the `problem'. Two CFCs often mentioned are CFC 123 and 134A. These are only partly halogenated; their molecules contain some hydrogen which has not been replaced by chlorine or fluorine. They are less stable chemically, break down more quickly and therefore do not persist in the stratosphere for as long. Molecule for molecule they would therefore cause only a fraction of the ozone damage as CFC 11 and 12. CFC 22 (table 1) is a partly halogenated CFC already in widespread use. Its ozone depleting potential is thought to be about 3% of that of CFC 11 and 12. The use of these substitutes would reduce but not abolish ozone depletion assuming that per capita release did not rise and populations remained constant.

Global per capita CFC release is about 0.16 Kg per year which is about one-fifth the per capita release of Australians (nearer one-sixth compared with Americans). The prevailing view is that industrial development is expected to spread into less developed countries over the next few decades and global population is expected to double in 35 years. Thus merely substituting these more benign CFCs for 11 and 12 without also imposing strict controls on release can only slow ozone depletion. It cannot prevent substantial damage. Recycling must be an important component of any strategy designed to properly address the problem of stratospheric ozone depletion.

The Montreal Protocol seeks control through production cuts. This Bill seeks to control emissions which, through reducing demand, will bring about production cuts. The advantage of this approach is the emphasis on recycling which must remain an important part of any effective strategy into the foreseeable future.

CFCs, including the new, partly halogenated CFCs, are very potent greenhouse gases. It has been estimated that CFC 123 and 134A have about 10% of the greenhouse potential of CFC 11 and 12. As pointed out above, approximately 27% of greenhouse warming between 1980 and 2030 is expected to be due to CFCs. For this reason also, substitution without recycling will merely exacerbate the problem of greenhouse warming.

Recycling also has a distinct cost advantage. Du Pont have recently estimated that setting up new plants to manufacture the new CFCs will cost $10 billion globally. Recycling to the extent of 95% would substantially reduce the size and cost of these new production facilities.
Pharmaceutical uses of CFCs

CFC's have been used in recent years to deliver metered doses of aerosols, especially in the treatment of asthma. This method of medication has advantages in that it is portable, it has a fast action, it delivers the medication to the site needed, the bronchial tree, rather than the whole body and it can be used by the patient early in an attack, sometimes preventing a full blown asthma attack from occurring. For this reason some legislation has sought to exclude from control CFCs used in pharmaceuticals. The pharmaceutical industry, notably Glaxo, has contended that there are no alternatives.

Australians currently release about 170 tonnes of CFC 12 into the atmosphere each year from this source and Glaxo state they expect this amount to rise and plateau at about 260 tonnes. The health costs of this release must be weighed against the health benefits. Increasing UV, consequent on ozone depletion, causes increases in skin cancer and other diseases. In 1982 there were approximately 3,000 cases of malignant melanoma diagnosed in Australia. About 15% or 450 patients had survival times of less than 5 years. Malignant melanoma is the fifth most common cancer in men and the third most common cancer in women.

If one exempts this use in Australia then we must exempt this use throughout the world unless we are prepared to argue for our use and deny it to those in Third World countries. Extension of Australia's per capita pharmaceutical use to the whole world would result in a global release of 100,000 tonnes per year or one-eighth of present release from all sources. I believe the health and other costs of this release would far outweigh the benefits.

I am not convinced that the advantages of this method of administering drugs could not be achieved using a gas other than CFC 12 but the stimulus for developing such a system will not be present if a time-limit for phasing CFCs out of use is not set. Carbon dioxide, which is already widely and cheaply dispensed in small containers as soda siphon sparklets, is one possibility. The matter of a longer phase-out period to allow the necessary re-design of dispensers would better be handled by way of regulation rather than providing a permanent dispensation in the Bill.
Too Little Too Late
Recognising that:
a. the Montreal Protocol falls far short of the 85% immediate reduction that is required. (Since 1986 actual ozone depletion has always exceeded computer predictions.)
b. the problem relates to CFC release to atmosphere, not in use
c. bringing in new gases and new technology in, say refrigeration, requires fairly long lead times,
on behalf of the Australian Democrats I introduced a motion in the Senate last year to achieve two things:
i. Eliminate the trivial and non essential uses of CFCs, i.e. in pressure packs.
ii. insist on recycling of CFCs in all other applications.

Both Government and Opposition in speaking to this motion recognised that global ozone depletion caused by CFC release was the most important environmental problem. I incorporate in Hansard the five figures to which I have referred.
The Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clear that much more needs to be done to reduce the release of ozone depleting substances than is incorporated in the Montreal Protocol. The Protocol specifically allows nations to proceed with CFC reduction faster than the mutually agreed 20% then 50% reduction by the end of the century. This is not only desirable it is both necessary and possible.

SPEECH.PARA: CFC use in pressure pack cans cannot be defended and should be phased out quickly and completely. This is a non-essential use of CFCs. Twenty-five per cent of pressure packs on Australian shelves still contain CFCs. Trivial applications, such as use in cosmetics appear to be expanding in Australia. It would be disastrous if China were to follow this path! In all other applications CFCs could be recycled. When a refrigerator requires regassing or gets to the end of its life the CFC could and should be collected, cleaned and recycled. At present it is merely bled to the atmosphere.

Table 3 shows that freon 22 has an ozone depleting potential near to zero. CFCs with unsubstituted hydrogens appear to be much less stable. Replacing CFC 11 and 12 with CFC 22 in refrigerators (where possible) would substantially reduce the ODP.

If CFCs continue to be used in foam expansions and solve applications, these processes could and should be carried out in closed systems, the CFC sucked off, condensed and recycled. Already Unifoam AG, Glarus, Switzerland, a plastic foam manufacturer has developed a process which is achieving 85% recycling. (Modern Plastics International, November, 1987, p.66.)
There are foaming gases other than CFCs in widespread use. Hydrocarbons have been used extensively but, as with pressure packs, they pose a risk because of their flammability.

It's clear that our ultimate aim should be to eliminate CFC use entirely. However, with CFCs a part of so many aspects of our industrial life style this cannot be achieved as quickly as necessary. The lead times for change are too long. But the achievement of 85%+ reduction is possible by elimination of unnecessary uses (pressure packs) and recycling in others.

1. The title of the Bill avoids reference to chlorofluorocarbons and uses the term ``Ozone Depleting Substances''. There are a number of non-chlorofluorocarbon substances which have ozone depleting characteristics, e.g. the 1,1,1,-trichloroethane used as a solvent in typist correcting fluid. At present these are not major contributors to ozone depletion. However the Bill leaves the way open to control the use and release of any of these agents should future research show that to be necessary.

2. The definition of ``ozone depleting substance'' (O.D.S.) in 3. (1) is in two parts. Part (a) adopts Group 1 of Annex A to the Montreal Protocol while part (b) allows the declaration of any other substance to be an O.D.S. It should be noted that part (a) does not include CFC 22 which has an ozone depleting potential of 0.03 compared with CFC 11 or 12 which have an ozone depleting potential of 1.0. As 26% of the CFC used in refrigerators in Australia in 1986 was CFC 22 rather than CFC 11 or 12, CFC 22 will almost certainly need eventual control. However, this Bill, which is designed to make the most rapid reduction in ODS release at the earliest opportunity, allows the uncontrolled use of CFC 22 to continue at present.

Halons are also not included at this stage. As mentioned earlier the ozone depleting potential of halons is large but, at the moment, release of halons is small. It is anticipated that halons will be quickly brought under this legislation but that 12 months, the ``period of grace'' allowed in this Bill, may be insufficient for the transition to alternatives for extinguishers. As the nature of their use precludes recycling of halons the only course open is total abandonment of their use.

3. The Bill sets a ``period of grace'' of twelve months after which the controls on substances, equipment and practices outlined in the Bill will become operative. The Bill contains no retrospective element with respect to equipment although, of course, bulk stocks of ODSs held at the end of the period of grace will become subject to control.
4. Clause 5 bans the use of ODSs in aerosols.

5. Clause 6 requires that all new refrigeration equipment, including air conditioners, be so constructed that contained ODSs can be collected, safely stored and recycled. Clause 8 requires that ODSs in equipment manufactured or sold after the end of the period of grace be collected and not allowed to escape when the equipment is serviced. Clause 9 requires that before disposal at the end of its useful life such equipment will be drained of its ODSs so that no ODS escapes to the atmosphere.

6. Clause 7 covers other uses of ODSs such as foam blowing and solvent degreasing. It requires that these operations be carried out in closed systems in such a way that ODS vapours can be removed safely, stored and not allowed to escape to the atmosphere.
Recognising that total recycling in such applications is clearly impossible, the clause sets a minimum of 85% efficiency in this recycling operation.

Both the major uses of ODSs covered by this clause are fairly large scale commercial operations for which the measurement of efficiency in recycling should be straightforward. In both applications there are non-CFC alternatives and some use of CFC 22.
I reiterate that equipment is available and in use in Switzerland for the manufacture of plastic foams which achieves an 85% efficiency of recycling of ODSs.

7. Clause 11 prohibits the exportation from Australia of equipment which does not conform to the new requirements imposed by this Bill. While Australia can have no control over the manner of use of this equipment in foreign hands, this requirement should act as an encouragement to behave responsibly.

8. Clause 10 controls the safe storage, transport and handling of ODSs. Once it becomes illegal to release ODSs to atmosphere those holding used ODSs collected from serviced or scrapped equipment or recycled solvent or foaming agents will have only two methods of disposing of these materials. Either they may be destroyed in a high temperature incinerator, which Australia does not yet possess, or they may be cleaned, redistilled and recycled into use. It is anticipated that this Bill will force this latter course.

In some quarters fears have been expressed that substantial diminution in CFC manufacture in Australia will lead to unemployment in that industry. Recycling of CFC's with a need to redistill or otherwise purify used, mixed or contaminated CFC almost certainly in the same facilities now involved in manufacture of CFC, will accommodate some of this potential unemployment.
9. Clauses 15-18 create the mechanisms for inspection by identifiable authorised persons of places and equipment and the taking and keeping of records.

10. Clause 21 enables the creation of regulations which require the keeping of records by appropriate persons and the specification of which records should be kept. Regulations will also require the labelling of refrigeration equipment and set the manner in which processes involving ODSs are to be carried out.

11. Clause 20 has the effect that the Bill will operate in relation to natural persons or bodies corporate who manufacture etc., in the course of or for the purposes of trade and commerce among the States and Territories or overseas.
For the information of Honourable Senators I would point out that the following changes to the Bill as originally presented and read a first time on 15 April 1988, have been made:

In Clause 2, the date of 1.1.89 has been adopted rather than a date to be fixed by Proclamation. As the Bill includes a 12-month period of grace before the various controls become operative it is felt this provides sufficient time for those affected to comply, it provides certainty and it also meets the recognised urgent need to quickly reduce the release of Ozone Depleting Substances into the atmosphere.

In Clause 3, ``examinable documents'' have been extended to include books and documents relating to ``the manufacture'' of Ozone Depleting Substances. This may have been included in (c) as originally worded; the addition makes it quite clear.
In Clause 3, ``sell'' has been extended to cover leasing or rental arrangements.

In Clause 11, prohibition of exportation of Ozone Depleting Substance containing products has been extended to importation. The Bill elsewhere prohibits the sale of such goods. This addition would have the effect of preventing the importation for personal use or as promotion give- aways, i.e., aerosol cosmetics.

Clause 11 (2) is deleted so as to prevent the export or import of non-conforming equipment, the manufacture of which was complete before the expiration of the period of grace. It is felt that the Bill should prevent the off-loading, perhaps to Third World countries, of equipment which does not conform with the requirements of this Bill. This equipment would be more safely scrapped in Australia under the stringent provisions of this Bill.

A new clause (Clause 11 (2)) is included which absolutely prohibits the export of Ozone Depleting Substances after the period of grace has expired. This is necessary as manufacturers of Ozone Depleting Substances in Australia, faced with substantially decreased demand as a consequence of recycling may seek to maintain production by selling ODSs offshore.
For the information of the Honourable Senators, the following are the references made in the speech.

2. Molina, Mario J et al. Antarctic Stratospheric Chemistry of Chlorine Nitrate, Hydrogen Chloride, and Ice: Release of Active Chlorine. (1987) Science 238: 1253-57
3. Tolbert, Margaret A et al. Reaction of Chlorine Nitrate with Hydrogen Chlorine and Water at Antarctic Stratospheric Temperatures. (1987) Science 238: 1258-60

PROCTEXT.PARA: That General Business Order of the Day No. 34 (Ozone Depleting Substances Regulation Bill 1988) be discharged from the Notice Paper.

DEBATE.TITLE: CENSUS AND STATISTICS AMENDMENT (VOLUNTARY PROVISION OF SURVEY INFORMATION) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the following Bill be introduced:
A Bill for an Act to amend the Census and Statistics Act 1905 to provide for the voluntary provision of information under the Act.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this amendment is to remove the compulsion to answer questions from all surveys save the census itself. It is not to deny the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) access to information, but to make the answers to survey questions voluntary for everything but the census. We all recognise the need for the Government to have adequate information on which to base decisions and there is no intention of denying this information to the Government. This information should be available under the prescribed subjects defined in the regulations to the Census Act, the answers to which would remain compulsory.

The reason for the proposed amendment is the public reaction to the current household expenditure survey. Initially most members of the public were willing to comply but when they realised the length and breadth of the survey they reacted in shock and amazement. On examination it revealed that the processes of the Parliament were being savaged by the ABS. In addition, client users such as the National Heart Foundation, Better Health Bureau, State, local and Federal governments and their departments, employer and employee groups, were using the ABS because of its powers to compel answers in order to gain information for their own purposes, information that represented a gross invasion of privacy.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics has displayed domineering arrogance and harassment. The ABS has given inaccurate directions to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) concerning the need to table its proposals in parliament. For the ABS to compel answers to surveys, it is required to table new proposals in both Houses of parliament; otherwise answers are voluntary.

There appears to be no power of the Parliament to reject or amend these tabled proposals, so there is no reason for the ABS not to table other than to keep its own purpose dark. Perhaps this is also the reason why the ABS tables such proposals under papers of the Clerks rather than under Treasury ministerial papers. Previous household expenditure surveys were voluntary and tabled prior to the advent of ABS. The authority derives from the Act of 1905 and previous tablings were an ongoing program.
The ABS claims that voluntary answers to its surveys would lead to:
unclear expenditure patterns for disadvantaged groups such as pensioners, one parent families and the unemployed.
inability to identify specific expenditures such as housing, health, transport, and geographical regional data for State governments.
But there are major differences between this household expenditure survey and previous surveys:
(a) Previous household expenditure surveys were voluntary;
(b) This one is compulsory despite no tabling of the proposal;
(c) There is an increase in the scope of the survey from 3,000 questions to 1,000 questions;

(d) Previous surveys applied only to capital cities but this one alleges that 25 per cent of the households to be surveyed covers 12 per cent of the people-Tasmania, Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory;
(e) Each member of the household is supplied with a personal diary which includes an expenditure questionnaire;
(f) It contains an income questionnaire involving the production of income tax return, bank books, collateral, guarantees and and access to people's bank managers.

The Bureau claims that this is simply an ongoing program. The Attorney-General, in expressing his opinion on the need to table the proposal, is apprehensive concerning the matter and has made the qualified statement that `if the 1988-89 survey is of the nature you have described then there is no necessity to table'. The ABS invokes the treaty power of the International Labour Organisation Convention concerning Labour Statistics (No. 160), which was ratified by Australia in 1987. Article 13 of that Treaty states, `Statistics of household expenditure . . . and, where possible, household income . . . shall be compiled covering all types and sizes of private households or families'. Obviously this is the type of survey that could be used in the foundations of introducing a wealth tax-a proposition to which most Australians are totally opposed.

The Statistician maintains that the reason he issues directives to people to answer is to ensure the information so acquired is protected by confidentiality and other provisions of the Act. He says he approaches respondents with sensitivity and delicacy in order to obtain their willing cooperation in the context that respondents have a legal obligation to respond. But we have had public backlash and court cases which the ABS has lost. The Statistician tries to convince respondents the surveys are worth while and reminds them of their responsibilities. He writes to all respondents explaining his powers and responsibilities, and follows up with phone or personal contact.

If all this persuasion fails he issues a directive where respondents know what they are doing or are encouraging others not to comply and where the respondent's replies are considered to be statistically significant. If all this fails then he selects which respondents to prosecute-that is, there are objectors and the Statistician picks and chooses whom he will harass, pursue, and prosecute. This may account for the huge public outcry compared with the few `Directives' and prosecutions. How many hidden cases have there been where the Statistician has hauled off and the respondent has retired to lick his wounds?

The Ombudsman largely sides with the Statistician in considering a person's privacy should be sacrificed because of the obligation owed to the community at large and it would only be in exceptional circumstances that official action could properly be taken pursuant to the statutory powers characterised as oppressive. It is difficult to assess the implications of overtly voluntary collection. However the ABS says there is ample evidence of severe consequences for the quality of statistical data:
(1) the drop in response rates would have an unknown impact;

(2) movements between the results of regular surveys would be different because voluntary respondents have different characteristics from involuntary respondents. There is no way to overcome this by increasing the number of voluntary respondents. This applies particularly to businesses. Voluntary respondents are therefore not typical;
(3) it would have dire consequences for statistical indicator collections. The largest 1,000 businesses comprise 60 per cent of economic activity;

(4) a high non-response would render surveys on agricultural, manufacturing and retail industries non-viable. This would limit data required by Governments and regional bodies; in which case State governments would probably use their powers to bring in compulsory surveys;

(5) voluntary household expenditure survey implications would also be serious. The non-response rate would be high, as shown by the experience of other countries-Australia and Canada . . . compulsory . . . non-response rate 5 per cent, Netherlands and Sweden . . . voluntary . . . non-response rate 20 per cent, West Germany . . . overtly voluntary . . . non-response rate 40 per cent. Again the difference in the characteristics of voluntary and compulsory respondents is stressed by the Bureau;

(6) the Australian Bureau of Statistics says voluntary surveys would cost more, as seeking to persuade people to cooperate would cost more, and it would place an unfair burden on those people and businesses willing to cooperate. None of those reasons carry sufficient weight to counterbalance the invasion of personal privacy and harassment occasioned by the ABS.

The only reason the consumer price index keeps escalating is that the Government keeps spending more than it reaps, and this devalues people's money. People invented government to protect their personal privacy, not to violate it. Certainly governments need certain information in order to make responsible decisions. But when the information is forced out of people in order for the government to engage in social engineering schemes, that is going too far. It is even worse when a government uses these forced confessions to advance its own political purposes, as the Hawke Government has done, and is doing, with this extended survey.

Privacy is a precious possession. That is why we have fought to preserve it since the beginning of democracy. It is the reason we invented government-to do those things for us which we could not do ourselves, such as defence of the nation and maintenance of law, both of which are largely to protect our privacy. Privacy is so important that the people have been willing to give up enormous power to governments to protect it. Governments in their turn are only interested in maintaining the power that has been given to them. In order to maintain that power they have descended to practice of promising handouts in exchange for votes. In order to capture those votes they need information on where best to buy them.

As the process develops they need so much information that the means of acquiring it becomes an invasion of privacy. This is where Australia is today. The process of acquiring information is not new. Generations of governments have initiated all sorts of spy networks in order to maintain power: for knowledge is power in our world. Catherine de Medici organised a network of courtesans, pimps and peepholes in order to maintain her influence. Signal towers and ships dotted nations and oceans. Laird's Lugs can still be seen in many Scottish and Irish castles. The history of government power and control of the people abounds with the means of acquiring information.

In Australia today this power is called the Australian Bureau of Statistics and it is being used cynically, callously and ruthlessly to extract personal information from people by the force of law. Apart from governments using the power of the ABS to acquire information from the people by compulsion, many outside agencies are using the ABS because of its power of compulsion.

I have cited the examples previously in my speech. The officers of the ABS are revelling in their position of power and privilege. Their bureaucratic arrogance is only exceeded by their intemperance. Our people are now willing to go to gaol and challenge the ABS officers in court rather than submit to their inquisition. The fact that the people are winning in court has not deterred the ABS from proceeding because it presumes it has the impenetrable barriers of the Public Service to protect it.

The ABS has attempted to use the power of its bureaucratic position to savage the procedures of the democratic process and the Parliament. It has attempted to bypass parliamentary scrutiny by crafty interpretation of the Acts under which it operates. It is attempting to compel answers from the people, without notifying the Parliament, on the grounds that it has already notified the Parliament about previous surveys that were made by another department, under a different Act and in any case were voluntary. This is the performance of civil servants that are no longer civil and no longer servants.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robert Ray) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS BILL 1988 INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1988

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering the Industrial Relations Bill and Opposition amendment (19) moved by Senator Chaney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an amendment to division 8, exclusive jurisdiction in relation to certain proceedings, dealt with in clauses 164 to 167. The Opposition has proposed the removal of this division, which provides for exclusive federal jurisdictions in certain cases, from the Bill. Clauses 164 to 167, division 8 of the Bill, provide for exclusive Federal jurisdiction in three situations: where there is a contravention of sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act by a union or an officer, employee or member of a union; in relation to industrial action by employees of the Commonwealth where there is conduct in breach of an order made under clause 127 of the Bill; and where there is conduct in breach of a bans clause made under the relevant provision to clause 125 of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Contrary to the impression given by Senator Chaney in his contribution to the debate when he moved the amendment, the exclusive jurisdiction provisions are limited to three distinct situations where a Federal remedy exists in relation to a particular course of conduct.

Clause 164 makes it clear that inconsistent State or Territory legislation cannot operate validly in relation to conduct by a union or an officer, member or employee of a union which contravenes section 45d or section 45e of the Trade Practices Act. In such circumstances there is Federal legislation, the Trade Practices Act 1974, which provides comprehensive remedies in relation to the conduct. There is no requirement for State legislation covering the same conduct. To the extent that any State legislation has additional provisions or remedies to those provided by the Federal legislation, those parts of the State legislation will remain valid. The provision will operate only to invalidate legislation which covers the same conduct that is subject to the Trade Practices Act 1974 provisions. The Government has been advised that, to the extent that any such State or Territory legislation is inconsistent with the provisions of the Trade Practices Act, it is invalid. This provision merely clarifies that position.

It should be remembered that the Queensland Industrial (Commercial Practices) Act 1984, which Senator Chaney suggested would be overridden by this legislation, was originally enacted by the Queensland Government to replace the secondary boycott provisions of the Trade Practices Act when it was intended that those provisions be repealed. Those provisions were not repealed and, to the extent that the Queensland Act covers the same areas as section 45d and section 45e, it is probably invalid and, obviously, unnecessary. The particular advantage that the Federal legislation has over the similar Queensland legislation is that where action is taken under the Trade Practices Act, under the Federal scheme, there are available conciliation processes before the Industrial Relations Commission which may help resolve the dispute. It should also be noted that the Industrial (Commercial Practices) Act now has a wider operation than the Trade Practices Act in those areas. It is unaffected by clause 164 of the Industrial Relations Bill.

Clause 165 relates to industrial action taken by employees of the Commonwealth. It is reasonable for the legislation to provide that where the Commission has made an order under clause 127 of the Bill relating to industrial action by Commonwealth employees the only statutory remedies which should apply to that conduct should be Federal remedies. Clause 166 will operate only to exclude State or Territory legislation where the conduct involved is in breach of a bans clause in an award made by the Industrial Relations Commission. This provision will ensure that statutory compliance measures provided under the Federal legislation are not supplemented by inappropriate State laws which may exacerbate or hinder the resolution of a dispute properly dealt with in the Federal tribunal.

It should also be noted that the exclusive effect of these provisions is limited. Actions under the common law or under other Federal legislation, for example, the Trade Practices Act, are not affected so there would have been no difference in the remedies available in, for example, the Mudginberri, Dollar Sweets or Plumbers cases. Under clause 167, actions under State industrial legislation for a contravention of an award, order or direction of a State industrial authority are not affected. Actions under State or Territory legislation for a breach of the criminal law are not affected.

That is what I want to put in relation to the debate so far. I understand that I have approval from honourable senators opposite to incorporate in Hansard a statement which would more explicitly develop the point and which could, for the purpose of interpretation, be referred to for clarification of some of the objections raised.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

Since the Industrial Relations Bill was introduced, representations have been received from the Confederation of Australian Industry about the meaning of the term ``an action under a law of a State or Territory'' in clauses 164, 165 and 166.
These provisions prevent actions under State or Territory laws from being available in relation to certain industrial misconduct for which remedies are available under federal legislation.

The CAI is concerned that the term ``an action under a law of a State or Territory'' either includes the common law or is so ambiguous that it could be so interpreted. If this view were correct, the provisions would also exclude actions under the common law.

The Government has been advised, however, that the term could not, in the context of clauses 164, 165 and 166, reasonably be interpreted as including the common law. The Office of Parliamentary Counsel has pointed out that it is now established Commonwealth drafting practice to use the term ``a law of a State or Territory'' or similar expressions where appropriate to refer collectively to legislation, whether statutes, regulations, ordinances or any other forms of legislation.

Accordingly, it should be clearly understood that clauses 164, 165 and 166 are not intended to, and do not, affect the common law. This reflects the Government's commitment made last year not to proceed with its proposals to have a limited exclusion of some injunctive remedies in tort which might otherwise apply to certain industrial action.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (20) Page 83, after Division 3 of Part VIII, add the following new Division:
``Division 4-Directions
Directions to stop industrial action

``187a. (1) Where it appears to the Commission that industrial action is occurring, or is threatened, impending or probable, in connection with an industrial dispute, the Commission may give, in connection with the exercise of conciliation powers or arbitration powers in relation to the industrial dispute, such directions as it thinks necessary or desirable to prevent or stop the industrial action or to prevent further industrial action.
``(2) A direction under subsection (1) may be given to:
(a) a party to the industrial dispute;
(b) a member, officer or employee of an organisation that is a party to the industrial dispute; or
(c) any other person engaged in industrial action in connection with the industrial dispute.
``(3) The Commission may give a direction to a person not to engage in conduct that hinders, prevents or discourages:
(a) the observance of an award;
(b) the performance of work in accordance with an award; or
(c) the acceptance of, or offering for, work in accordance with an award.
Injunction to stop industrial action

``187b. (1) Where, on the application of the Minister, or of a person who is a party to the industrial dispute or is bound by the award concerned, the Court is satisfied that a person has engaged, or is proposing to engage, in conduct that constitutes, or would constitute:
(a) a breach of a direction under section 187a;
(b) an attempt to breach such a direction;
(c) aiding, counselling or procuring a person to breach such a direction;
(d) inducing or attempting to induce a person to breach such a direction;
(e) being in any way, directly or indirectly, knowingly concerned in, or party to, a breach of such a direction; or
(f) conspiring with others to breach such a direction;
the Court may grant an injunction in such terms as the Court considers to be appropriate.
``(2) Where in the opinion of the Court it is desirable to do so, the Court may grant an interim injunction pending determination of an application under subsection (1).
``(3) The Court may revoke or vary an injunction granted under subsection (1) or (2).
Damages for conduct in breach of direction

``187c. (1) A person who suffers loss or damage by the conduct of another person that was done in breach of a direction under section 187a may recover the amount of the loss or damage by action against that other person in the Court.
``(2) An action under subsection (1) may be commenced at any time within 3 years after the date on which the cause of action accrued.
Other actions not affected
``187d. Nothing in this Division limits a right to bring an action otherwise than under this Act.
Conduct by officers, employees, members or agents

``187e. For the purposes of sections 187b and 187c, action taken in breach of a direction under section 187a by an officer, employee, member or agent of an organisation shall be deemed to have been taken by the organisation, unless the organisation establishes that it took all reasonable steps to prevent the person from taking the action.''.

This amendment relates to Part VIII of the Industrial Relations Bill; that is, the compliance provisions. We seek to insert a new division, division 4, in Part VIII of the legislation. On page 83, at the end of clause 187, we seek to insert a new provision relating to compliance. The amendments that we are seeking to insert will introduce into the Bill a new division which incorporates the compliance provisions which Senator Chaney moved in his Conciliation and Arbitration (Compliance Provisions) Amendment Bill 1987 towards the end of last year. We believe that this detailed amendment with regard to compliance is necessary because the Industrial Relations Bill 1988 does nothing to remedy the impotence of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to enforce its decisions. The former Minister, the present Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis, in his second reading speech on the first version of this Bill, the Industrial Relations Bill 1987, said on 14 May last year that the compliance provisions were an essential element of the industrial relations system. He went on to point out that the current bans clause procedure was disreputable and `substantially moribund'. The fact that not a single union has ever been prosecuted under the present bans clause procedure only goes to show how totally ineffective the current legislation is. Yet this Bill retains those existing moribund, useless provisions, so it does even less than the original Bill of 1987 to give the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission some teeth.

In the 1987 Bill the range of penalties to be made available were to be tougher than those under the existing Act. They were to include fines, alterations to an organisation's eligibility rules to exclude specified groups from membership, and the imposition of conditions as to future industrial conduct. A serious continuing breach of a direction by an organisation or its members would lead to deregulation. However, when the Government shelved this Bill for its own electoral convenience last year, when it called the unnecessary early election, it also dropped these tougher compliance provisions. The Government is now blaming the employers for this but it is quite obvious that it was pressure from the Australian Council of Trade Union (ACTU) which forced the Government to back down on this question. The President of the ACTU, Mr Simon Crean, is quoted as saying:
They can still introduce a Bill but it will have to be one which does not do anything on compliance.

If that does not spell out the intentions of the ACTU, I do not know what does. Moreover, many employer groups, including the Confederation of Australian Industry, expressed opposition to the original Bill-that is, the 1987 Bill-on the grounds, among others, that it did not do enough to strengthen the enforcement provisions. The end result is that we are now faced with a piece of legislation which nominally gives the Commission a great number of powers but does not back up those powers with effective enforcement provisions.

The policy of the Liberal-National Party coalition is that employers and employees should be free to make their own agreements on employment conditions and wages. But while we have a system of conciliation and arbitration in place, there must be some provisions to ensure that parties subject to the Commission's rulings comply with its directions. In a Press statement on 26 August Mr Bryan Noakes, representing the Confederation of Australian Industry, called on the Government to support the amendment which I am now moving. He said:
The Government must act to equip the new Industrial Relations Commission with effective processes for disciplining trade unions which defy Commission decisions and rulings.
The Opposition proposes that the Bill be amended to give the new Commission the power to direct that industrial action cease, a direction enforceable by injunction.

The Government should accept this amendment. It must act to ensure that an institution as important as the new Commission has adequate powers to perform its functions. If it does not accept the amendment it will be an abdication of its responsibility to act in the national interest.

It is because this legislation leaves the unions, or employers for that matter, free to flout the Commission's decision with impunity that the Opposition considers it vital that the amendments which I have introduced for effective compliance provisions be adopted by the Committee.

A major thrust of the Liberal-National Party coalition industrial relations policy is to restore accountability to the industrial relations system. Unfortunately, all of the cooperative behaviour in the world can still be destroyed by the unreasonable behaviour of a few. Last year we saw examples in the building industry, with the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union of Australia, the actions of a minority of metalworkers in Victoria, and the Federated Storemen and Packers Union of Australia in New South Wales. A feature of many of these destructive disputes was the fact that renegade elements of the trade union movement involved were frequently in conflict with the trade union movement generally and with the government of the day as well as with the employers. What has been lacking up to now has been an effective mechanism within the industrial arbitration system which enables those renegade elements to be made subject to the system of which they are so ready to take advantage. A system of conciliation and arbitration which binds only one side of the employer-employee relationship is clearly defective. The existence of this defect has been conceded by the present Government and we have introduced these amendments because the Government has made it clear that it has no intention of coming to grips with the problem which it admits exists.

These amendments are designed to introduce effective compliance provisions into the conciliation and arbitration system. One of the most serious defects of the existing system is that there is no effective way of ensuring that the unions comply with the decisions and orders of the Arbitration Commission. For example, when the Commission arbitrates for a pay increase, that is written into the award and the employer is legally obliged to pay. Moreover, there is an effective system of sanctions to ensure that he does so. Employees who are members of a union may sue their employer for any payment due to them under an award. Employers can be and often are prosecuted by the Arbitration Inspectorate under section 119 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act for monetary breaches of awards. Yet when unions disagree with the outcome of arbitration they are, in practice, free to indulge in industrial action to impose their claims with virtual impunity. The Australian Chamber of Commerce recently noted:

. . . There is a widespread view amongst commerce and industry that the trade union movement practices only selective and optional compliance-and then only with regard to those decisions/directions that suit their interests.

The Chamber went on to state its strong belief that any system of arbitration and/or adjudication must contain an effective system of sanctions for those who fail to comply with its orders, processes and requirements. Our amendments squarely address this issue. Under the existing system Commission directions to return to work are regularly flouted by unions. There are no effective means of dealing with this.

A good example of the way in which unions treat Commission decisions is the 1985 Dollar Sweets dispute. In that case the union-the Federated Confectioners Association of Australia-engaged in a campaign of industrial action in pursuit of a 36-hour week. This claim was totally outside the Arbitration Commission's wages principles. The employers sought to resolve the dispute through the conciliation and arbitration system. Commissioner Bain held a hearing and conducted an inspection of the employer's premises. He then issued a recommendation that the picket lines imposed by the union be lifted. To quote the Supreme Court judge in the later common law action on this issue:

It is apparent that the union and the defendants paid no heed to this recommendation. Instead they, as it was put, thumbed their noses at the Commission and continued with their picketing and illegal practices, apparently aware that the Commission is powerless to apply any sanction.

It has to be recognised that the lack of effective compliance provisions not only prejudices the position of the immediate victims of industrial action; it also introduces a fundamental bias into the system. It is hard to deny that the Commission's inability to enforce its decisions and orders means that the Commission often has to weigh up what is right with what is acceptable to the unions. The question of acceptability to the employers, who will be obliged to follow the decision whatever the outcome, is barely of consequence. In fact, an arbitration system that is voluntary on one side but compulsory on the other will eventually lose its legitimacy.

As the previous Minister for Industrial Relations pointed out last year to the ACTU Congress, the lack of effective compliance provisions in the system has led to an increasing resort by employers to remedies outside the system through either common law or the Trade Practices Act. The Government's ill-fated Industrial Relations Bill of 1987 recognised the inadequacy of the existing system. Earlier I referred to Mr Willis's remarks when he introduced that Bill but, in more detail, on 14 May he said:

An essential element of any industrial relations system which provides benefits and protections to registered organisations and their members is that there should be an effective means of ensuring adherence to the principles on which the system is founded and compliance with the decisions of its institutions.
The Minister announced:
. . . the present bans clause provisions, which have long since fallen into disrepute and are now substantially moribund, will be replaced by a new direction and injunction process.

In our view there were substantial defects in that proposed new process. Nevertheless, even with these defects, the new directions and injunctions procedures represented some improvement on the bans clause system. What was totally unacceptable, however, was the attempt to present these new provisions as a trade-off for major restrictions on employer access to common law and Trade Practices Act remedies. The result of these changes would have been to give unions even greater scope to engage in industrial action with impunity. Eventually, the Government backed down and on 6 June last year the then Minister for Industrial Relations announced that there would be no changes to employer access, common law actions or Trade Practices Act remedies. At the same time he announced that monetary penalties for non-adherence to compliance provisions in the Industrial Relations Bill would be the same as those currently applying in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. However, he announced that the range of non-monetary penalties in the Industrial Relations Bill would be retained. Thus the dropping of the proposed $5,000 a day fine was effectively presented as a trade-off for dropping the common law and Trade Practices Act changes. But three weeks later Mr Willis reiterated the Government's position:

. . . the original proposals to prevent the use of Common Law and to require conciliation before trade practices action could be taken in respect of 45d and e . . . will not be gone ahead with, nor will the increase in monetary penalties.

During the election campaign last year, Mr Willis was still telling the community that the Government was committed to introducing new compliance provisions based on a direction and injunctions process. But then of course Mr Crean came on the scene. On 17 August, after the election was out of the way, Mr Simon Crean was quoted in the Australian Financial Review as saying:

Our position is that if the Bill does not touch Common Law or the secondary boycott provisions of the Trade Practices Act then it must not increase or strengthen sanctions. They can still introduce a Bill but it will have to be one which does not do anything on compliance.
So the ACTU had given its orders to the Government and Mr Willis again changed his position. On 10 September he stated:

. . . in the absence of a willingness by the employers to make concessions in respect to penalties which can apply to unions outside the arbitration system, we don't believe it is appropriate to be amending the provisions within the arbitration system now.

The Government completely backed down on doing anything effective in this legislation with regard to compliance by trade unions. We are now left with legislation which is totally inadequate in its capacity to deal with trade unions that will not comply with the decisions of the conciliation and arbitration system. Therefore, it is essential that the amendments which I move on behalf of the Opposition be supported by a majority of this chamber and that they become part of this legislation if it is effectively to retain an adequate balance in our industrial relations system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an Opposition amendment to insert two new divisions in part VI of the Industrial Relations Bill. It is an Opposition amendment which is related to one of the most contentious areas of industrial relations; that is, when action that is engaged in is undesirable, what powers does the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission have to curtail such action? Thus it generates a fair bit of heat. We have seen an example of that today. As I think properly befits an area of great controversy, I will pick my way through it quietly and gently in a thorough and comprehensive way so that the logical remedies that the Government proposes are better understood.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the first alternative system proposed by the Opposition, the grounds on which an injunction may be issued are vague. The court need only be satisfied that a person has engaged, or is proposing to engage, in conduct that constitutes or would constitute a breach of a direction; an attempt to breach such a direction; aiding, counselling or procuring a person to breach such a direction; inducing or attempting to induce a person to breach such a direction; being in any way directly or indirectly knowingly concerned in or party to a breach of such a direction; or conspiring with others to breach such a direction. The availability of direct and immediate access to such a process could well be used to thwart and frustrate efforts by the Commission to resolve an industrial dispute. Paradoxically, the proposed scheme might delay the availability of remedies for industrial action. If these amendments were to be adopted there is a clear risk that enforcement proceedings in the court could undermine attempts by the Commission to resolve the underlying industrial issues. Given the severity of the remedies and the lack of any sensible process for a cooling off period, it would be understandable if the Commission and employers treated directions as a process of last resort and were reluctant to use them for fear of inflaming a dispute.

It is, I would suggest, self-defeating to introduce processes which will completely undermine the commitment of the trade union movement to the conciliation and arbitration process. For example, why would trade unions continue to give voluntarily no extra claims commitments when there was an unrestricted access on the other side to still use the big stick? As well, these proposals are quite contrary to the objective of encouraging commitment to sensible grievance procedures.

The alternative amendment-that is, amendment (21) proposed by the Opposition in anticipation of the first proposal meeting flat rejection-is a direct lift from the directions and injunctions process included by the Government in the 1987 Bill, but with three very important differences. Firstly, under the proposal the court is able to grant an injunction to enforce directions given by the Commission without the requirement of the 1987 Bill that it be `satisfied that the respondent has breached the direction'. Secondly, there is no prohibition on action taken under other laws-that is, common law-if action is taken under the proposed provisions. Thirdly, the ordinary contempt powers of the Federal Court are not restricted in respect of an injunction granted under the provisions-that is, the maximum penalties laid down in the provisions are not necessarily the limit of the court's power. They are three flaws or differences from the 1987 proposals.

In the 1987 Industrial Relations Bill we included a directions process quite fundamentally different from the process proposed by the Opposition. The main objective of the 1987 Bill was to establish effective machinery for the resolution of disputes by conciliation and arbitration. That is also the case in this Bill. At the same time, the Government saw the need to have a sensible, balanced and comprehensive set of compliance measures within the Federal industrial relations system. It is obviously preferable for the Federal system to provide its own remedies for conduct inconsistent with the aims of that system. Accordingly, the Government proposed a new directions and injunctions process with substantially higher monetary penalties for non-compliance as well as a range of non-monetary penalties. More efficient processes were also proposed for resolving secondary boycotts before sanctions were needed.

The Government recognised, however, that it was simply neither practical nor reasonable to have a comprehensive set of compliance measures for the Federal system, all of which were designed to promote the resolution of disputes, while leaving open access to common law and other external legal actions which had nothing to do with dispute settlement. For this reason, the Government excluded access to some common law injunctions where an injunction was available under the Federal system. Damages were not affected. Overlapping civil remedies under State legislation were also excluded.

The directions process envisaged in either of the two alternative proposals contained in the Opposition amendments does not achieve any of the objectives that were the basis of the Government's directions process. Either Opposition amendments (20) or (21) would introduce a compliance system heavily and inequitably weighted against the trade union movement and in favour of employers. The Opposition has simply forgotten the lessons it had to learn, not at its own cost but at great cost to the community in the 1960s when the coalition Government introduced processes for dispute resolution before access to the enforcement bans clauses was permitted. It expressly acknowledged that there were two main deficiencies in the existing processes which gave virtually immediate access to penalties. Those deficiencies were the immediacy of availability of enforcement measures and the fact that the process did not allow the court to take hold of the dispute between the parties and endeavour to assist them to resolve it.

These fundamental weaknesses are reinstated by the Opposition proposal that is now before the chamber. Far from a prescription for improved industrial behaviour, these proposals represent a return to the discredited confrontationist approach to industrial relations of the Fraser Government. They will make disputes worse and, as has been said by one judge in relation to common law action in industrial disputes, leave a `legacy of bitterness between the parties'. It is for those reasons that the Government does not accept the amendment that has been moved.

I might add that Senator Chapman, in supporting the amendment, made a couple of claims that I think ought to be rebutted. I am not sure of the order in which Senator Chapman made his claims but, according to the way I wrote them down, his first claim was that this Bill was framed in accordance with Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) direction. One of the fictions that the Opposition wants to try to embed in the consciousness of Australian electors is that this Government acts because the ACTU says so. Anyone who reads in the daily papers the arguments about the differences between the Government and the ACTU will clearly see the fallacious nature of that allegation. But the Opposition believes that simply by repeating that allegation at every opportunity it somehow will gain importance and somehow the electorate will believe it. The suggestion is, of course, fatuous.

The Government reached its decision to modify the 1987 Bill's compliance measures in the face of the objections of the employer bodies. It consulted employers and the ACTU about possible modifications. The ACTU was prepared to accept the balanced package that was originally proposed. The employers wanted an amendment similar to what is being put now for unrestricted access to sanctions. The Government was not prepared to introduce legislation containing comprehensive Federal compliance measures and greatly increased penalties without there being proper processes which emphasised dispute resolution in the first instance or ensuring that those processes could not be upset by damaging intrusion of external legal remedies. It is a matter of public record that the ACTU would not accept a system which established a smorgasbord of Federal sanctions to supplement a range of common law and other non-Federal sanctions. That is understandable.

It is absurd, however, to suggest that the Government's decision not to proceed with its original proposals or to modify them as the employers wanted was attributable in any way to supposed directions given to it by the ACTU. That fiction is not applicable.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a truth.

—No, it is just a fiction. As I have said, it is a fiction that, by continual repetition, the Opposition wants people to believe. It remains, however, a fiction and no amount of repetition will change that fact.

SPEECH.PARA: In the few minutes that remain, I should reply to the remarks made by Senator Chapman that touch on what he alleges to be the inadequacy of the compliance provisions in this Bill. This Bill is not, as the honourable senator has suggested, virtually devoid of compliance measures. It is true that the Bill retains the bans clause processes established by the coalition Government in 1970 and revised by the coalition Government in 1972, but it also contains many other provisions for dealing with non-compliance with the requirements of the Federal system.

Before I go to those, it is worth recalling why the bans clause processes have been retained in the first place. The 1987 Bill provided for a more effective compliance process involving directions from the Commission and injunctions from the proposed labour court to enforce such directions in cases of intransigence. These remedies, together with other remedies under the Bill and Federal law, were intended to comprise a comprehensive code of compliance measures in the Federal system. Various checks and balances were incorporated to emphasise the resolution of disputes and to prevent the relationship between dispute settlement and effective compliance from being disrupted by resort to some external legal remedies.

Employer bodies, supported by the Opposition, objected in an extremely short-sighted and jaundiced way to the new system. They wanted all the sanctions but not the checks and balances that ought to go along with them. The Government agreed to defer the legislation for further consultation with employers and unions over the system. Despite very full discussions over some time, no agreement was reached. The Government decided, therefore, to retain the bans clause processes instead of introducing the directions and injunctions process and to proceed with the other principal non-compliance measures.

The 1988 Bill, which is now before the Committee, contains a range of measures relating to industrial action, including a bans clause that can be inserted in an award, with monetary penalties for breach ranging from $500 to $1,000 a day-clauses 181 to 186. Stand downs can be authorised under clause 126. Awards can be set aside or varied: for example, the recent removal of the 4 per cent second tier pay rise for storemen and packers in dispute at the Nippondenso factory in Victoria-clause 113. Awards can be suspended or cancelled-clause 187. The hearing of claims before the Commission can be deferred where industrial action is occurring, as set out in clause 111 (1) (g). Deregistration can be sought with a range of remedies short of deregistration also available: examples are orders about the use of funds or property, changes to coverage of rights, and restriction of rights under the Act as set out in clause 293.

Equivalent measures exist in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, but the Bill's provisions are clearer and drafted so as to operate more effectively. A key point, however, is that the best compliance is voluntary. The dispute figures show the contrast between the approach backed up by these Opposition amendments and the Government's approach. One has only to look at who does industrial relations better in government to see that the overwhelming verdict of popular opinion and of the statistics is that it is this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one would argue with the Minister's concluding remark that the best system of industrial relations compliance is that which is voluntary, and that is exactly what the coalition policy seeks to develop much more fully. But we live in the real world and we will not always get voluntary compliance. It is for that reason that the Opposition has moved these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister, in responding to this amendment, claimed that the issuing of a direction could undermine the potential for conciliation, but the opportunity for conciliation is available well before any direction would be issued. Indeed, it would be expected that all avenues of conciliation would be exhausted before a direction was sought, as our amendments provide. An injunction would be used only as a last resort when conciliation and arbitration had broken down. I refer the Minister to the comments of Mr Bert Evans, Chief Executive of the Metal Trades Industry Association, a gentleman whom the Government from time to time is fond of quoting in support of its arguments. Mr Evans said:
In introducing in the Senate a private member's Bill on industrial relations-
of course, that is the private member's Bill introduced by Senator Chaney last year, to which this amendment give effect-

the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, has done the community a service by focusing attention on the need for long-overdue compliance provisions in the compulsory conciliation and arbitration system.

The Opposition's Bill has obviously been carefully drafted with the practicalities of day-to-day industrial relations in mind. It contains no provisions which any fair minded person prepared to abide by the rules of compulsory conciliation and arbitration could object to. On the other hand, it clearly would remove the imbalances which presently exist and which favour recalcitrant trade unions at the expense of employers who are trying to work within the system.

That description of Senator Chaney's compliance Bill which he introduced in November last year applies exactly and equally to the amendment which I have moved today. This amendment would have the same effect on the Government's legislation as Senator Chaney's own Bill would have had on the situation last year.

Senator Cook also referred to our amendments as being inferior to the provisions in the Government's 1987 Industrial Relations Bill. Our amendment differs from that proposed in the Government's Bill of last year in the following ways: first, it would not be necessary to obtain a certificate from a Full Bench before proceeding to obtain an injunction. In our view, and contrary to what the Minister said, such a step is totally unnecessary and would be likely to lead to substantial delays. Time is often of the essence in industrial disputes and in achieving an effective solution of those disputes. Under the procedures which were set out in last year's Bill employers could be financially ruined while waiting for the Full Bench to be convened.

A second major difference from that legislation was that breaches of injunctions would be treated as contempt of court. There would be no arbitrary restrictions on the power of the court to decide the appropriate punishment. In the Industrial Relations Bill there was a limit imposed of $5,000 a day for breaches of injunctions. There is normally no upper limit for penalties for contempt of an injunction of the Federal Court or of a State Supreme Court. The penalty is related to the circumstances and the seriousness of the contempt. For example, in the plumbers' dispute last year a penalty of $10,000 per day per site was imposed. It is critical that penalties be set at a level sufficient to deter a large union. By way of comparison, it can be noted that breaches of the Trade Practices Act can result in fines of up to $250,000 in the case of a body corporate for each separate breach.

A third major difference is that under our amendment a person who suffers loss or damage as the result of industrial action in breach of a direction can sue the responsible union in the Federal Court. This would permit aggrieved third parties as well as employers to sue unions for damage resulting from industrial action forbidden by the Commission. The extraordinary aspect of industrial relations in our society is that it is the only area where an organisation can wilfully set out to wreak damage and expect to escape responsibility. Those who operate within a system which provides extensive rights to go to arbitration in the event of a dispute can least of all claim that such action can be justified. It is a provision of our amendment that the new directions and injunctions procedure in no way override or limit any other legal rights a person may have in face of industrial action. Employers would retain their full common law rights. Nor would actions under section 45d or section 45e of the Trade Practices Act be affected. I reinforce the need for this Opposition amendment to be passed by the Committee and urge its support.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chapman's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (21) Page 83, after Division 3 of Part VIII, add the following new Division:
``Division 4-Directions
Direction to stop industrial action or other conduct

``187f. (1) Where it appears to the Commission that industrial action is occurring, or is threatened, impending or probable, in connection with an industrial dispute, the Commission may give, in connection with the exercise of conciliation powers or arbitration powers in relation to the industrial dispute, such directions as it thinks necessary or desirable to stop or prevent the industrial action or to prevent further industrial action.
``(2) A direction under subsection (1) may be given to:
(a) party to the industrial dispute;
(b) a member, officer or employee of an organisation that is party to the industrial dispute; or
(c) any other person engaged in industrial action in connection with the industrial dispute.
``(3) The Commission may give a direction to a person not to engage in conduct that hinders, prevents or discourages:
(a) the observance of an award;
(b) the performance of work in accordance with an award; or
(c) the acceptance of, or offering for, work in accordance with an award.
Directions and orders in relation to industrial action involving public sector employment
``18g. (1) Where it appears to the Commission that industrial action by persons engaged in public sector employment is occurring, or is threatened, impending or probable, the Commission may:
(a) give such directions as it thinks necessary or desirable to stop or prevent the industrial action or to prevent further industrial action; or
(b) make such orders as it thinks necessary or desirable by reason that the industrial action is occurring or is threatened, impending or probable.
``(2) An order made under paragraph (1) (b) is enforceable under this Act as if it were an award.
``(3) The powers conferred on the Commission by this section are in addition to, and not in derogation of, the powers conferred on the Commission by the rest of this Act.
Provision relating to directions under section 187f or 187g
``187h. A direction under section 187f or paragraph 187g (1) (a):
(a) shall specify the period for which it is intended to continue in force;
(b) shall come into force when it is made, unless it is expressed to come into force at a later time;
(c) shall be deemed to be an award for the purposes of section 143; and
(d) may be varied or revoked at any time.
Breach of direction under section 187f or 187g
``187j. (1) Where the Commission has given a direction under section 187f or under paragraph 187g (1) (a), the Commission:
(a) shall, if it is satisfied:
(i) that industrial action or other conduct in breach of the direction is not about to stop; and
(ii) that there is no other appropriate step which the Commission could take to prevent or stop such industrial action or conduct promptly;
give a certificate in writing to that effect and may, if it thinks fit, vary the direction; or
(b) may, if it is not satisfied as mentioned in paragraph (a) and if it thinks fit, vary or revoke the direction.

``(2) Where industrial action or conduct in breach of a direction under section 187f or under paragraph 187g (1) (a) has stopped without a certificate under subsection (1) having been given, the Commission may, if it is satisfied that the giving of a certificate for the purposes of section 187k is justified having regard to:
(a) the nature of the industrial action or conduct;
(b) the circumstances in which the industrial action or conduct ceased; and
(c) the terms of any settlement of the matter that gave rise to the industrial action or conduct;
give a certificate in writing to that effect.

``(3) The powers of the Commission under subsection (1) or (2) in relation to a direction given under subsection 187f (1) are exercisable on application by a party to the industrial dispute concerned.
``(4) The powers of the Commission under subsection (1) or (2) in relation to a direction given under subsection 187f (3) are exercisable on application by a person bound by the award concerned.

``(5) The powers of the Commission under subsection (1) or (2) in relation to a direction given under paragraph 187g (1) (a) are exercisable on application by the employer of persons engaged in the industrial action concerned or likely to be engaged in the threatened, impending or probable industrial action concerned.
``(6) The powers of the Commission under subsection (1) or (2) to give a certificate or to vary or revoke a direction shall be exercised by a Full Bench and not otherwise.
Compliance with directions

``187k. (1) Where a certificate has been given under section 187j in relation to a direction under section 187f or paragraph 187g (1) (a), a prescribed person may apply to the Court to enforce the direction.

``(2) Where, on application under subsection (1), the Court may, if it considers it appropriate, grant such injunction as the Court thinks appropriate to prevent or stop the industrial action or conduct concerned.

``(3) Where the Court grants an injunction under subsection (2), the Court may, by order, declare the engaging in conduct in breach of the injunction shall be deemed to constitute a separate breach of the injunction on each day on which the conduct continues.
``(4) In dealing with a breach of an injunction granted under subsection (2), the Court may make any one or more of the following orders:
(a) an order imposing on the party in breach a penalty as provided by subsection (5) or (6);

(b) an order determining alterations of the eligibility rules of an organisation in breach to exclude from eligibility for membership of the organisation persons belonging to a specified class or group;

(c) an order declaring that persons belong to a specified class or group, being persons who are eligible for membership of the organisation by virtue of an agreement of the kind referred to in section 202, are excluded from eligibility for membership of the organisation in spite of anything in the agreement.
``(5) The maximum penalty that may be imposed under subsection (4) in respect of a breach of an injunction, where the breach is a separate breach by virtue of an order under subsection (3), is:
(a) in the case of a natural person-$1,000; or
(b) in the case of a body corporate-$5,000.
``(6) The maximum penalty that may be imposed under subsection (4) in respect of a breach of an injunction, other than a breach referred to in subsection (5), is:
(a) in the case of a natural person-$1,000; or
(b) in the case of a body corporate-$5,000.
``(7) In dealing with a breach of an injunction granted under subsection (2), the Court may, instead of making an order under subsection (4), do either or both of the following:
(a) accept an undertaking entered into by the party in breach relating to the party's future industrial conduct;
(b) impose on the party in breach such conditions as the Court thinks fit relating to the party's future industrial conduct.

``(8) The Court may, on application by a party to a proceeding in which the Court took action under subsection (7), deal with a breach of an undertaking accepted, or a condition imposed, under that subsection as if it were a breach of an injunction granted under subsection (2).
``(9) An alteration of rules determined by order under paragraph (4) (b) takes effect on the date of the order or on such other day as is specified in the order.
``(10) In dealing with a breach of an interlocutory injunction granted in relation to the enforcement of a direction under this section, the Court may:
(a) make an order of the kind referred to in paragraph (4) (a); or
(b) do either or both of the things referred to in paragraphs (7) (a) and (b).
``(11) In this section:
`prescribed person' means:

(a) in relation to a direction under subsection 187f (1)-a party to the industrial dispute who has been affected, or an organisation that is a party to the industrial dispute whose members have been affected, by a breach of the direction;
(b) in relation to a direction under subsection 187f (3)-a person bound by the award concerned who has been affected by a breach of the direction; or

(c) in relation to a direction under paragraph 187g (1) (a)-an employer of persons engaged in the industrial action concerned or likely to be engaged in the threatened, impending or probable industrial action concerned, being an employer who has been affected by a breach of the directions;
`respondent', in relation to a direction under section 187f or paragraph 187g (1) (a), means the person to whom the direction was addressed.''.

This amendment has been moved consequent upon amendment (20) not being supported. Again, this amendment deals with compliance. It inserts a new division containing the compliance provisions which were contained in the Government's own Industrial Relations Bill 1987. It is presented as an alternative to the amendment which I moved previously and which was lost. The provisions which amendment (21) will introduce to the Bill are the very provisions which the Government supported in its own legislation last year. Undoubtedly, these provisions are not as satisfactory as those which I moved a few moments ago, but they are certainly far superior to the provisions in the Government's Industrial Relations Bill 1988.

One of the arguments put forward by the Government against sanctions concerns double jeopardy-that there would be a danger of unions being subject to double jeopardy if the compliance provisions which we seek to have incorporated in this legislation were accepted. The Government says that it would be unfair to expose unions to sanctions within the arbitration system if they still faced sanctions outside it. That is a fairly recent argument that the Government has produced. We might ask why it was not produced earlier, particularly during last year's election campaign.
