Was it because at that time the Government did not want to admit to voters that it had no intention of doing anything about compliance, that its original compliance provisions in the 1987 Bill were simply a blind to con voters into believing that something would be done about introducing effective compliance provisions applying to trade unions?

We should look at whether the argument about double jeopardy has any real credibility. It should be understood that this so-called double jeopardy would not be some new product of a system of directions and injunctions: it already exists. There is an overlap now between sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act, the common law and the bans clause provisions of the old Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Indeed, there is an overlap between some of the industrial torts. The fact is that it is not at all uncommon for there to be more than one legal remedy available to deal with a certain situation. The courts are quite experienced in dealing with this and no new problems would be created by the establishment of a new directions and injunctions procedure alongside common law and the Trade Practices Act.

Section 11 of the Crimes Act permits a person who has committed an offence that breaches more than one law to be prosecuted and convicted under either law, but not to be punished twice in respect of the same offence. For civil remedies there is no point in getting an injunction under more than one Act.

The main differences between our proposals on compliance and those contained in last year's Industrial Relations Bill are, firstly, that it would not be necessary to obtain a certificate from a full bench before proceeding to obtain an injunction; secondly, that breaches of injunctions would be treated as contempt of court and there would be no arbitrary restrictions on the power of the court to decide the appropriate penalty; and, thirdly, that a person who suffered loss or damage as a result of industrial action and a breach of direction would be able to sue the responsible organisation in the Federal Court.

In view of the unwillingness of the Government and the Australian Democrats to support our amendment (20), which sought to place what we believe would be the more effective compliance provisions into this legislation, I believe that it is even more essential that at least these less effective compliance provisions be incorporated in the legislation so that there is some opportunity for an even-handed approach to be adopted in industrial relations and for the new Industrial Relations Commission to have the power to enforce effectively the provisions and decisions which it makes. Therefore, I urge the Committee to support amendment (21), which seeks to insert a new division 4 in part VIII of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I addressed this amendment in the body of my remarks when I was dealing with the earlier amendment (20) moved by Senator Chapman. In view of the remarks he has made there are a few points I need to re-emphasise. This amendment arises as an Opposition effort-to put it honestly and squarely-to embarrass the Government by lifting a clause from our 1987 Bill and attempting to insert it in the 1988 Bill. Indeed, that would be embarrassing if it were exactly the same in every respect.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said before, there are three major differences between the 1987 Bill and what is now proposed. The first is that the court is able to grant an injunction to enforce directions given by the Commission without the requirement of the 1987 Bill that it be satisfied that the respondent has breached the direction. That is a very important difference between what is being proposed now and what we proposed then.

The second difference is that there is no prohibition on action taken under other laws-that is, common law-if action is taken under the proposed provisions. The third difference is that the ordinary contempt powers of the Federal Court of Australia are not restricted in respect of an injunction granted under the provisions. That means that maximum penalties laid down in the provisions are not necessarily the limit of the court's power. I think that the first effort to embarrass us by copying us has not succeeded. If it were a comprehensive and complete duplication of what we are doing, it might have succeeded. It does not because of these alterations and differences.

My second point relates to double jeopardy. Mr Willis made the point strongly that double jeopardy was part of our concept of improvement in the 1987 Bill. It is not a new idea. The idea of double jeopardy has been around for as long as section 51(xxxv) of the Australian Constitution has empowered the Commonwealth to make laws to prevent and settle industrial disputes. Under that head of power we have introduced arbitration and conciliation legislation. Ever since there has been arbitration and conciliation legislation in Australia there has been a concept that there are penalties built into that legislation, that area should be fenced off so that people behaving within that structure of a Conciliation and Arbitration Act should be dealt with within that structure and not have other penalties visited upon them from outside that disrupt or interfere with the ability of the Commission to, as the Constitution spells out, prevent and settle industrial disputes. So I rebut the double jeopardy argument that has been raised here with those remarks.

The course we are proposing to take-it is consistent with what we have proposed to do all the way through-is that when there is a dispute in which the compliance provisions of an Act may be or should be invoked, it is far better for the management of industrial relations to involve the Commission at each particular stage to bring about a resolution of the dispute. If that fails, the compliance provisions work. Under this amendment they fast track the big stick and thus, from practical experience, exacerbate and extend the disputes.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chapman's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 3, subclause 4 (1) definition of ``collegiate electoral system'' lines 13 to 27, leave out the definition
(2) Page 7, subclause 4 (1), definition of ``one-tier collegiate electoral system'' lines 43 to 44, leave out the definition.
(5) Pages 88 and 89 paragraph 197 (1) (a), line 39 (page 88) to line 2 (page 89) leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
``(a) shall provide for the election of the holder of each office in the organisation by a direct voting system;''.
(6) Page 89, clause 198 (1), lines 36 to 39, leave out the subclause, insert the following subclause:
``(1) Where a ballot is required for an election for an office, the rules shall also provide that it shall be a secret postal ballot.''.

The Committee will be aware that the Conciliation and Arbitration Act of 1904, which is in place, and the Industrial Relations Bill, which is before the chamber at the moment, both provide for some unions to elect their office bearers by the indirect or, otherwise known as, collegiate system of elections.

It is the view of the Australian Democrats, in fact it is the view even of some of those unions that employ the collegiate system of elections, that the collegiate or indirect system has always been a poor substitute for direct democracy. Honourable senators will be aware of the fact that it involves a process whereby the members of the union elect a group of people, generally referred to as `the college'; or it may go by another name in the case of some unions and be referred to as `the council'. It is a group of people who have been elected and from whom and by whom further representation will result. In other words, it is a two-tier or two-stage system of deciding who holds power.

Historically, that system emerged when and where direct democracy was impracticable because of, say, lack of knowledge, remote location, inconvenience or lack of communication, et cetera; therefore, where representative democracy made more sense. Most people are probably most familiar with the collegiate system in relation to presidential elections in the United States. As I say, historically it came about when it was impracticable to have in place a system of direct democracy. Of course, we in the Australian Democrats argue that this is not acceptable in a day and age in which information and opinion can be transmitted instantly.

I have over and over again cited examples of this where, for instance, any of us can go into a special place called a totalisator agency board centre and offer our opinion about the most irrelevant things and have that opinion processed virtually instantly with the aid of modern technology. This is a day and age when in fact any of us can procure or purchase commodities by means of using a Bankcard and the authority to use that card and the credibility of its use are established by telephone and telecommunication methods.

In other words, we live in the day and age of instant communication in which the impracticability of elections no longer applies and in which therefore, a system of indirect democracy is unjustified in cases such as the election of union leadership. Therefore, in this context, it is no longer an acceptable alternative to direct democracy. Some unions retain this system because it allows them the opportunity to manipulate outcomes and to manipulate numbers on national conferences or national executives, et cetera. I am not saying that this is not in itself significant; I am simply saying that that is the reason why the collegiate or indirect system of elections is maintained or retained by some unions.

Australia has a long history of supporting fair elections. We were the first country to introduce secret ballots. We were the second country to introduce votes for women. These amendments, if supported, would essentially reintroduce the Clyde Cameron amendments of 1973 when he proposed amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 to do away with the collegiate or indirect system of voting. Those amendments have certainly been good enough for the Australian Labor Party (ALP), which is now in government. They were certainly good enough for the ALP when Clyde Cameron was Minister for Labour. The ALP policy of that day stated:
Labor will also ensure a system of democratic control of all unions, allowing the fullest participation by members in their union affairs, a system of participatory democracy.

The Government recently put to a referendum a question which sought to ensure fair elections on the one vote one value system for all Federal and State elections. If that was good enough for Federal and State governments, as the Government was arguing at the time, it should be good enough for union leadership elections also.

Of course, I realise and am sensitive to the fact that Senator Harradine would not be happy with these amendments, because if they were implemented they would negate his hard-won victory of 1976 when he negotiated with the then Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, in support of Mr George Crawford of the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union of Australia and at the urging of Mr B. A. Santamaria and other members of the National Civic Council, to replace the Cameron system with the collegiate system.

There is a history of vested interest for and against this system. On the one hand, we have had previous Labor Ministers and previous Labor policy opposing the collegiate system which is now in place and which is endorsed in this Bill and in place in the Act; and, on the other hand, we have a history of Independents in support of the Fraser Government putting it in place and therefore entrenching a system which, we argue, is inappropriate and unfair. Indeed, in September 1978 Mr Cameron wrote to Mr Crawford on this topic, amongst others. I quote in part from a letter which is contained in his book. The letter stated:

I still have the telegram I received from you on 8 May 1973, calling upon me to withdraw my amendment to the Act which required that all union officers exercising powers to make or alter rules, impose fines upon members, expel members or to exercise the functions of union management, must be elected by a direct vote of all of the union members likely to be affected by those decisions.
The letter continued:

Tell me now, what is wrong with that? But your telegram informed me that my amendments were `causing concern' to your union and called for their withdrawal. The National Civic Council took the same line. Malcolm Fraser also supported the stand stated in your telegram and has obligingly amended the Act to repeal those democratic procedures which I put through the House of Representatives in 1973. In doing so, Malcolm Fraser had the full support of Mr B. A. Santamaria who, in `Point of View' published in the Newsweekly, 26 May 1976, demanded that the Parliament should not be permitted to end its 1976 Autumn Session without deleting those amendments from the Act. He went on to defend the collegiate system for the election of union officials and condemned direct rank and file elections on the ground that they would `ultimately hand over to the Communistic-extreme-Left coalition, behind the camouflage of an A.L.P. ticket'.

In other words, the whole issue of collegiate elections in 1973 and 1976 was extremely emotive and real, one which deserved the attention of the Government and the Opposition, and one which we argue today still deserves the attention of the Government and the Opposition because it is an unacceptable second-best, unnecessary system of elections.

Of course, the realities are that just as the collegiate system has, until recently, been used to entrench right wing union leadership, it could just as easily entrench left wing union leadership. Its effects, as applied now, entrench certain privileged leaders. It is a system that gives rise to entrenchment of certain privileged leaders. In that respect, it is a less than satisfactory and less than adequate electoral system. Merely as a consequential amendment, as all elections would be direct if the Australian Democrats amendments are successful, it should be pointed out that all ballots would, therefore, be secret postal ballots. The Bill does not ensure this with respect to those ballots that come under the collegiate system, although it does ensure it for ballots conducted under the direct voting systems.

It is interesting to note that at the South Australian convention of the ALP, held between 12 and 14 August this year, the following motion was carried without dissent. I note the interest of the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) in this particular motion. I am not sure who the movers of the motion were, but the motion reads:

That in accordance with the referendum proposal that in elections for political office the principle of one-person, one-vote apply, that the Industrial Relations Bill 1988 be amended so as to reflect the same principle in Union elections and in particular that the definition of `Collegiate Electoral System' in s. 4 (1) be amended to exclude the possibility of up to 15 per cent of members of Union Executives and Councils being not directly elected by members.

That is a unanimously supported resolution of the South Australian branch of the ALP in August of this year having to be advanced as an amendment to the Industrial Relations Bill 1988 by the Democrats on behalf of that ALP branch. It will be interesting to hear the Minister's response.

Under the proposed collegiate system, it is possible for up to 15 per cent of national union office-bearers in some unions to be elected without any direct input from their members. This is a patently unfair system of elections, and the intention of these amendments is that that entitlement be expunged from the Bill. The Australian Democrats urge the support of the Committee for these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had hoped not to involve myself in this debate because I thought the debate would be conducted at the level at which it heretofore has been conducted. But since my name was mentioned in dispatches just a moment ago, I should think the Committee would allow me to make a couple of comments.

SPEECH.PARA: I am surprised to learn from Senator McLean, a newcomer to this whole area, that certain things-which I am not aware of-happened long ago. Apparently I was somehow acting in concert with George Crawford and Bob Santamaria over some amendments to legislation. I inform Senator McLean that is mutually contradictory. The implication also is that the Government and the Opposition are now somehow acting in concert with those persons over this issue. I shall make my position perfectly clear. Current proposals in the Bill, for example, clause 197, preserve the importance of direct democracy. But clause 197 also acknowledges that certain unions have a branch structure that is jealously guarded by the particular States, and that is something that only a person deeply involved for many years in the trade union movement would understand. I could name quite a large number of federal secretaries and federal presidents of unions from smaller States who would not have been able to be elected as federal secretary or federal president of the union if a system of direct voting for those offices was in place-that is to say, if there were not a system which enabled persons to be directly elected to a national council, or whatever name the federal management committee is titled, who would then, amongst themselves, elect members of that body as federal office-bearers.

When talking about democracy, it is important to understand that members of this Parliament are elected on a collegiate system. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was not directly elected by the electorate, was he? The Prime Minister was elected by members of his Party-members of the Australian Labor Party, members for whom the electors voted to represent them. They in turn elected their leader. Actually, they would have met beforehand to elect their leader. Let us take the Ministry. Ministers are elected by a group of party members.

It is important to note that the principle of freedom of association should indicate that as far as is possible the rules and structure of an organisation of employees, or employers for that matter, should be left to the members of that organisation and not be imposed upon them by the dead hand of legislation or government. If certain unions choose to proceed along the lines of the collegiate system, that is their choice. There are provisions in the rules of all organisations for amendments to be made to the rules. If they want amendments made to those rules, they can change those rules-there is nothing to stop them.

I should emphasise that the direct system of voting clearly operates at the branch level. For example, if a branch organisation has a State secretary and a State president and so on-I may be wrong, but I cannot think of any union at present that has a collegiate system at that level--

TALK.START.PARA: —At branch level?

—At the branch level. In any event, clause 197 provides that the collegiate electoral system in the case of a full time office is a one-tier collegiate electoral system. That important point should be recognised. I am opposed to the proposition put forward by Senator McLean not only because it is based on false premises, but also because it really is undermining the principle of freedom of association where that freedom would indicate that the members of the organisation should have the right to determine the type of organisation they are in, the structure of that organisation, and its rules.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes these amendments which have been moved by Senator McLean on behalf of the Australian Democrats and which relate to collegiate elections. Prior to 1973, and since 1976, the courts have consistently found that the collegiate style election, when coupled with the statutory requirement that ultimate control of an organisation be in the hands of its members, is democratic. There are a number of cases to which reference can be made to reinforce that, among them the cases of Ford v. the Federated Municipal Workers Union 1954, Steele v. the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia, Crealy v. the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association, Spence v. the Amalgamated Postal Workers Union of Australia, and Grove v. the Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union of Australia. All these cases illustrate examples of where courts of review have approved the collegiate system and specifically found that the utilisation of that system in elections was not oppressive, unreasonable or unjust. It is very significant that this was the view of a wide range of eminent judges, whose assessment of what is just must be highly persuasive.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats, in moving these amendments, have completely overlooked the fact that the Industrial Relations Bill, like the existing Act, specifically provides that control of an organisation and its branches must be in the hands of its members. Thus, any council or committee which is elected is always subject to some approved system of control of its policies and actions by the members. The collegiate system is widely used to guarantee the rights of minority States and branches within a registered organisation. Coming from a small State like South Australia, I believe that is particularly important. A vote of all members of an organisation for each Federal position could mean that a majority State, a large State, could dominate elections and hence dominate the policy of a Federal organisation. In the case of Crealy v. the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association, which I mentioned, the Commonwealth Industrial Court, comprising of the Chief Justice Sir John Spicer, Mr Justice Dunphy and Mr Justice Morgan, stated:
In the creation and maintenance of such a body-
they were referring to a union-

it seems to us not unreasonable that its members should seek to ensure by constitutional provisions that the numerically smaller divisions should have an effective voice in its federal conference and in its federal committee of management. In this particular case, if New South Wales had a majority of the members of the Association, as it conceded it may at times in the future have, it could, if all voting in the federal conference was to be strictly limited to membership strength, elect all the office bearers from that division and thus control the policy and activities of the whole Association.

Senator McLean, in moving his amendments, made the point that the collegiate system emerged where direct democracy was impracticable because of lack of knowledge, remote location, inconvenience or lack of communication and, therefore, where representative democracy made more sense. This is incorrect. The system has flourished in the years right up to the present and has proved to be an effective and efficient democratic way of governing organisations in the contemporary environment. The honourable senator's description of the history of the collegiate system is simply incorrect.

Senator McLean also claimed that `some unions retain it because it allows them the opportunity to manipulate outcomes and numbers on national conferences and national executives'. This is overlooking the fact that, both under the existing legislation, the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, section 140, and the proposed legislation, clause 196, a member of an organisation has the right to have the rules of an organisation, or the actions of the officer of an organisation, scrutinised by the court at any time to rectify any Act which is oppressive, unreasonable or unjust to that member. The manipulation of elections, or the manipulation of numbers on executives, would clearly be conduct which would allow an aggrieved member to bring these matters before the court under the existing and the proposed legislation, the Industrial Relations Bill, which we are now debating.

Senator McLean has also alleged that the collegiate system is capable of entrenching right wing union leadership or left wing union leadership. This misunderstands the collegiate system. The elected officers who engage in a collegiate system are elected by a majority of members of the organisation who prefer the political position of those candidates to that of other candidates. They are therefore reflecting the views of the majority when voting in a collegiate election. The collegiate system cannot therefore contribute to any entrenchment of leadership unless the majority of members want this.

Senator McLean also stated that, if the Democrat amendments were successful, all ballots would thereafter be secret postal ballots. Both the Bill and the existing Act presently provide that all elections for office shall be by secret ballot, but additionally provide that elections, other than collegiate elections, shall be secret postal ballots. Senator McLean appears to misunderstand the legislation in this respect by assuming that collegiate elections are not presently required to be secret ballots.

Senator McLean also said in his speech a few moments ago that `under the proposed collegiate system, it is possible for up to 15 per cent of national union officeholders to be elected without any direct input from the members. This is patently unfair'. The honourable senator is referring to subparagraph (b) of the definition of `collegiate electoral system' in clause 4 of the Bill. He does appear to have misunderstood this subparagraph. The subparagraph deals merely with the situation where the elected body engaged in a collegiate system is not composed in total of officers elected at the first stage of that particular collegiate election. They must, however, have been elected by a previous election pursuant to the Act, as any officer of a registered organisation must be an elected officer, except in the very limited case of casual vacancies, which exception is dealt with by a subparagraph of the definition. Their term of office is also limited by the provisions of the Act and of this present Bill. The honourable senator is wrong in alleging that there can be no direct input from members as to 15 per cent of national officeholders. The collegiate system of elections is well established and it has worked quite reasonably with regard to trade union elections.

As Senator Harradine said a few moments ago, our Australian parliamentary system in many respects is virtually a collegiate system. He referred to the election of the Prime Minister by the members of parliament of the majority party. Of course, under a Labor government not only the Prime Minister but all Ministers of the Crown are elected by their parliamentary colleagues in what is virtually a collegiate system. I hope that Senator McLean would not regard our present parliamentary system as an undemocratic system and a system which entrenches leadership which is not supported by the electorate. It is for these reasons but, more particularly, for the points that I have made in response to Senator McLean's advocacy of his amendments that the Opposition will be opposing the Democrats' amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairperson, if I might use the Commonwealth's non-sexist language--
—Goodness me.
—That is proper usage, Senator Boswell.
—Get back to reality.
—That is reality, Senator. Fifty-four per cent of the population happen to be women. I do not want to get into a side debate about this. There are several points that I want to comment on.
—I am sorry I started all this.

—No, I did. There are several points I want to comment on in terms of the amendments moved by the Australian Democrats. Firstly, I accept what Senator Harradine has said about the alleged conspiracy involving him, George Crawford and the National Civic Council although, when I saw Senator Harradine's thin red leather tie today, I was tempted to believe the conspiracy theory might be true. But I accept the honourable senator's explanation about it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McLean has asked me specifically to reply about the South Australian branch of the Australian Labor Party. As a member of the Labor Party and the National Executive of the Party, I can say that six States and two Territories constitute our national formation, and under our rules one State doing something does not constitute a majority. If it did, we would take more notice of a particular State that expresses a particular view on this subject. But one State expressing a view, five others remaining silent and the two Territories not commenting suggests that, although I certainly find an interest in what the South Australian branch does, I am not necessarily obliged to observe it, and I do not. Thus I do not support the amendments that the honourable senator has put forward.

I am tempted simply to coopt the remarks of the other speakers who have opposed the amendments, but I think the Commonwealth's position should be stated. In referring to those remarks, I note that Senator Chapman frequently referred to secret ballots being held by unions. I say by way of observation that I am glad that at last someone from a conservative Opposition has said that unions hold secret ballots, because the impression that is often generated from the Opposition is that that does not happen.

We have several objections on the issue of collegiate elections. First, a large number of employer and employee organisations already use the collegiate system. There is no major complaint about that: it is a commonly used device to determine how committees are elected. Secondly, the Confederation of Australian Industry has explicitly indicated that it does not support a change, and so has the Australian Council of Trade Unions. As a government that tries to find consensus among our social partners in this respect, I believe we are obliged to take account of those views. Thirdly, some years back we set up the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems to examine industrial relations. That inquiry reported early last year. It deliberated on the question of collegiate elections. It said that the frequency of amendments to a union election requirements was a `frustrating and costly' irritation for unions. Moreover-I think this is the more important point-it said:
unions should have as much freedom as possible in designing procedures to meet their needs within the framework of encouraging democratic control.

The bottom line has to be that it is democratic, but the proper format for democratic control is something that the unions should be free to determine for themselves. Fourthly, that is a view supported by the International Labour Organisation, which has said that the right of unions freely to elect their own representative is essential to enable them to act-these are again the important words-in full freedom and effectively promote the interests of their members. Public authorities should refrain from any intervention which might impair this right. Regulating trade union elections too closely may limit this right.

I think it is a fair observation to make that one of the certain signs of a dictatorship emerging in any country is an immediate move to regulate and control the freedom of election within a union structure. I am not suggesting at all, by the way, that that is the honourable senator's intent. I respect the remarks he has made; I just disagree with them.

There are other good reasons for retaining collegiate elections. Let me be brief about them. First, direct election is not in all situations a guarantee of democratic control. Senators Harradine and Chapman have argued on that point. Secondly, a one-tier collegiate electoral system gives adequate representation to the wishes of rank and file trade unionists. I believe that to be a true statement. But, more importantly, in a united gesture from Government to Opposition-I might say, hands across the chamber-I agree with Senator Chapman. Being from Western Australia, I come from a State with a small population as he does. Senator McLean comes from New South Wales, a State with a large population. There is a need, in structuring a democratic framework, for the consideration of States with smaller populations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad you acknowledge that.

—A collegiate system-exactly the one we are applying here, Senator Boswell-is more likely to do that. Collegiate elections can allow unions to have more democratic control over the elections of their officials. They make it easier for candidates to stand for office in national unions with memberships throughout Australia. For many unions with a highly mobile membership which is geographically dispersed throughout the country, the collegiate electoral system can ensure that the Federal officials of unions are properly representative of the entire membership. Simply to remove from the Bill the provisions which allow collegiate elections would be highly disruptive for organisations with rules which provide for such elections. No transitional provisions are provided in this amendment which would throw into disarray the smooth running of organisations under existing legislation. An amendment to the legislation in 1976 restored the ability for organisations to conduct collegiate elections. This amendment was made prior to the end of the three-year transitional period and many organisations were not required to change their rules.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that there is a contingent amendment, to be moved if these are defeated. I indicate now that the remarks I have made with respect to these amendments will also apply in that case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The responses of the Government and the Opposition were anticipated, and it was probably the anticipation of those responses that caused certain unionists and unions to approach the Australian Democrats specifically in this cause rather than the Government or the Opposition. I concede the superior knowledge and experience of Senator Harradine and the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), but I do not believe that has anything whatsoever to do with the principles about which we were approached by members of unions that are controlled by collegiate systems of election. I do not believe that has anything to do with the fact that the South Australian branch of the Australian Labor Party was forced to approach us to advance its cause in this chamber in relation to the Industrial Relations Bill. They are the realities of the vested interests that prevail, and they result from the fact that unionists were just as able to anticipate the positions that would be taken as we were.

SPEECH.PARA: We reject the arguments that have been put forward about the freedom of association exclusion. We do not believe that a system of direct democracy is in any way threatening to the rights of association or is in any way a process of exclusion to those who partake of it. We still argue the principle that the direct system of democracy is superior to the collegiate system. We are therefore not surprised that unions that find themselves confronted with entrenched representation at their highest levels of control year after year, by a formula which gerrymanders the process of election, are dissatisfied. Nor are we surprised that they should have to approach the Democrats to advance their cause.

I reject Senator Chapman's claim that we misunderstand what the Bill is proposing. We simply interpret it differently and we project different opportunities into it from what he may wish to project. I do not think it is reasonable to say that we therefore misunderstand it. The realities are seen in the case of the Federated Clerks Union of Australia, which is one of the unions that approached us about their dissatisfaction in relation to the formula that applies in those unions. Fifteen per cent of its leadership can be elected and remain entrenched, year after year, without going back to the membership to be re-elected. There is no way of breaking that bind: it is all a matter of how the numbers fall out from period to period. It is all about numbers. It is quite legitimate to say that it is in the interests of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Government and some unions to have this system in place because the numbers fall out the right way. We are simply acknowledging that it is the limitations of the collegiate system which enable those games to be played. We do not apologise for having advanced, on behalf of some unions presently using the collegiate system, amendments suggested by them to us to rectify the inadequacies of the system they are confronted with. On their behalf I commend those amendments to the chamber.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator McLean's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Page 3, subclause 4 (1), definition of ``collegiate electoral system'', paragraph (b), lines 20 to 27, leave out the paragraph.

I will be very brief. This is a contingent amendment. We are suggesting that if the Opposition and the Government are not prepared to accept the proposition that collegiate elections could be improved upon by direct forms of democracy which are quite achievable, readily available and quite appropriate, perhaps they will acknowledge the fact that it is quite clearly inappropriate that up to 15 per cent of the leadership of some unions using the collegiate system can be elected to their positions and remain entrenched in those positions indefinitely without reference to the membership. In proposing this contingent amendment we are again simply saying to the Opposition and the Government: collegiate elections now remain in place but there is absolutely no reason why 15 per cent of elected office-bearers should be elected by and from that college without any reference at all to the membership.

Once again we are advancing this amendment specifically at the request of the unions to which it applies. Honourable senators know why those unions have not used the alternative avenues of access to this Bill. They have not done so because they have entrenched vested interests in the formula that prevails. So, they have come to us. It is now on the record that we have advanced a proposition which clearly simply says, `Let us be as democratic as is possible and let us scrub out from this Bill any opportunity for people to remain entrenched year after year without having to return to the members to have their positions endorsed'.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator McLean's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

My clock seems to have been connected the wrong way around. Hence, I was unable to be in the chamber on that occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (26) Page 100, paragraph 213 (2) (a), line 26, leave out ``or'' (last occurring).
(27) Page 100, after paragraph 213 (2) (a), insert the following new paragraph:
``(aa) on application by or on behalf of a number, ascertained as prescribed, of the members of the organisation or branch; or''.

These amendments relate to clause 213 of the Bill and refer to certificates of exemption permitting organisations to conduct their own elections. Our amendments would give a prescribed number of members of an organisation the right to apply to the Registrar for the revoking of a certificate of exemption which enables the organisation to conduct its own elections. Under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act an organisation or a prescribed number of members of an organisation may request that the Registrar conduct elections for office with a view to ensuring that no irregularities occur. Such elections are usually administered by the Australian Electoral Commission. Of course, such elections have become very common.

Under the present Bill elections for office are to be normally conducted by the Australian Electoral Commission. Organisations may, however, request a certificate of exemption to enable them to conduct their own elections. Members of those organisations, however, under this legislation are given no right to seek the revoking of such exemption. In practice this means that, where an organisation is conducting its own elections and there is concern on the part of a number of members that it would be more appropriate for the Electoral Commission to conduct the elections because of the fear of irregularities, those members would no longer have the right to apply to the Registrar for this to occur. Our amendments therefore effectively restore the rights of the organisation's members-rights which this Bill would take away-to seek the revoking of a certificate of exemption which enables a particular organisation to conduct its own elections. I urge the Committee to support our amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments are not acceptable to the Government. I shall not go into all the details of what is in the Bill and why the amendments are not acceptable, except to say that there are a number of procedures which affect the environment in which the proposed Opposition amendments have to be considered. First, any irregularity in the conduct of an election or any experience of irregularity in the conduct of elections in an organisation would or could lead to the revocation of the exemption by the Registrar. That has happened.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, members objecting to the granting of the exemption always have the right to be heard by the Registrar before any exemption is granted. Finally, should any irregularity occur in the conduct of an election for office, a member can apply for an inquiry into the election under clause 218 of the Bill. That is the procedure which has been there traditionally and which is preserved in this Bill. Having regard to this and a variety of other circumstances, the Government does not regard these amendments as necessary and opposes them.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (32) Page 131, after subclause 264 (6), add the following new subclause:

``(7) Where a member of an organisation has not, for a period of 6 months, paid membership subscription that the rules of the organisation require members to pay, the person shall be deemed to have resigned from membership.''.

This amendment relates to clause 264 and to resignations from an organisation. The amendment provides that, where a member of an organisation does not for a period of six months pay membership subscription, that person shall be deemed to have resigned from membership of the organisation. Under section 145 of the existing Conciliation and Arbitration Act a member of an organisation is allowed to resign his membership by notice in writing if he ceases to be employed in or in connection with the industry or industrial pursuit in relation to which the organisation is registered. Alternatively, a member may resign by giving at least three months' notice of his intention to resign.

These provisions are essentially retained under this Bill. Not only do members have to resign in writing, but the resigning member possesses the onus of proving that his resignation has been received by the organisation. Clause 264 (1) requires that the written notice of the resignation shall be addressed and delivered to a person designated for the purpose in the rules of the organisation or branch of the organisation. A resignation would not be effective if it were merely put in writing, addressed to the appropriate officer, and placed in the post. There must be proof of receipt by the organisation. In practice, this usually means sending the written notice of resignation by registered mail. All of this applies even if the person has left his job to which the union membership related. Thus, one would still remain a member of an organisation even after one ceased to do the work that made one eligible to become a member, unless one provided the appropriate written notice.

In practice many union members do not know of these requirements. They simply cease paying their union subscriptions and possibly tell their union delegate that they are leaving the union. This means that many people unwittingly remain in the union. Unions may then years later pursue individuals for back subscriptions, usually amounting to hundreds of dollars. This of course is quite inappropriate, unreasonable and unfair. It is for this reason that we move our amendment relating to resignation from organisations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —There would be some merit in this proposal if it were to apply only in the case where a person ceases to be eligible to remain a member of a union by virtue of the fact that that member has ceased to be employed in an occupation or industry covered by the scope rule of the union. To that extent it would seem to me to have merit, but at present it appears that it would apply also to those persons who are eligible to remain in the union. Thus, it would create large administrative difficulties with organisations. If the Opposition intends to clear up the problem of persons who leave their occupation covered by the union rules, do not indicate to the union their intention and after six months are deemed to have resigned, I can see some merit in the amendment. But unless it is limited to that problem-and it is a problem-as it stands at present I could not support it, unless Senator Chapman is prepared to limit it to that aspect.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. To demonstrate how serious he and his Government are in their commitment to the environment, can the Minister explain why he personally failed to attend the last meeting of the Australian Environment Council and the last meeting of the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers (CONCOM)? Is it a fact that these two meetings are the peak meetings for Commonwealth and State Ministers responsible for environment and conservation matters, and that the last meetings were set at a date to suit the Commonwealth's convenience? Can the Minister justify the Commonwealth's total lack of any ministerial representation at the latter two of these meetings? Similarly, if this Government is serious about support for sport in Australia, in addition to Budget cuts for sports funding, can the Minister say why he failed to attend the last meeting of the Australian Sports Ministers Council, and why that meeting was held without any ministerial representation from the Federal Labor Government? Can the Minister confirm that he simply failed to attend any of these three meetings-of the Environment Council, the Nature Conservation Council and the Sports Council-for which he is the responsible Federal Labor Minister, and that at least two of those meetings the Commonwealth had no ministerial presence at all?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
