ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the comments quoted by Senator Zakharov in an RSL publication. As far as I am aware, those comments reflect the views of the author and not necessarily those of the RSL. It is true, I think, that from time to time the RSL does have divided views over immigration. It is usually those with the more extremist or colourful approach that tend to get the publicity, and those with a more reasoned approach tend to be ignored in the press, although there are one or two exceptions. I reiterate that this Government will stick to a firm policy of non-discrimination so that no nationality or race is either favoured or disadvantaged. There are a lot of myths in the community as to the entitlement of migrants coming to this country. They do not get special treatment. Refugees do not get bumped up housing lists and they do not get a brand new car the moment they arrive. Many of them have to struggle and struggle very hard. But the actual level of achievement by refugees, no matter what part of the world they come from, having settled in Australia, is quite magnificent.

ANSWER.PARA: I am disappointed from time to time when I see these particular articles appearing; they serve only to inflame prejudice. It is very easy in this community to spread misconceptions. Probably the worst offender is late night talkback radio but also via newsletters, et cetera, many of these particular myths become entrenched and are regarded as reality. It is very hard for government or political parties as a whole to dispel these myths. In the case of this one I say that there is no special treatment accorded to immigrants or refugees. The only government programs that are there to assist them are those in terms of access and equity to give them an equal chance within Australia for access to services. That is the way it should be. It will not be my position, as the Minister for Immigration, to try to condemn every article such as this. They are numerous.

I do believe that in the long term government must look at some sort of educative program to put a lot of the facts on the record. I am not talking about a political campaign; I am talking about an information campaign that if properly based might enable us to have a more reasonable immigration debate in this country. We might be able to have a debate in which most of the facts are agreed. We can then get onto other judgments and debate those on a rational basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. My office is grateful for having had the response from Minister Hand that some 260 Aboriginal communities and leaders in Western Australia have been sent a package containing a copy of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) legislation which was first tabled in the House of Representatives on 24 August this year. As recent telephone calls to some communities have revealed that they have not all received the Minister's package, I ask: Is it a fact that Minister Hand gave an undertaking to give sufficient time to Aboriginal groups in Western Australia to study this legislation? Is it a fact that the Aboriginal land rights legislation for the Northern Territory, under the Federal Liberal Government in 1976, was available for public scrutiny after being introduced to the Parliament for nearly six months? To date, what suggestions for amendments to the ATSIC legislation has the Minister received from Aboriginal people?

—I have been informed by the office of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that between 25 August and 6 September a videotape entitled `Aboriginal Australia: Special Edition' and an information kit comprising the Bill and explanatory memorandum, a guide to the Bill, the second reading speech and a covering letter from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs were dispatched to 987 Aboriginal organisations around Australia, including 268 in Western Australia. A map of ATSIC boundaries was dispatched on 20 September. The list of organisations which received the material was prepared on the advice of State directors of the Department. State directors and regional managers have also been provided with a supply of the material to ensure that information about the legislation is readily available to all members of the Aboriginal community. That is consistent with the Minister's undertaking that legislation and associated explanatory material would be widely disseminated to Aboriginals and Aboriginal groups. The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Bill 1976 was introduced into the Parliament on 4 June 1976. It achieved passage in the Senate on 9 December 1976. The Minister has been informed by the ATSIC task force that it is aware of only one formal request to amend the ATSIC Bill at this stage. This request was received from the Yugulmangi community government council from Ngukurr in the Northern Territory.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. As there is pressure in this Parliament to bring on this legislation this session, I ask the Minister whether any special consideration is going to be given to the Aboriginal communities in the outer areas such as in the northern parts of Western Australia where it will take some time, if that package was sent on 20 September, to reach those groups. It will take a little longer for it to reach those groups. Is any special consideration going to be given as far as those groups are concerned to make sure that they are able to put in their returns?

—As I indicated, State directors and regional managers have been advised which communities should receive these materials. I would imagine that some of them are in remote locations and that it would take more than an overnight postal service for the communities to receive them. I know from personal experience of trying to contact the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs at various times that he is constantly on the move amongst many Aboriginal communities in the most remote areas of Australia. He has taken an active and exhausting role in conferring with them and ascertaining their wishes so they might be best represented in the legislation that comes before the Parliament. I am sure that he and his office will be taking every step possible to ensure that those in remote regions of Australia have an opportunity to make their views known as much as those who are in the more settled areas or even urban areas.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. What has been the impact of World Expo 88 on tourism in Australia? Is it true that Expo 88 has had a negative impact on domestic tourism?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Expo 88 has been an extraordinary success. By this week Expo attendance is running at 13 1/2 million and is expected to be 15 million by the end in the next few weeks. That is an extraordinary number of people. It shows the foresight involved by those who sought to bring it to Australia.
—Who was that?
—Llew Edwards.

—I can confirm what Senator Tate has just said. Sir Llew Edwards has done a great job. According to the World Expo 88 Authority the Queensland market has contributed about half of the number of people who have attended which is, of course, significant. It shows just how often people in Brisbane have gone to see it. I am glad we have given them something to do. Apart from that, approximately one-third of the people have come from interstate. That figure has obviously varied dramatically depending upon holiday seasons. In holiday seasons that third jumps up enormously. The international market has been responsible for just under 20 per cent attendance. By looking at where people have come from, it can be seen that there has been a considerable spread.

ANSWER.PARA: Obviously, the economic benefits are starting to emerge. That has happened pretty quickly. Business contracts worth about $100m have been signed up as a result of the Expo business centre. Qantas Airways Ltd has reported a 21 per cent increase in overseas visitors to mid-September. There is no doubt that Expo has had a very considerable impact on Australian tourism and all to the good.

There have been some criticisms about domestic tourism and whether it has been made to suffer. All that could be said is that certainly a lot of people have chosen to ignore some other resort areas in Queensland and perhaps northern New South Wales and go to Brisbane for Expo instead. There have been some isolated instances where the local tourist market has suffered because of Expo. Having said that, there is no evidence as yet that domestic tourism as a whole has been harmed by it. I would be surprised if that evidence does come in at a later point. Obviously, that one-fifth of tourists or just under that I mentioned coming in from overseas has added to the enormous numbers coming in for reasons other than Expo.

That being the case, the Government has just announced a $240m expansion at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport to make sure that we can cope with those huge numbers which, by the way, were running at 1.2 million halfway through the year and will be about 2.2 million, we think, by the end of the year. Australia has many, many attractions. Expo in Brisbane has been foremost among them during this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Acting Attorney-General. I refer him to the Government's proposal to introduce a comprehensive tax file numbering system and the proposed accompanying privacy legislation. I ask: What is the status of the proposed privacy legislation being developed as a complement to the tax file numbering system? Is it a fact that this proposed tax file numbering system is estimated to yield additional tax revenue of only $340m by 1993-94?
—Only.

—Wait for it. Further, is it also widely recognised in the community that the extent of the cash economy and tax evasion runs into many billions of dollars, perhaps as many as $10 billion? Of course, this has been admitted by the Treasurer to be at least $6 billion. As it is clear from this that the proposed tax file numbering system will have only a minimal impact on tax evasion, what justification can the Government make for the introduction of this system, other than that it is being taken as a first step in the Government's still deep desire to introduce a comprehensive identification system akin to the bungled Australia Card proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most parts of the question addressed to me by Senator Messner do not fall within my portfolio responsibilities; certainly, the last three of the four parts of the question do not. Nevertheless, I think it is fair to say that every step is taken to ensure that the revenues of this nation are protected and that they are available for the proper expenditures which the Government, elected by the people, decides should be undertaken.

ANSWER.PARA: I think that most Australians, whilst aware that there may be other areas of evasion and the black economy which also have to be addressed, would support those simple straightforward steps which are foreshadowed in the tax file number legislation. As I say, they are not really within my portfolio responsibility. As to the figures put forward by Senator Messner, I am quite unable to comment on their accuracy or their comparative worth.
As to the status of the privacy legislation, that legislation is intended in many ways to stand in its own right.

TALK.START.PARA: —Separate and distinct!

—It is important that privacy legislation be introduced into this Parliament. But the fact is that the community and, indeed, the Opposition and the Government see that the links between the general desire for privacy and the assurances that are required in relation to tax file number legislation are such that that privacy legislation should be introduced into the Parliament as soon as possible. That will be done. I would expect that to be achieved very shortly.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is quite clear that the Minister simply does not know what the right hand is doing, let alone the left. The point is this: can he make representations to the appropriate Minister to provide the Senate with a cost-benefit analysis so that the economics of the tax file numbering system can be made clear before the privacy legislation is brought in?
—It is quite obvious that that question is not within my portfolio responsibility.

—My question to the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer relates to the matter of average living standards in Australia. In the adjournment debate yesterday Senator Messner argued that the family circumstances that he had described in detail in the Senate on 30 September represented a true average. Is the Government persuaded that the picture of average living standards given in Senator Messner's figures provides an accurate indicator of development in true average living standards in the Australian community since 1983?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have looked at Senator Messner's comments in yesterday's adjournment debate. He asserted again that the figures he presented to the Senate on 30 September related to `the average family in this country'. I have had a look at these figures. I know it is hard to understand these things or absorb them but I appeal to members of the Opposition at least to make an attempt to do so. I think that most of the Liberals anyway are probably capable of absorbing the information if they concentrate very hard. I am not so sure about the National Party.
—We have to concentrate very hard to hear you.

—However, I am sure that Senator Stone is quite capable of absorbing it. Let me tell honourable senators about the particular family, to use Senator Messner's phrase, that the figures relate to. It is a family of four with dad, as Senator Messner puts it, being a full time worker and working as an employee; mum, as Senator Messner puts it, does not work outside the home and, apparently, has not done so at any time in the last five years; and there are two dependent children. That, says Senator Messner, is the average Australian family.

ANSWER.PARA: The latest Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) survey of the labour force in fact found that there were some 670,000 families with a husband working full time, a wife not in the labour force and one or more dependent children. Therefore, it is a slightly broader definition, indeed a significantly broader definition, than Senator Messner's mum, dad and two dependent children. The ABS family is mum, dad and one or more children, which is obviously a significantly broader category. That survey also included the self-employed as well as the wage earner. There were 670,000 families in that category.

Families with dependent children in which both parents were in paid employment numbered 948,000. Altogether there were 4.1 million families in Australia, which, of course, included families with grown-up children, retired couples, sole parents and so on. Therefore, Senator Messner's average family in fact at this stage is less than one in six of all families.

Senator Messner's specific family is, indeed, a great deal more special because it paid private health insurance in 1983 and also managed to claim a tax rebate under the old concessional expenditure tax rebate system. In 1982-83 fewer than one in 10 Australian taxpayers claimed a rebate under that tax rebate concession. Therefore, what was one in six has now become one in 60, at least.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is not mathematically logical.

—Here is the expert on logic! He does not know whether his Party is going to phase in tax cuts over three years or one year. He got himself sacked from the front bench for his trouble. I was about to point out that that included all taxpayers, but there is no reason to believe that there would be a significant distributional difference between these particular taxpayers in Senator Messner's families and taxpayers in general. Therefore, one in six Australians has become about one in 60. Well over half of those people had taxable incomes in excess of $22,000 a year, which is well above Senator Messner's example of a typical family on a $19,000 income. So the one in 60 Australians is now one in 120. Of course, the breadwinner in Senator Messner's family is assumed by Senator Messner--
—Order! There are too many interjections from both sides of the chamber. I call Senator Walsh.

—This is the latest tactic of the Opposition. I thought it was the elephant juice yesterday when honourable senators opposite were making all their noise but now I can see that it is a deliberate tactic designed to protect them, I suppose, from the exposure of their intellectual sloth and moral humbug. Of course, Senator Messner's typical family is one that has received no benefit from the 3 per cent productivity-superannuation round. So the one in 120 Australians has become one in 240. Indeed, the number of typical families to which Senator Messner referred has now become so small that it surprises me he has not given us the names and addresses of all of them. The Liberal Party has put as much intellectual effort and vigour into this exercise as it put into its 1987 alternative Budget.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, and relates to the concerns expressed by many families in rural Tasmania and, I suspect, in all rural Australia. Can the Minister advise on the number of families likely to be affected by the Government's uncaring decision both to reduce funding of the assistance for isolated children scheme by 16.9 per cent and to impose assets tests on AIC recipients and their families? Is the Government aware that the low incomes currently experienced by rural families with respect to farm asset valuations mean that the Government, by its assets test, is condemning many rural children to a life on this Government's massive unemployment payroll? Further, is the Minister, on behalf of the Government, prepared to foreshadow any alternative measures to ensure that rural children are afforded the same opportunities for education as are those in metropolitan areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I recall correctly from the Senate Estimates committee hearing yesterday or the day before, that 16.9 per cent reduction in the total amount paid is partly attributable, and I believe mostly attributable, to the transfer of some people formerly receiving assistance under this program to another educational allowance program. I am sorry, I cannot remember the details of that.

ANSWER.PARA: Moving on to the assets test, I point out, firstly, that the basic component of assistance to isolated children-that is, an annual payment of, I think, $980 a year-continues to be paid to everybody. Additional payments have always been income tested. This year an assets test has been added to the income test, and that will reduce the payments for some students from better-off families who would otherwise have qualified for the income tested additional benefits. It will, however, count for only 50 per cent of the value of the farm or business on or in which the owner works, disregard the value of the family home, as for a number of other cases, and allow mortgages or other encumbrances to be deducted in calculating the net market value of an asset. Off the top of my head, I cannot recall what the total asset allowance is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some $300,000. I thank Senator Hill. I thought that was the case. The plain fact is that if anybody has a business asset of $300,000 and is getting anything like--
—You were a farmer. You know that some years they are not getting any income at all.
—You have been there. You know what it is about.

—Any more? If a person with a business asset of $300,000, and who is also working, were getting a reasonable income and a reasonable return on that asset, he or she would already have been income tested out of the additional allowances by a very big margin. On the other hand, if that person is not getting a reasonable return on the value of the business asset, the asset is either being mismanaged or is overpriced.
—That is rubbish.

—Here are the people who proclaim themselves to be experts in the operation of a capitalist system and a market economy. Senator Boswell says, `That is rubbish'. We know how much respect Senator Boswell's Party has for the operations of a market economy. That is why in Queensland one can grow sugarcane wherever one likes, but if one grows it on land that is not assigned one has to deliver it to the cane board; one is told what mill to deliver it to, when to deliver it, and so on. That is the operation of a market system Queensland National Party style. I repeat: anybody who is getting a reasonable return from an asset of that value plus recompense for his or her own labour would have been income tested out of the allowance. If that person is not getting a reasonable return, either he or she is managing the asset inefficiently or the asset is overpriced.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not the business of governments to correct the overvaluation of an asset through some payments system, nor is it the business of governments to compensate people for inefficiency in managing assets. Indeed, to the extent that assets are mismanaged, it is to the advantage of society as a whole that the management of that asset be transferred from the current inefficient manager to some other person.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the beef crisis? What about the wool crisis?

—I know that it is difficult to give people who sit opposite the most elementary lessons in economic logic, but the cost of drought, I point out to Senator Boswell, should be negatively capitalised in the price of the land. That is the proper market response-the system which Opposition members say they support but which none of them understands.

—Is the Minister for Consumer Affairs aware that unsuspecting consumers are being ripped off in get rich quick schemes sent through the mail, and can the Minister do anything to protect consumers from such schemes?
—Tell the post office not to deliver them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —That thought did cross my mind. The question asked by Senator Childs involves not a postal strike but pyramid selling, which is a problem that has been endemic in Australia from time to time. It is a scheme which promotes the promise of getting rich very quickly-riches that never eventuate for anyone other than those at the top of the pyramid. Section 61 of the Trade Practices Act provides for such schemes and, in fact, declares them illegal. The financial reward does not eventuate. The section provides that people who promote those operations can in fact be prosecuted.

ANSWER.PARA: So the short answer to Senator Childs's question is yes, the Government can do something about the get rich quick scheme that is currently floating in the community. The provision has been in the Act for some time, but it was only recently that the Trade Practices Commission in fact initiated proceedings, and has been successful in prosecuting the promoter of a pyramid selling scheme. This was the first prosecution in Australia and a successful one. The conviction is one of two important steps pursued by the Government and the Trade Practices Commission to make the public aware of the pitfalls of such schemes and also to stop them. In this particular case, the promoter had been promoting the Edward L. Green scheme. He was contacted by the Trades Practices Commission a couple of times. He did not desist from promoting the scheme. As a consequence, he was prosecuted and convicted, as well as having a penalty of $1,500 imposed on him. This is an important part of the Trade Practices Commission's attack on such promoters and such schemes.

The other aspect is an educational campaign. It is a campaign that the Commission, in consultation with the Government, has been promoting in order to warn people-I think in this case the scheme operated in South Australia-and generally make people aware of the dangers encountered in schemes such as this.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT PUBLISHING SERVICE: STYLE MANUAL

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women inform the Senate of the cost of the preparation, printing and distribution of the new 17-page chapter on non-sexist language for the Style Manual of the Australian Government Publishing Service? Is further expenditure of public money to be committed for the purpose of butchering the English language? Does the Minister foresee that the term `manual' may soon be at risk as a consequence of the campaign for non-sexist language?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Knowles has raised questions about the non-sexist chapter in the Style Manual. I believe that there has been a gross overreaction in some sections of the media to this particular chapter. On Friday John Laws directed a number of callers to my office to complain about the legislation that the Government was going to bring down to enforce the use of non-sexist terminology! It was obvious that John Laws was totally misinformed and exaggerating the intent--
—That is not the question I asked.

—I am coming to that, Senator, but I think it is important to raise the issue of how people have grossly overreacted to it. I think that it gives some indication of the power of John Laws when he can say to people, `Ring Margaret Reynolds's office and complain' and they ring and say, `I don't know what I am complaining about, but John Laws told me to do it'. I think that brings into serious question the responsibility of certain media commentators.

ANSWER.PARA: To come to Senator Knowles's question: I can give her the exact costs of the consultancy for the chapter. The cost of this was $3,691 all up, including the consultancy fee, travel allowance, et cetera. Senator Knowles might be interested to know that on the basis of a population of 16 million this would mean that the cost for the Style Manual project would be 0.02c for the whole population or 0.04c per woman in the population.

The answer to the second part of Senator Knowles's question is no and the answer to the third part of her question about whether the use of the word `manual' would be banned is also no. I think it important that honourable senators appreciate that the Style Guide is precisely that-a guide. It is important that the chapter highlights the way in which non-sexist language can be used to further promote equality of women in Australian society. No-one is going around saying, `Don't use the word ``manual'' '. No-one is saying that we must use the phrase `utility hole' rather than the word `manhole'. That is taking an extreme position in relation to the guidelines. It is a chapter relating to guidelines and it is anticipated that editors and authors should refer to it and think whether they can use another form of language whereby there is not the automatic assumption that one is talking about only men when in fact, one is referring to men and women.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. With relation to the consultancy, I ask the Minister: Was the consultancy publicly tendered? If not, who chose the consultant; and, if so, on what basis was the consultant chosen anyway?
—As that question relates to a period before I was Minister responsible, I will have to take it on notice.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of a delegation from the Parliament of Ireland, led by the Speaker of the House, Mr Sean Treacy. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome you, Mr Speaker, and your delegation to Parliament House and to the Senate. I hope your visit to Australia is both informative and enjoyable.
—I call Senator McKiernan.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President.
—No commercials are allowed.

—More appropriately, go raibh mile maith agat, a uachtarain. It is nice not to be the only Irish born politician in this place, but that is not going to last for too long. I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether he has seen a report in last Saturday's West Australian newspaper quoting Mr Wilson Tuckey when he opened the Bellvue goldmine, north of Kalgoorlie, as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: I made the clear point that our policy was not to impose a gold tax and in any party forum I would take a very very tough line on ensuring that our policy did not change.

Given this opposition, and the opposition of Senator Crichton-Browne reported in the same article, will the Government still proceed with the removal of the exemption from taxation of income from goldmining? If it does proceed, does the Government anticipate any delay in the announced schedule for the removal of the exemption on 1 January 1991?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry I do not have the right accent for our guests.
—You have the right name.
—I have got an appropriate name, yes.
—Have you got the right answer?
—I certainly have the right answer. I have seen a copy of the article to which Senator McKiernan referred. Just for the record, it also quotes Senator Crichton-Browne as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: My commitment is no different from that which I made in the campaign I conducted in the party organisation against the tax. I will strongly oppose it in party forums.

Once again we have members of the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party-a party which, if I may say so, has a well-established record of permissiveness, to say the least, towards dodgy tax practices-upholding the privilege of a particularly favoured group in the community who do not want to pay their fair share of taxation. They believe that, while every other industry in business in Australia pays taxation, people who hold shares in goldmining companies should not pay tax.

I have been asked whether this opposition will make any difference to the Government's policy of removing the exemption. The answer to that is no, it will make no difference. I do not believe that these couple of people in the Opposition will have any effect because there are more important people in the Liberal Party-I know they are not terribly important people overall, but they are important people in the Liberal Party-such as the Leader. In comments on this matter reported from an investment seminar which was held in New York last week, he said that it would be very hard to justify the continued exemption of one section of Australian industry over another. I concur entirely. That comment was itself a reinforcement of a statement made by Mr Peacock in May that the Opposition would not be making recommendations to block it. For those reasons, among other reasons, I do not believe that the opposition of these particular couple of people will make any difference to the legislative program.

It is possible and indeed, I understand, very likely that the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party is making a desperate appeal to the lobby to pay funds into the Liberal Party in order to fund its State election campaign. If it does that, that is its affair. Let me just say that it is wasting its money if it does. This is yet another example of the maverick Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party thumbing its nose yet again at a weak Federal leadership.

Finally, it will be interesting to see which way Senator Chaney jumps on this-whether he supports the leadership of the Liberal Party in the House of Representatives or whether he makes the same sorts of noises that his Western Australian colleagues are making in order to ingratiate the Liberal Party with the tax dodging lobby in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. With the decision of the Government to replace the $2 note with a $2 coin, is the Minister aware that the pioneers of agriculture are being removed from the Australian currency? In view of this Government's record of continuing high inflation, when the Government is considering a $200 note will it arrange for a picture of Farrer, the father of the wheat industry, to be placed on that note in recognition of the industry's role in generating such a high proportion of Australia's export earnings?

—I am very flattered to be asked this question, because I know absolutely nothing about the topic. It is very encouraging that Senator Bjelke-Petersen thinks I do. Being a more astute senator, I can understand her general position. I will certainly make inquiries of the Treasurer regarding this matter. On the point of whether notes or coins should commemorate particular figures of great scientific prowess in terms of their contribution to agriculture, I am not sure-it is a matter of opinion-that we should necessarily be stuck with Farrer, because some other very great Australian scientists have contributed enormously to agriculture in this country.
—Give us a few names.

—Well, there are some in the divisions of plant and technology of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation who would fall into that category. I do not propose to answer the interjections of any of Senator Bjelke-Petersen's colleagues. She having directed a thoughtful question to me, I will supply her with a thoughtful answer in due course.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I refer to the fact that the Royal Australian Navy has planted unidentified observers at meetings of the Jervis Bay Protection Committee and the fact that the Navy's Commodore Matt Taylor has now initiated legal action against Committee Convener Sue Hanley for comments she made during a recent meeting. Did the Minister know of, authorise or order these espionage and harassment activities against the Jervis Bay Protection Committee? Is it a fact that the Government will be funding this legal action, either directly or indirectly? What involvement of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) in this or any other aspect of the Navy's proposed shift to Jervis Bay has been initiated or requested by the Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the first thing to say in answer to Senator Sanders is that it is not normally the case that all those who attend a public meeting identify themselves and declare that they represent an organisation.
—Like a Labor Party conference.

—I hope it is not like the Australian Labor Party conference. If one walks into a meeting, one is entitled to sit there and mind one's own business and listen to the proceedings. Anyone at a public meeting who seeks to say more than he or she ought to say within the law on a question of defamation has to face the music. As far as the question is concerned, the Minister has not known of, authorised or ordered any espionage or the harassment of anyone in the Jervis Bay Protection Committee. As for legal action between Commodore Taylor and Ms Hanley, I can say that the Minister certainly has no knowledge of any action of that kind. As to whether the Commonwealth will fund such action directly or indirectly, one would imagine that it will continue to pay the Commodore concerned, so if he is to pay for a legal action out of his own pocket, I suppose we could draw a long bow and say we are funding it indirectly. Obviously, the Commonwealth will not be funding this legal action. As for ASIO being requested by the Minister to get involved, I think I can again issue a blanket denial.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article on the front page of today's Sydney Morning Herald business section referring to the activities of the long term audit teams of the Australian Taxation Office operating among Australia's top 100 companies? The article was headlined `Big business's most unwelcome guest'. The article reports that the Managing Director of Elders Finance Group Ltd, John Crosby, has written to John Hall of the Australian Merchant Bankers Association (AMBA) offering Elders' assistance in establishing a unit within the AMBA to conduct a propaganda war with the Tax Office. I ask: Would any costs incurred by Elders or other members of the AMBA in conducting such a propaganda war against the Australian Tax Office be tax deductible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article, which reports that for every dollar spent in audit activity about $8 of additional revenue is raised. It also says that there have been 10 such auditors in Elders offices for the past six months and, on the basis of the 8 : 1 rule of thumb, that would have brought in about $2m extra from Elders. The article also says-I suppose as a result of that apparent outcome-that Elders is particularly upset by the Tax Office. Indeed, according to the article, the Elders letter to the Merchant Bankers Association says:

ANSWER.PARA: It is apparent to us that the Australian Taxation Office, Canberra, which now has a public relations department . . . puts the ATO view in emotive language to the public and is now very active.

Further it is our view that from an ATO viewpoint this campaign has been an outstanding success because no one has publicly contradicted such statements at all, let alone in a calm and rational manner.

I am pleased to see that Elders recognises that the Tax Office is winning the battle against tax evaders and tax avoiders and that there is little public sympathy for shonky notions that taxes are something for wage earners but not for silvertails. The views in the letter come from a company whose Chief Executive would be Prime Minister if he could only organise it. I say for any of Mr Elliott's shareholders who are listening or who read a report of this in the press that if he is going to use Elders shareholders' funds to run a political campaign targeting the Tax Office, which is impartially implementing the laws which have been passed by this Parliament, as I understand the taxation law, a contribution to a propaganda campaign of that sort will not be an allowable deduction from the company's taxable income.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: OFFICE OF THE STATUS OF WOMEN

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, relates to an article in last Friday's Age by Eva Cox questioning the achievements of the office of the Status of Women and indicating that it is often referred to as `The Office of Women of Status' and as being peripheral? First, is the article's author correct in saying that, despite some achievements, which are acknowledged, `In a time when economic outcomes override all other considerations, the office appears to be marginalised'? Secondly, as the main public activity of the Office is in the areas of domestic violence and images of women in the media and, as Senator Knowles points out, in style guides, how can the Minister defend the Office against the claim made in the article `that these marginal areas are seen as an appropriate playpen for a unit with limited legitimacy in the core areas of government'? Thirdly, how does the Minister propose to address the claim that the Fraser Government's National Women's Advisory Council was powerful, spoke out against Government decisions, and represented its constituency as opposed to the present National Women's Consultative Council, which lacks access to the media, and, more importantly, to the Prime Minister? Fourthly, do the remarks made by the new Office head imply a further restriction of the Council's role to that of a body which in reality is intended only to be a publicity arm of the Government rather than a genuine agent for change on behalf of women?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to summarise as much as possible. I have read the article. I think that in her comments Eva Cox was fair in certain areas but perhaps not so well informed in others. First, in regard to her comments that status of women issues have been marginalised, I would say that she is not at all in touch with the process by which the Office functions. The Office monitors all Cabinet submissions and makes an input about the impact any major decision would have on Australian women.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, her comments about the National Women's Consultative Council indicate that she is obviously further out of touch because when I addressed the recently appointed third National Women's Consultative Council at its first meeting I emphasised that that organisation was to be regarded as totally independent. Certainly, it is appointed by government but it is to be independent. I can arrange for a number of press statements already issued by the Council to be sent to Senator Vanstone. The Council is certainly speaking out in the media.

Thirdly, let me indicate that the Council does have access to Ministers. In fact, the Prime Minister hosted the inaugural meeting of the National Women's Consultative Council a month or so ago. I think Senator Vanstone and a number of Opposition members, together with Government members, met Council members at a social function. Furthermore, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, John Dawkins, will be speaking with the Council at its next meeting in November. While I am normally a great admirer of Eva Cox and pay tribute to a great deal of work she has done in the past, I think that perhaps she is not up to date in her understanding of how the Office of the Status of Women functions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Lewis asked me to reconsider my decision that certain words used by Senator Walsh in answering a question from Senator Foreman were not unparliamentary. I have examined the transcript of the question and answer concerned. I believe that the words used by Senator Walsh to which objection was taken could not possibly be regarded as unparliamentary or as a personal reflection within the meaning of standing order 418.

—Yesterday Senator Peter Baume asked me a question concerning protection of witnesses. I undertook to investigate the matter to which he referred. I am advised that the committee concerned is now looking into the matter, as it is obliged to do by the resolution of the Senate of 25 February 1988. I will therefore not take any further action until the committee has concluded its investigation. In response to Senator Baume's question as to whether witnesses are protected, I point out that improper interference with witnesses is declared by the resolution of 25 February 1988 to be a matter which the Senate may treat as contempt and is also a criminal offence under the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time Senator Reid asked me a question about alleged reduction in nutritional services because of staffing cuts in the Department of Community Services and Health. I am now in a position to answer that question. The Department of Community Services and Health is not reducing its priority for nutrition services. Nutrition is one of the five priority areas nominated in the better health program. This program is managed by the health advancement division of the Department of Community Services and Health. It is therefore sensible to amalgamate the work of the nutrition section with better health planning in nutrition within that division. While there will be some staff savings resulting from the amalgamation, the bringing together of better health activities in the nutrition area and the work of the nutrition section should lead to a more efficient and coordinated approach to the development of nutrition policies and programs within the Department. In summary, the proposed staff movements are essentially the result of organisational change to produce a more efficient bureaucracy while at the same time maintaining the Government's commitment to the nutrition services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 September I replied to a question from Senator Dunn relating to assurances about nuclear weapon accident liability. In giving that answer I pointed out:

ANSWER.PARA: Any claims for compensation resulting from a nuclear weapons accident would be dealt with through diplomatic channels in accordance with customary procedures for the settlement of claims under generally accepted principles of law and equity.

Furthermore, in the case of the United States, I referred to settlement of claims taking place in accordance with article 12 of the agreement between Australia and the United States concerning the status of United States forces in Australia. I have since had drawn to my attention that this description of claims procedures derives from discussions between Australian and United States officials in 1976 following a request by the then Australian Government for an assurance regarding liability in the event of an accident involving a nuclear weapon that might be carried on a United States warship visiting Australia. The advice about procedures given to the Australian Government by the Government of the United States is the same kind of assurance regarding visiting warships as it has given to the governments of Canada, New Zealand and other allies. Details of the assurance are classified. As I made clear in my earlier reply, the question of assurances relating to the stationing of nuclear weapons on Australian territory does not arise.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 September Senator Hill asked me about subsidies paid to non-government business colleges. I am now able to provide the honourable senator with the following information supplied by Mr Dawkins's office. As part of the recent Budget deliberations, the Government examined the position of private business colleges and decided to phase out subsidies for these institutions. Such courses are available in public institutions such as schools and technical and further education colleges. Providing the subsidy for only a limited range of private courses was inequitable and anomalous.
—But they are not always available; that is the point. Furthermore, you need different qualifications to get there.

—Perhaps Senator Hill can wait until I finish. Subsidised courses included those which were both substandard and out of step with modern office practices. The decision to discontinue the subsidy scheme from 1989 is consistent with the Government's policy on private higher education institutions set out in the White Paper. Students likely to be dependent on Austudy will have alternative courses available to them. Their opportunity for further study need not be curtailed. Of the 55 colleges only two are in rural centres. Other non-metropolitan colleges, of which there are 10, are in centres which have other further educational opportunities, for example, Newcastle, Toowoomba and Geelong. All existing eligible students will continue to be subsidised up to December 1988. Those who started courses before 23 August 1988 will be subsidised in 1989. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training is currently reviewing the situation of students enrolled to commence courses in January 1989 and to whom colleges had already made a commitment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by-leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware of the Parliament's initiative in regard to parliamentary education and of the work of its officers in preparing the two parliamentary education kits. These kits, one for primary students and one for secondary students, have now been distributed to all schools in Australia. I am pleased to inform the Senate that the primary school kit, called The Parliament Pack, has won an award for the best multi-media educational package of 1988. The award, given by the Australian Society for Education Technology, is especially pleasing, given that the Parliament's schools kit was competing against resource and training material prepared by experienced and well-known media organisations.

INTERJECT.PARA: I am sure that honourable senators will be gratified by this success and by the encouragement it has given to officers of the Parliamentary Education Office. They are currently working on schools based and parliament based projects to reinforce the success of the schools kits and to ensure that the role and the work of the Parliament are more effectively presented in the nation's classrooms. As a parliament we are committed to improving the quality and extent of parliamentary education for the future benefit of Australia and its democratic process and I know all senators will join me in congratulating the Parliamentary Education Office on this recognition of its important work.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation in response to an inaccurate and misleading report concerning me which appeared in today's edition of the Launceston Examiner newspaper. The article by Mr Barry Prismall, and based on comments made by the Tasmanian Deputy Premier, Mr Pearsall, sets out a grossly distorted and damaging picture of my personal housing arrangements in my home town of Burnie. The facts of the matter are that I have made several approaches to the Tasmanian Housing Department seeking to buy the departmental unit my wife and I occupy. This morning, in a conversation with the Tasmanian Minister for Housing, Mr John Beswick, I repeated that offer to buy. My previous requests had been rejected because the unit is one of six on a common title. Mr Beswick, in our conversation this morning, agreed that there were barriers in allowing the sale, and undertook to look at the situation again. Mr Pearsall, in making the statement yesterday, is guilty of the worst kind of gutter politics.
—Order! Senator Devlin, when making a personal explanation you must not criticise; just correct.

—I withdraw that comment. His assertion that I can and should buy the property ignores the fact that I have attempted to do precisely that, and overlooks the difficulties which his own ministerial colleague acknowledges. I have occupied the same unit for approximately 12 years, eight of those years before entering Parliament as a senator for Tasmania. Just like other Tasmanian citizens, I joined the waiting list for a Housing Department unit as a normal wage earner. At the time I was working on the Burnie waterfront. I was allocated the unit when my turn came, I have paid rent for the past 12 years like any other tenant, and unless permitted to buy I will continue to pay whatever the Department decrees is an appropriate rental. During my 12 years' occupancy of the unit I have made a number of improvements and maintained the property in excellent condition. Mr Beswick has been made personally aware of this and of my desire to buy the property. I am disappointed that Mr Pearsall has allowed his ignorance of the facts and the desire to score political points to produce an inaccurate and offensive attack on my family and me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time Senator Walsh was uncharitable enough to reflect indirectly on my motive for opposing a tax on gold. My motive and position in respect of a tax on gold is identical to that of the Premier of Western Australia, Mr Peter Dowding, the Deputy Premier of Western Australia, Mr David Parker, and, as at the last Federal election, that of the Prime Minister, Mr Robert J. L. Hawke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report marks the retirement of Professor Ralph Slatyer as Chairman of the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC). Also, during 1987-88 Dr Tegart took over as Secretary and Professor Martin as Chairman. I believe that the report shows that they have attacked their jobs this year in a very businesslike way. They have endeavoured through their four-theme program to make provision for the future. The first of the four headings that they chose is the health of Australian science. I would have to query whether this is healthy or not. The second heading is the role of science and technology in the economic and social development of Australia; the third is the management of technological change, the fourth is international trends and their relationship to science and technology. I would like to read out a passage from page 6 of the report:
There is reason to believe that in several key areas there are deficiencies in this core capacity.
The report is talking about the capabilities of science. It continues:

The provision of adequate funding to maintain and develop the capacity has long been an issue of concern. There may now be a need for a substantial program to renew or replace existing facilities and equipment that has become obsolete and for additional trained personnel.

It was brought to our attention last night when we were examining the estimates of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) that the capital expenditure for that body this year, next year and the following year has been cut by 50 per cent of what it was last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can say that at any time in the CSIRO's history, if you want to. You know that. It was four times the capital amount when they were building the animal health laboratory at Geelong.

—The Minister is welcome to participate in the debate later, if he wishes. But, in the meantime, it does not do any good to pretend that there has not been a 50 per cent cut this year compared with last year in respect of the capital equipment allocation for the CSIRO as well as cuts in operating costs. ASTEC is the main body of advice to the Government-via the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-on science and research and development policy formulation.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators can see from what I have said that ASTEC has joined virtually every other reputable scientific or research and development body in Australia in raising the issue of the general inadequacy of government funding and our slow and sure decline in world ratings.

The management of technological change, as proposed by theme three, raises some very important issues. Mention is made of agricultural chemicals, the ozone layer depletion and the greenhouse effect. But what has not yet been said and what the Government has not come to grips with is who is going to coordinate these massive problems. No coordinating authority has yet been set up in Australia to discuss or lead in respect of the greenhouse effect. Bodies such as the CSIRO's Division of Oceanography and the Division of Atmospheric Research, the Bureau of Meteorology, the Australian Institute of Marine Science and the University of Flinders are all doing work independently. They discuss their work with one another. But the Government has done nothing to coordinate in any way a problem of this massive nature. I believe it is time that the Government decided who is going to do it and to get it organised. As the major science and research and development policy formulation and advisory body in Australia, I hope that the advice that ASTEC has given to the Government will at least be read carefully and accepted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to hear the remarks of Senator Archer because I will certainly be seeking that the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology take up the matter of the greenhouse effect in relation to the restructuring of Australian industry. In addressing my remarks to the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) report, I draw attention to the fact-not surprisingly when one looks at the composition of ASTEC-that not surprisingly and rather unthinkingly ASTEC has accepted much of the Government rhetoric. On page 14 of the report we find that one of the matters it is necessary for ASTEC is to address is the matter of increasing international competitiveness. On page 6 we find that what is required is the achievement of sustained economic growth. That is an oxymoron. It is depressing to find that an organisation which should be about taking a much broader view than the government and advising government is accepting without question many of these unthinking directions in which the Government is unthinkingly attempting to push the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: If we want to make people more competitive I would remind the Senate that there are in several laboratories around the world massive attempts to totally describe the human genome. There are approximately 1,000 million bases in the human genome. Shortly, next century, that code will probably be totally described. We will know the total sequence of the human genome. Then, if we want to, we will be able to make people more competitive by genetic engineering. To unquestionably accept the idea that people should be made the instruments of economic indicators is to deny the basic premise of any sensible morality in our society-that is, that the government must be about making sensible choices. People are not and should not be made the instruments of economic indicators to be manipulated simply to make the economy grow or to make us more or less competitive.

It is interesting to find on page 11 of the report that in comparison with different countries Australia is doing very poorly as measured by the science citation index. We are the lowest in earth and space research, second lowest in biomedical research, lowest in physics, and second lowest in mathematics. Having said that, I believe it is important to return to the point that, if as a society we continue to become more technically and socially complex and at the same time wish to retain, and hopefully enhance, processes of participatory democratic decision making, we must constantly achieve higher levels of broad education, producing citizens with a well-integrated understanding of these technical and social processes and interactions. The obverse of having a tenured position in a university, protected from the self-serving and job-threatening recriminations of either private industry or government, is the responsibility of holding before society an informed and critical appraisal of that society, its decisions, directions, processes and, importantly, its consequences. I do not believe that universities-and this applies to this report-have discharged this social responsibility as well as they might. To an extent a better fulfilment of this role in the past may have led to greater community support for the universities in their present hour of need.

Comparing this approach to one important role of universities with the Government's thrust for greater economic relevance and the thrust of this report, honourable senators will appreciate my very great concern over the latter. We may well produce more narrowly trained whiz-bang engineers who will come up with more profitably competitive engines, but will there be those in sufficient numbers and with sufficient social prominence to raise the questions and inform the public about the social and environmental consequences of the application of these new technologies? Will the public be well enough educated to take these increasingly complex questions on board and make informed and caring decisions about them? If the Government has its way and if ASTEC, as indicated by this report, has its way, I am sure that the answer will be no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment briefly on the section of the report of the Australian Science and Technology Council relating to a study initiated this year by ASTEC dealing with the quality and potential of basic scientific research in Australia and entitled `The Profile of Australian Science'. I notice that in that section of the paper ASTEC provided figures for the amount spent in Australia on basic research for 1984-85. I will quote those figures briefly. In that year, Australia spent over $600m on basic research. Universities spent just over 50 per cent of this total; the Commonwealth Government 35 per cent; the States and private non-profit institutions about 5 per cent each; and private industry about 2.5 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats are deeply concerned about the continuing low level of funding for research in general but, most particularly, the diminishing funds available for basic research. When one looks at the amount spent on basic research by private industry-that is, 2.5 per cent-I believe that industry needs to become more involved in basic research. Of course, industry is often not interested in fundamental basic research. I quote from a comment made by a representative of Ciba-Geigy Australia Ltd which quote I also used when expressing concern during the debate on plant variety rights in February 1987. The representative of that major corporation said:

I see research divided into the discovery phase, and the exploitation phase. I believe that most of the discovery work in plant breeding such as genetic resistance to disease . . . will continue in public institutions. Conversely, I believe that the exploitation of the research can best be done by private enterprise.

As I said at the time, I believe that this amounts to a public subsidy of private enterprise, whereby private enterprise pulls in the dollars at the end of that exploitation phase. This critical issue of funding for fundamental and basic research was drawn to my attention again recently in a letter from Professor Lovett of the University of New England in Armidale, a person with whom I am frequently in correspondence on agricultural research in particular and on research into land degradation and alternatives in agriculture. Professor Lovett expressed very strong concern in his letter and stated:
For sound commercial reasons, however-
in relation to achieving funding for research from private industry-
they are not interested in funding the more basic research from which application and commercialisation ultimately flow.

We must bear in mind that comment from one of our very important agricultural researchers in academia. I know that the Government is also concerned about this question. An article in today's Age newspaper expresses that concern. The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, Mr Barry Jones, is quoted quite extensively in the article, which points out that, despite incentives, including the 150 per cent tax concession for such expenditure, private industry expenditure is still unacceptably low. On behalf of the Australian Democrats I express that concern as a result of the annual report of ASTEC, particularly in terms of fundamental research in primary industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on the report so I seek leave to continue my remarks on the next General Business Thursday.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Science and Technology Council Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I support this report. So many of its recommendations have continually been stressed by the Opposition. As a senator who holds the title of Queensland's fisherman of the year-a title bestowed on me by the commercial fishermen of Queensland-I have many times brought fishing industry issues before the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did you get the title for, though?

—For disallowing a regulation that your Government brought up that would have wrecked the fishing industry. I have many times urged the Government to do something to encourage the development of our magnificent renewable and export earning marine resources. Once again, we have another report which backs the call for measures to develop our offshore fisheries. This report accepts that most established fisheries are now exploited at or near their maximum capacity. Pressures for structural adjustment within the industry are growing. The disparity between the fact that Australia imports over 60 per cent of its seafood and yet has thousands of kilometres of coastline and 8.6 million square kilometres of sea serves to show how little this Government has done, despite urging from the industry and various committee recommendations, to assist the Australian fishing industry to take its rightful place in the international marketplace. As well as encouraging fisheries research and value added processing, including marketing, the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) stresses the need for development of a fishing fleet with on-board processing capacity, willing and able to work in our deep waters, in isolated fisheries and outside the 200-mile zone.

SPEECH.PARA: The potential for import replacement offered by these undeveloped fisheries must be explored. The dependence on limited products and limited markets makes it imperative for the Australian industry to explore options for increasing export opportunities. In 1987-88 the value of export of fisheries products was $775m, making fish the fourth most valuable Australian rural export. As the report correctly states:

Further increases in export earnings will assist Australia's balance of trade. Development of new products and new markets may also create, directly and indirectly, employment opportunities, and some of these will be in regional areas where unemployment is highest.

With regard to the contentious issue of foreign involvement in the fishing industry, ASTEC clearly states that increasing levels of foreign involvement in the catch and processing sectors of the fishing industry require further careful assessment. It observed that foreign capital was becoming increasingly available. If overseas countries can take an interest in our resource and profit handsomely from it, why is this Government not doing more to promote Australian fishing interests? This Government even now is negotiating with the Russians to allow them into our ports and waters. The Government is, in effect, discriminating against Australian fishermen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't talk twaddle, Senator.

—Well, it is. The report notes that there was strong support from industry representatives and from many government officers for facilitating access to Australian venture capital for fishing industry enterprises. The report also supports the recent Industries Assistance Commission recommendation urging that restrictions placed on importing second-hand fishing vessels be lifted in order to allow the fishing industry to extend its operations into new waters. Again, the question is whether the Government will listen to its own advice.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past various measures were aimed at assisting Australian fishermen to modify their existing boats. There have been financial incentive schemes, Australianisation of foreign operations, and training provisions to equip our own people to explore and farm our marine resources. It is my sincere hope that this time the Government will do something about it for, as this paper says, larger vessels are essential for exploration of fisheries outside the Australian fishing zone and within the 200-mile area, and facilitating access for the Australian fishing industry to vessels capable of fishing such waters is important for industry development. At the moment Australian producers are disadvantaged in comparison with foreign vessels in terms of access to certain fisheries within our waters. The scope for growth of on-board processing needs to be further examined, and a program of upgrading existing vessels in some fisheries to include processing capacity may be appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not yet read the full report of the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC), but have read enough of it to see that it is another valuable unit in trying to increase the productivity of Australia's primary industries. The fishing industry has my great respect because there is no group in society that works harder under more difficulties, with more ups and downs and more uncontrollable issues to contend with than fishermen. We have to see that fishermen are adequately rewarded for what they do and we have to ensure that at all costs we preserve the resource. The best way to see that the fishermen can continue to make a living is to see that they get the best price possible for the product they currently handle. This is exactly what this volume is all about. It is an excellent project for ASTEC to be involved in.

SPEECH.PARA: What surprises me is that its annual report, which the Senate has just dealt with, lists all the projects on which the Council was working and mentions all the reports it hopes to do this year and next year, but did not include this report. I do not know when the report suddenly sprung up, but it is a volume of some consequence. I hope that it will be read by the widest possible range of people in the fishing industry. It concerns me that it is now nearly 10 years ago that the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce conducted an inquiry into the fishing industry and a considerable amount of the material in that report is now repeated in the present report. This goes to show that, in spite of the fact that we recognised the difficulties as long ago as that, very little has been done about the matter since then. I hope that we will not have to wait another 10 years before something is likely to happen. There has been a lot of change in the industry over that time, particularly on the organisational and catching sides. I give ground on the fact that it was probably necessary for those areas to be improved first during that time. However, I look forward to seeing our better handling of the product and our use of the best technology. We must take on the issue of quality assurance and presentation and see that we utilise all the facilities that are available to make the industry better.

The volume recommends better records, greater coordination and communication, better research, the development of quarantine and other procedures, by-product investigation and cooperative ventures. A lot of that will require changes, particularly to our attitude towards foreign fishing-onshore and offshore processing, the requirements on foreign fishing to process portions or all of its catch in Australia, and matters such as that. The facilities that are now available, including plant and equipment, for freezing and handling fish, are ever so much better than they were in the past, and I believe that we can increase considerably the status of fishing in our national Budget. I notice that the report states that last year Australian fisheries' production was valued at $850m and that fishing was the fifth most important rural industry in terms of value of production. I think that the industry can do a lot better than that. We ought to be looking at at least another 50 per cent in the next few years. This will involve our looking after the resource more carefully than we have in the past. As this chamber knows, we have been looking at the tuna question in the last month or so. I hope that we will not get into a situation with any other species as we have with tuna.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wonder why the Commonwealth Grants Commission believes that it is necessary to duplicate the work of the Local Government Grants Commission, in Queensland, which tours the State, inspects the shires to establish any disabilities which they might have, particularly in the far-flung parts of our State, and then brings in its report. This year I read in our local paper, the South Burnett Times, of how the State Grants Commission had recommended $71,000 less for South Burnett shires than they received last financial year. The Federal Government at that time had not accepted the Commission's recommendations and, as in 1987-88, decided the allocations itself.

The Chairman of the Murgon Shire Council-one of the councils in South Burnett-Councillor Bill Roberts, said it was disappointing that, when councils prepared budgets on their 1987-88 figures, expecting a quarter share grant payment by 15 August, the Federal Government did not accept the figures proposed by the State Local Government Grants Commission. It would appear to me that the Queensland Local Government Grants Commission would prepare a more valid report than the Commonwealth, which does it from its own office, through its own consultant whom it asks to prepare another list of grants to councils. There is no doubt that making grants in this way places all councils in a dilemma. To say that they would all be confused would be an understatement of some magnitude.

Local authorities were to be informed of Commonwealth grants by 15 August, but the councils were at least five weeks late in being advised. I had wanted to ask a question in the Senate about the delay in advising councils of their Commonwealth grants allocations but was unable to get the call for a question at that time. During the parliamentary recess the local government authorities were finally advised of their allocations by the Government. There is no doubt that the delay by the Commonwealth in forwarding official advice of grants to councils makes it very difficult for local authorities to budget. These Commonwealth grants are to make up the leeway while councils wait for revenue to come in. As honourable senators can imagine, councils budget for an anticipated grant from the Commonwealth Grants Commission. Each year it seems to be getting less.

Another problem for councils now is that the Commonwealth gives only one-quarter of the allocated amount in August, or five weeks later as happened this year, whereas once the whole amount was given to local authorities and they could invest it and obtain interest. Now the Commonwealth Government keeps the money for itself and invests it. I suppose with the financial problems that this Government is having with its foreign debt and balance of payments it is no wonder it has to resort to mean tricks like not giving the local authorities their grants in one lump sum. What I fail to understand is why, when the agreement between the Federal and State governments on allocating local government's share of personal income tax required the assessment work to be done by a grants commission, the Commonwealth Government does not accept the assessments provided by the local authorities State Grants Commission in Queensland. No doubt there was a problem between the Commonwealth and the Queensland State Government over the allocations, for the two governments again appear to have failed to reach an agreement, although the State Government in Queensland has made some amendments to the system used by the Commission in deciding grants.

The way the money is decided and the delay caused by the Commonwealth has disadvantaged a lot of outback local authorities in our State. I think they have enough problems with severe droughts without the disadvantages I have outlined. These problems do not arise to the same extent in the big cities. Perhaps that is because votes are where the people are. Is it any wonder that councils view with concern the late notification of their annual grants and the confusion over the future role of the State Grants Commission if the Federal Government persists in distributing grants?
Question resolved in the affirmative.
