SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to continue the remarks that were made the other day on the report Manufacturing Industry Revitalisation: Making it Together by the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. I wish to add a couple of points to the comments he made. This report is a result of endless discussions with government, industry and trade union officials attempting to achieve a coherent list of recommendations with an aim to improving the efficiency and future prospects of the manufacturing industry. It must be noted that the time of the hearings was considered to be a period of a significant downturn in agricultural and mining markets. Therefore, the manufacturing industry would have to be relied upon as a saviour of the Australian economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Times have changed and we are now experiencing a boom in agricultural commodity prices and a relatively promising outlook for the mining industry. Nevertheless, the manufacturing industry is still in crisis. We are currently involved in a major recession in the manufacturing industry. It is necessary to reverse this declining trend and to move speedily along the road to recovery. The downturn in manufacturing production raises doubts about the competitiveness of the sector with the Australian Bureau of Statistics recently releasing figures showing a fall in production for the industry of 2.5 per cent for the June quarter. That is of considerable concern to all members of this chamber.

One of our recommendations was that manufacturing bodies must continue to encourage employees to undergo further training, either on the job or externally, through our efficient system of technical and further education colleges or universities and to increase their knowledge of improvements in technology and other aspects so as to benefit the industry as a whole. As patron of the Work Skills Australia Foundation for northern New South Wales I believe that participants in the Skill Olympics must continue to be given the public recognition that is due to them. In talking about further training for people in the manufacturing industries, I should point out that that competition covers some 42 skilled occupations in vehicle and automotive engineering, metal building and construction, electrical, hospitality and service industries. As a voluntary testing service it presents to young people an opportunity for reward and an incentive for the achievement of excellence. This is something that the manufacturing industries must strive for.

Careers in the manufacturing industry must be depicted and promoted as sound and rewarding. I notice that there are a lot of young people in the gallery at the moment. I am quite sure that they would be happy to enter the manufacturing industry if it could offer them a rewarding future and a career path. That is one of the other problems we found when looking at the manufacturing industry. Sometimes there was not a career path to pursue for people of the quality and age who are now leaving the chamber.

There must also be serious action taken to rectify the catastrophic situation on our waterfronts which is severely hindering the growth of industry. Only a few weeks ago industrial chaos erupted on the waterfront bringing all cargo traffic in Sydney ports to a standstill. It is interesting to note that the recent Industries Assistance Commission report on coastal shipping has identified that the industry is costing users in the proximity of some $450m per year. With the present over-regulated and militant union control of coastal shipping and the waterfront situation it is cheaper to ship cars from Melbourne to Japan than to ship cars from Melbourne to Tasmania. I am disgusted to admit that the higher costs and poor record of service have progressively reduced the industry to a position where the only goods currently shipped around the coast tend to be those for which alternative transport either is not available or does not represent a realistic proposition. The inefficiency and corruption particularly prevalent at Sydney ports and container depots is adding hundreds of thousands, probably millions, of dollars a year to the cost of imports and exports.

One of the other recommendations in the report is that the Government should provide leadership and consistent policies in pursuit of a clear national objective. In that regard I mention people in the manufacturing industry who now see rising interest rates caused by government intervention, in what is meant to be a free market, in order to hold the value of the dollar, as is causing problems for the manufacturing industry too. Really, there is not the leadership or consistency of policies for the manufacturing industry which we would like to see. I believe that the Australian manufacturing industry has the capacity to restore its international competitiveness. I hope that, with serious consideration of the issues raised and the application of the recommendations of this report, a positive outcome will result sooner and not later.

Other points in the report that I would like to highlight relate to the industrial relations side of manufacturing industry revitalisation. The report suggests that we have more individual company agreements. I think that that has to be looked on much more favourably than it has been in the past. Hopefully, some of the work practices that are now being fixed up in the Australian coalmining industry can also be fixed up in the industrial relations area of manufacturing industry. Another point that we made was that, in particular, management should aim for conciliation rather than confrontation. We suggest that management should introduce rewards for higher productivity. Of course, productivity is the key to profitability in manufacturing industries, as it is in a lot of other industries.

We also suggest that labour take positive steps to improve its situation. In particular, we say that the labour force should aim for conciliation rather than confrontation. Would it not be nice if that were always the case on the shop floor rather than having demarcation disputes, stand-downs or interruptions of production? We suggest that the labour force should take the lead in negotiating the removal of restrictive work and management practices. We also suggest that the labour force accept that it may not always be possible to give precedence to the maintenance of wages and the protection of specific jobs. Of course, that is what has happened with the mechanisation of many of our manufacturing industries that want to compete with our Asian neighbours and countries in other parts of the world.

We have suggested, in regard to the work and factory organisation side of things, that no single aspect of manufacturing industry revitalisation offers tangible results more quickly than does the reorganisation of the manufacturing systems. Some of the factories we visited around Australia demonstrated a need to look at some of the new systems put in place by some of the more successful manufacturers. I refer to the just in time policy of not carrying too much stock on the floor. Industries that have adopted those practices have definitely kept up with the times.

We also recommended that the Commonwealth Government's direct expenditure on research and development through the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and other agencies be maintained and, where possible, increased. Of course, that subject has been brought up here today in references to the cutback in funding for the CSIRO. It is of concern to me that the Government has not continued to increase funding for research and development in a vital part of Australia's industry, the manufacturing industry, which is needed to help all Australians to enjoy a better way of life and a better standard of living. If we could get the manufacturing industries to the stage of replacing a lot of imports we would solve some of our balance of payments problems. We have just had two months over which there was a $2.9 billion balance of payments deficit. We are likely to see a $1.2 billion deficit for the month of September.
I commend this report to the Senate. I hope that the manufacturing industries grasp the nettle to help all Australians enjoy a better standard of living.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that honourable senators will have noticed that as a member of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, which inquired into certain aspects of Australia's manufacturing industry revitalisation, I wrote a minority report. It was not that I found a great deal wrong with the major report, except that it really did not go far enough. It was, to use a mathematical expression, a necessary set of conditions but not a sufficient set of conditions to ensure a really human and humane society in the future. It is true that we need to make industry a great deal more efficient; nobody would agree with that at all. But the questions of where that industry is to be directed, how it is to be directed and so on were largely left out of consideration by the Committee. The prevailing view, both in the Government and the Opposition and in the Committee, was that that should be left to market forces and that the direction of society should be directed towards the economic benefits of industry.

SPEECH.PARA: In my minority report I quoted from J. K. Galbraith's book The New Industrial State which, interestingly, was written in the late 1960s. That books seem to me to tell us a great deal about the state of our society today. It makes one feel very sad that we have not moved on from that understanding; rather, we have moved backwards. Galbraith wrote then:

If we continue to believe that the goals of the industrial system-the expansion of output, the companion increase in consumption, technological advance, the public images that sustain it-are coordinate with life, then all of our lives will be in the service of these goals. What is consistent with these ends we shall have or be allowed; all else will be off limits. Our wants will be managed in accordance with the needs of the industrial system; the policies of the state will be subject to similar influence; education will be adapted to industrial need; the disciplines required by the industrial system will be the conventional morality of the community.

It seems to me that in the Australian Science and Technology Council annual report, which was discussed only a short time ago this afternoon, one finds a similar expression of the narrowing of the goals of society towards the perceived economic needs of industry.

Elsewhere in my minority report I drew attention to the 1972 Stockholm Conference on the human environment. After that conference the Swedish Government established a commission for the future. One hoped that when the Australian Commission for the Future was established it might have been modelled on that Swedish pattern; but, unfortunately, that proved not to be the case. The Swedish body is independent of government. It contains a research unit and opens up for public debate options for the future. Information is supplied to the public on where certain courses of action are likely to lead. The public can then decide whether that is where it wants to be 25 or 50 years into the future. The commission can then help in outlining what present actions need to be taken to ensure that those desirable objectives are approached and that undesirable outcomes are avoided.

Interestingly, in relation to what our present Government regards as long term planning, the Swedish Commission has a mid-term horizon of 15 to 25 years and a long term horizon of 25 to 40 years. The processes in which it involves the public in decision making concern the public's own future. Therefore, it produces both a better educated population and a population more committed to bringing that future into existence. It also sets long term guidelines within which industry can develop. It is recognised that industry development is simply a subset of overall social development. This is the point that is missing in the major report of the Industry, Science and Technology Committee. It is notable that Sweden is performing much better than Australia, both socially and economically. One cannot help but contrast this approach with that of the present Government, of the present Opposition and of the majority report. Market directed, growth-oriented mechanisms are to be the approach, and where that may lead Australian society and Australian manufacturing is anyone's guess. People are to be part of the mechanism, but as pawns to be manipulated not as decision makers and ultimate beneficiaries of processes and goals that they have chosen for themselves.

I shall refer to several examples to indicate the differences that would result from this alternative approach. Fossil fuel, which has been mentioned several times today with respect to the greenhouse effect, is used principally as an electricity generating fuel. Its production is a factor measured in the gross domestic product, and in a growth-oriented economy the increased production of coal will be seen as a benefit. In a market-driven economy effort will be put into finding ways of selling more coal. This is exactly what is being experienced at present. There have also been attempts to streamline the mining, transport and marketing of coal. The recent annual report of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) places increasing emphasis on these market imperatives. For instance, the CSIRO's strategic plan for 1988-92 states:

Coal is a vital contributor to Australia's exports and domestic electricity supplies. CSIRO research aims to reduce production costs and improve the range and efficiency of coal use through work on exploration, mining, product quality control, handling, fuel conversion and pollution.

But coal is also a major source of carbon dioxide, and that, as we all know, leads to greenhouse warming and a number of other consequential effects. It follows that in a sensible society, if we intend to tackle this problem comprehensively and take into account the long lead times required for alternative technologies, we would be putting a great deal of research not into coal development but into energy efficiency and alternative energy sources. Such a society would not be solely market driven but would be taking the longer view.

For similar reasons, one can criticise the Button car plan. The formulation of that plan paid no attention to the emerging desirability of conserving fossil fuel. Fossil fuel adds to carbon dioxide in the atmosphere and is a non-renewable resource, and Australia's supplies of liquid fuel are very limited. We have been told that by 1991 Australia will have to import some $3 billion worth of oil each year. Instead of responding to the short term market forces, if that plan had responded to these longer term indicators, Australia would have developed different types of cars. It is significant that out of the Button car plan the latest Holden has a four-litre engine with an optional five-litre engine. In its advertisements, the company is claiming that that car will take it through the 1990s. That is totally out of keeping with the real needs as perceived by today's society.

Whatever the shape and structure of Australian industry, it is desirable that manufacturing be efficient. That is necessary but is not a sufficient condition. To address the long term needs of society requires that society take a longer term and comprehensive view of fossil futures and then direct its energies, including those of its manufacturing industry, towards agreed goals. This is not happening, and nothing in this report will cause it to happen.

Unless we lift our gaze and broaden our view in a period of rapid change, we will forever be developing technical solutions to last year's problems. We will become a society lacking direction and increasingly despondent over our own predicament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time I have available to speak on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, entitled Manufacturing Industry Revitalisation: Making It Together, I want to give credit to some of the people who have been involved in bringing the report to the floor of the Senate. Before I do so, I wish to comment on the title Making it Together-something we all aim for and strive for in life. That is a commendable objective in life, and the theme of this report, above anything else, is to bring the three major partners involved in manufacturing industry in this country-government, employers and workers-together, to make it together for the benefit of Australia. The stylised cover of the report portrays that goal we should be aiming for.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had an unfortunate start in attaining the objective. The unfortunate start is the minority report that has been just spoken to by Senator Coulter. It would have been better if the Committee had brought down a majority report, but one can understand that individuals need to bring down minority reports from time to time. I make the point at this stage that Senator Coulter is a relatively new member of the Committee. He joined the Committee after the bulk of its work, including submissions, meeting with witnesses and public hearings, had been completed. The theme of the inquiry was well and truly set in concrete by the time the good senator joined the Committee.

Therefore, there was some expectation that new senators who became members of the Committee would not necessarily be au fait with every aspect of the investigation. I recognise that members of the Committee, who represent all political parties in this chamber, have different views. The Committee sought, as much as was possible, to accommodate each of those views. But it is difficult to reach that accommodation when the objectives are already set in concrete and when individual senators are often unable to attend every meeting of the Committee to argue through their points. That is perhaps one area where Senator Coulter may have missed out. He may have been better able to forcefully put his view and obtain some accommodation of that view in the Committee's report. The Committee's investigations commenced following a reference by the Senate on 13 June 1986, so it was well and truly under way by the time the good senator joined the Committee.

In commending other members of the Committee, I particularly commend the work undertaken by Senator Childs, the Chairman of the Committee. Senator Childs attended each and every meeting of the Committee and as an individual undertook a lot of background work that is not, and cannot be, recognised because this is a committee report. If the credit for the report can be individualised, it must go to Senator Childs because he did a lot of work on his own, above and beyond the demands of being a member of the Committee.

I commend each of the other senators from all political parties who were members of the Committee. Those members have ideological and philosophical differences of opinion, but we were able to sit down in amicable surroundings, not only during hearings and meetings in Parliament House but also in the various forums throughout Australia, as the Committee visited a number of capital cities.

Many other people also require commendation. I mention first of all the support staff, including Mr Peter Keele, who was the secretary of the Committee until 26 November 1987. He was later replaced by Ms Ann Stewart on 17 December 1987. Those people, together with the additional research staff, contributed an enormous amount to the report and in bringing it to this stage. A lot of work still must be done in this area, and I shall make some brief comments on the content of the report. In our introductory chapters to the report we examined where Australia was at. One very interesting point in the usage of statistics comes from page 10 of the report: we examined the position of Australia's manufacturing industry as it is at present relative to what it had been in previous years. A couple of statistics help to illustrate the point that I want to make:
The percentage of Australia's work force employed in manufacturing industry fell from 26 per cent in 1966-67 to 16.2 per cent in 1986-87.
That is a dramatic decline. To continue:
Manufacturing industries share of GDP in 1986-87 was 17 per cent, compared with 25 per cent-
that is 20 years previously-

It is a bit of a gloom and doom story when one looks at statistics such as that, but it is not totally doom and gloom. The reason it is not totally gloom and doom is that in March 1983 the people of Australia elected a Labor government to office. They have re-elected it on two occasions since then. Our Government has turned the situation around very well. For example, production levels in the manufacturing sector have increased by 20 per cent since the 1980 trough when this Government came to office. An increase of 20 per cent is not something to be sneezed at, but it is not something that we can relax on because a lot of work has got to be done, and hopefully that 20 per cent will be increased to 120 per cent.

Production in the manufacturing sector is at record levels at the moment. It was 5.3 per cent higher in the last financial year, 1987-88, compared to the previous year. Manufacturing sales are expected to grow by 9.4 per cent this current financial year. Manufacturing exports, which above everything else are what the theme of the report is about, were 16 per cent higher in the three months to August 1988 than in the same period in 1987. In August alone manufacturing exports rose by 4 per cent in that month. That is something we can really build upon. I think the message is getting through, thanks to the words of the Government and spokespersons such as the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button.

This is not something we can relax about, however, because there are many impediments to the redevelopment and revitalisation of the manufacturing industry in Australia. In this report, as much as we possibly could, we have sought to cover the whole range of the impediments that might be facing us. We have looked, in particular, at industrial relations. While not wishing to dwell on that at this point, it is a very important element in the revitalisation and redevelopment of Australia's manufacturing industry. One reason for those good figures I was able to enumerate a short while ago is that we have got relatively good industrial relations operating in the Australian workplace at the moment. As I said on a number of occasions, we cannot relax; it has to be built upon.

We have put a lot of emphasis on training and retraining as well, as indeed the major players are doing; and quite rightly so. It is a pity that that emphasis had not come about earlier. I commend the report to the Senate and to the other major players in the manufacturing sector in Australia-the captains of industry, trade union leaders, and others. They should have a look at it. I am certainly not saying that we have got all the answers here, but certainly this report contains a lot of food for thought and matters that can be digested. Hopefully, we can all pull it together and we can, indeed, make it together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to address some remarks to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology entitled Manufacturing Industry Revitalisation: Making it Together. Could I say at the outset, on Senator Chaney's behalf, that he would have been participating in this debate as well had not problems of his throat and laryngitis prevented him from doing so. He did want that point to be clearly made. I cannot speak for Senator Chaney, but I think that he would echo some of the remarks that I will be making today.

SPEECH.PARA: The report deals with a vitally important subject-the revitalisation of manufacturing industry. I was a member of the Committee in its early stages, but I have had no involvement over the last 12 months in the Committee's inquiry, having moved off the Committee. I was not heavily involved in the hearing of the evidence and had no involvement in the preparation of the report.

The inquiry took more than two years to complete. That is a long time. Things can become outdated whilst inquiries of that length are continuing. We have seen that from time to time with numerous reports of parliamentary committees. I think it is clear that that has happened on this occasion. The time involved was partly because the terms of reference were very wide ranging and, because they were wide ranging, the Committee spent a considerable time considering just which aspects of those very wide terms of reference it should deal with. I remind the Senate that the terms of reference were worded as follows:
Certain aspects of Australia's manufacturing industry revitalisation.

Those are very broad ranging terms of reference indeed. The Committee, quite rightly, took some time to think through that and to determine for itself which aspects of manufacturing industry as a whole it wanted to concentrate on. It had a lot of pre-hearings and took evidence from and had discussions with a very wide range of employers, unions and others involved before finally coming down to believing that, given that it did not want to re-invent the wheel and all the other numerous reports into this industry that have been undertaken over many years now, it would concentrate on a particular range of issues and, in particular, on the questions of attitudes towards manufacturing industry in Australia of employers, the work force and the community at large.

I think all of that added up to the report being overtaken by events and by the debate that has gone on in Australia in the last couple of years about the role and future of manufacturing industry and what ought to be done to revitalise it. To that extent, I think it is unfortunate-and it is not a criticism of the Committee-that the report comes out 2 1/4 years after the inquiry had first been conceived. As I say, that is not specific just to this report. I think that we should be looking at making more of our Senate committee inquiries shorter and more practically oriented. If we do not, then we can get involved in such a broad spectrum that we really produce nothing that is new and fresh. I think that this is an example of that.

While congratulating the Committee on its work and for producing a very comprehensive report, I must say that I do find it somewhat disappointing for some of the reasons that I have already mentioned, but also for others. For example, it contains many motherhood statements and conclusions. There seems to me not to be a lot that is new in the report. Perhaps that is not surprising, given that there have been many other studies of manufacturing industry over many years. As I said, the Committee tried to get around that problem by concentrating on the area of attitudes towards manufacturing. Perhaps, with hindsight, that in itself made it difficult to come up with hard edged conclusions and recommendations. I think we would all agree that, whilst attitudes are terribly important, their nature is such that it is hard to make specific hard edged recommendations about them. I congratulate the Committee on some of the recommendations it has made in that area, but it is a very difficult area in which to be specific. The question of attitudes is critically important to the future of manufacturing in this country, particularly in the area of education, because the future of manufacturing is going to depend on the type of people we get into the manufacturing sector.

Let me give the Senate an example of the sort of problem we have. I was told today of a group of Sydney school children who a couple of weeks ago were given a guided tour, at their teacher's request, of one of Sydney's most efficient and clean factories. At the end of the tour the teacher turned to the students and warned them that this was where they would finish up if they did not knuckle down at school. That is a very sad attitude, because manufacturing offers great scope and great opportunities for very rewarding and interesting employment. I think that is a good example of the attitudinal problems that exist in some sections of the community concerning manufacturing industry.

I think the report misses many of the real issues, in addition to attitudes, that need to be addressed. For example, in my view the report correctly diagnoses Australia's main economic problems-the record level of debt which is rapidly bankrupting this country, the huge current account deficit that seems to be incapable of being properly brought under control, and the nation's underlying lack of competitiveness. Many of those problems are of the Government's own making through economic mismanagement and policy decisions that have greatly damaged the fabric of Australian industry and the economy over recent years, but the report does not make many recommendations in this area. Although it diagnoses the problems, the real hard problems that need to be solved, those I have just mentioned, get lost in the broader context of the debate over attitudes and other such issues.

The report by and large comes down very heavily in favour of positive government intervention in the manufacturing sector, although that support is qualified by statements about the need to ensure cost effectiveness of programs, et cetera. It puts forward a basically prescriptive set of policy recommendations involving governments doing certain things across the gamut of manufacturing industry. I believe that is a fundamental problem with the report because, if we are to solve the problems of manufacturing industry in this country and really revitalise it, which I think everyone in this nation and certainly in this Parliament would agree is essential, we have to make our manufacturing industry more competitive, more hard edged, and more able to stand up for itself in a very highly competitive international environment. If we cannot adopt economic policies which enable it to do that, nothing that we do in the area of prescriptive measures for the manufacturing sector will solve its problems.

Again, I congratulate the Committee and its staff on the work they have done. I think the Committee has produced a report that is worthy of detailed consideration. It is a very useful addition to the Parliament's literature and thoughts in this area. I hope that we will give it the consideration it deserves but, as I say, I find it a disappointing report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a few brief remarks on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology entitled Manufacturing Industry Revitalisation: Making it Together. I wish particularly to make some remarks about the minority report put down by my colleague Senator Coulter. With all due respect to Senator McKiernan, his comments as a member of that Committee might be seen in some sense as devaluing that minority report. I refer in particular to his reference to the fact that Senator Coulter had become a member of the Committee relatively late, given that the Committee was set up with this reference in 1986 and that Senator Coulter did not come to this place until 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important to recognise that, as part of the democratic political process in this country, the people of this nation-thank goodness-quite often make changes to their representation in this place, and as a result there are changes in committee representation. I would not want, particularly on a broadcast day, any implication to be left hanging in the air that if a senator did not serve on a committee for its full length of time or did not attend every meeting of that committee, the contribution that senator might make would be of any less value. Indeed, of the whole of this report I find the minority report the most refreshing. As Senator Coulter said in his report, his dissatisfaction is not so much with what the report says but with those assumptions, which Senator McKiernan pointed out had been set in place before Senator Coulter actually joined the Committee. Senator Coulter subsequently found those assumptions to be unsatisfactory and chose to put down a minority report based on a holistic view of all of the elements of our activities as members not only of the Australian community but of the global community, and based on different assumptions about what is meant by development-industrial development in this case-and about the results of development.

As I have said, I find this minority report to be a fresh and courageous approach in the area of industrial development, one which is based on a very deep concern not just for the survival and development of industry in Australia but indeed for the survival of our whole planet. I think the points that Senator Coulter made in his speech earlier and which are made in his dissenting report are very important for all of us in a broader context but also in relation to industrial development in Australia, which was the brief of this Committee. That is not to say that the body of the report does not bring forward valuable insights. I simply want to underscore the fact that, late though Senator Coulter's election may have been in the context of this reference to the Committee-I point out that he made earlier attempts to become a member of the Senate-the insights which he has been advocating outside this Parliament for some decades have been brought to this Parliament and subsequently to the Committee by courtesy of the voters in the democratic system in Australia, particularly those of South Australia.

Not only do I find this minority report refreshing and quite inspiring, but also I have found the election of Senator Coulter to this place to have the same effect. I think it would be a pity if discussion on this report were to conclude leaving any cloud over the value of a minority report which is as important as this one. We are all concerned about the depletion of the ozone layer and the greenhouse effect, but some of us have held that concern for very much longer than the current public debate would indicate all too many people have held it. These are issues which must be borne in mind in all areas of our social and economic development, and that is a very strong point in this minority report, which I commend here today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Cooney, Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, I present the twelfth report of 1988 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills concerning the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1988 and Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988. I also lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 12 dated 12 October 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS BILL 1988INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1988

TALK.START.PARA: —Before lunch the Committee was considering the Industrial Relations Bill 1988 as a whole and amendment (32) moved by Senator Chapman on behalf of the Opposition. The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Chapman be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 131, after subclause 264 (6), add the following new subclause:

``(7) Where a member of an organisation has ceased to be eligible to become a member and has not, for a period of 12 months, paid membership subscriptions that the rules of the organisation require members to pay, the person shall be deemed to have resigned from membership.''.

This amendment is designed to facilitate the resignation of a member of an organisation who has left the job to which membership of that organisation relates. It provides that where a member of an organisation has ceased to be eligible to become a member of that organisation and has not, for a period of 12 months, paid membership subscriptions that the rules of the organisations require members to pay, the person shall be deemed to have resigned from membership. In that respect it picks up one aspect of amendment (32) which was the last amendment moved by the Opposition and which was not supported by the Committee. This further amendment would allow people who wish to remain members of the organisation they are no longer eligible to join to do so. A 12-month period of grace is provided to deal with seasonal workers who may work in a particular industry for only part of the year but who would normally retain their membership of the organisation. It would deal, however, with the situation of a person who has left a job without formally resigning his membership from the organisation in writing. We believe it is quite unfair to require him to do so. It is for this reason that we have moved this amendment. I believe it warrants the support of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the amendment. We appreciate the spirit of the amendment and the motives for it being moved by the Opposition. However, as is often the case, even though something may appear to be attractive on the face of it, there are some inherent problems with the proposition being put forward. In fact, the Government believes that quite a number of practical problems would emanate from an amendment such as this if it were passed. The amendment's main aim is to provide an automatic system of terminating membership of an organisation. It does this whether a member wants this to happen or not. Persons who may inadvertently forget to pay their subscriptions to organisations while they are away or for some other reason-as many of us often do-will have their membership interrupted.

SPEECH.PARA: On the face of it this may not appear to be much of a problem. But, as honourable senators involved in industrial relations may know, removing continuity of membership has consequent problems. For instance, qualifying periods for standing for office relate to continuity of membership. As well as that, rights of membership-rights to loans, grants, donations from the union, funeral benefits, legal services and so on-may depend on continuity of membership. So to have an automatic suspension of membership because of the circumstances encompassed by the amendment could cause problems for particular members who, as I said, may not want their membership to lapse.

That is the primary problem. There are, of course, other problems. By having such a mechanism we may in fact find problems in respect of voting in union ballots. For instance, although union membership may have elapsed, the union records may not have been consequently amended. Organisations could be involved in expensive legal proceedings because of the direct inflexible approach of the amendment put forward by the Opposition.

Eligibility of membership of an organisation is also something which is not very readily identifiable. In fact, the industrial law of this country is riddled with quite a number of cases of union members trying to organise within unions. Disputes can arise in regard to the eligibility of members within groups. As a consequence, an inflexible amendment, such as the one that is proposed, will have indirect effects on that regime of law and structure that is in place in the industrial system. All in all, therefore, the Government does not support the amendment.

Finally, I should say that the term `membership subscriptions' is in itself inherently flawed in that we do not know whether the Opposition means by this all payments or whether it includes levies, partial payments and so on. So there is that problem as well. But mainly for the reasons of inflexibility and the dire consequences that could in fact flow from an inflexible amendment such as this, the Government is not moved to support it even though we do appreciate the motives behind the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Chapman for raising this issue because it is a matter which is of concern not only to individual members of unions but also to unions themselves and, I have no doubt, employer organisations. The union movement tends to get a bad name when unions-and I have one in mind-attempt to chase people who have left the industry for back dues. I would think that most unions, most registered industrial organisations, take a realistic view of this situation. Clause 195(d) states:

SPEECH.PARA: shall require the organisation to inform applicants for membership, in writing, of:
(i) the financial obligations arising from membership; and
(ii) the circumstances, and the manner, in which a member may resign from the organisation.

Many people are involved in time consuming work and they may not always bear in mind what they were told when they made application for union membership. Of course, they may have made application many years previously. If they go out of their occupation they may think that they are not covered by the awards of the union which has coverage of the industry. Therefore, they may feel that they are not obliged to continue paying union dues.

Most unions, including the one to which I belong, treat union membership on a practical basis. Many unions have what are known as the purging rules. These rules enable the committee of management of a registered industrial organisation from time to time to purge its register of members who are no longer in the industry. My recollection is that under those circumstances the member concerned is advised that his name is going to be purged from the membership records. He is given the opportunity of responding to that advice.

The previous amendment proposed a period of six months. This amendment proposes 12 months. In answer to what the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) said, a member of an organisation may be interested in using the services offered by a union-for example, loans that may be made available. He may be interested in picking up his membership again after a period of 12 months. Seasonal workers, who may work for only three months, may want to remain members of an organisation. Clearly, the amendment which had a six months provision would not have covered that situation. Senator Chapman clearly understood the position and therefore changed the period to 12 months. In response to what the Minister said, 12 months seems to be adequate in that during that period a member who is interested in obtaining the services of a union or, indeed, standing for office or engaging in some other activity in respect of which he would need to maintain his continuity of membership, surely would be interested in making the appropriate payments.

However, I think this matter has been aired before the committee today. Again, I appreciate Senator Chapman raising the matter. This is a matter which is of pretty broad concern. Perhaps I will await any undertaking that might be given by the Government before I vote on the matter. This is a matter that should be of interest to the National Labour Consultative Committee, the employers and the unions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the point raised by Senator Chapman is a very important one. When I think back to the various unions of which I have been a member-truck drivers, storemen and packers, teachers and so forth-I cannot remember ever writing a letter to resign. Although the rules obviously require one to submit a written resignation, one assumes when one moves on that one does not need to pay any longer. I was just trying to think of some other instances.
—You might get an account next week.

—Yes, I probably will. One tends to move out of most of the organisations in the community to which one belongs by not paying rather than by actually sending a formal written resignation as is required by this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder whether the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) is able to inform the committee of whether or not that aspect was considered when the Bill was being drafted. The provisions in clause 264, to which an amendment has been moved, seem to suggest a level of involvement and understanding of the rules that I do not think are possessed by an ordinary member of any organisation. Senator Chapman alluded to the problem of a union actually pursuing someone for back pay of $400, $500, $600, $700, or whatever, when that person wishes to come back into an industry on the basis that he has always in fact been a member of the union. That proposition seems to be a bit steep. The possibility does not seem to exist of getting out of a union by simply not paying. That is the reading that I have of the clause. If that is not true, probably the problem is dissolved. If a person does not pay dues after the three-month period that is mentioned in the clause, will that automatically mean that the person is no longer a member of the union? If that is the case, the problem dissolves; but, on my reading of the clause, the person hangs on to membership in some form or another, and that is where the problem arises. I think that it is a real problem, and the Opposition's argument should be answered.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak as a former full time union official and I see a problem in this area-a problem of which unions are aware. To my knowledge, most unions have not resolved the problem. Let me give the committee an instance where this provision could operate in the opposite way to that which is intended. As a member of parliament, as a senator, I am still technically eligible to be a member of the union for which I worked, and indeed for 17 years I have been a member of that union both in this country and of its parent body back in the United Kingdom. What happens if through no fault of mine I do not pay my union dues and subscriptions at the due date? Different unions have different time frames for payment; some require payment quarterly or fortnightly and others require annual payments. If through some delay in the post the account does not arrive or through neglect-and this happened on one occasion to me-the individual union member does not pay the subscription when due, that person will be cut out of the union even though that was not that person's intention. It may happen because those concerned were slack. I appreciate the spirit of the amendment, but I think that carriage of this amendment could raise many more problems than it would solve. However, I understand that the Government intends to oppose it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to the contributions made by Senator Harradine and Senator Macklin. Senator Harradine asked whether the Government was prepared to take the issue to the National Labour Consultative Council. I am in a position to say that we will do so, and I hope that satisfies Senator Harradine's request. I recognise that his experience in this area gives the Government great cause to listen to his contributions on an issue such as this.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin asked questions about the rights and knowledge of members. The Government was sufficiently concerned to include in the Bill clause 195, which makes it mandatory on industrial organisations to advise members of an organisation of their rights and obligations, and more particularly to make them aware of the method of resignation adopted by that industrial organisation. I think that answers the first part of Senator Macklin's question. Senator Macklin made a couple of points about his involvement in trade unions, but obviously he has not been followed across the country in pursuit of unpaid dues. I am in the same position as Senator Macklin. I have not been followed across the country by the Federated Clerks Union of Australia, of which I was a member for some time, or by any other organisation such as the shop assistants union.

Clause 264 sets out the processes of resignation and tightens the existing provisions of the law but, in essence, the bottom line is that, if a person has not taken a positive act of resigning, he or she can be eligible for membership. The Government feels that, given the regime of industrial law, the Opposition's amendment is too inflexible. We recognise that problems have been raised in this debate to warrant further consideration by the National Labour Consultative Council. Accordingly, we are prepared to pass the issue on to that Council.
Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 September, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States (Works and Housing) Assistance Bill 1988 allocate payments to the States for the year 1988-89 as agreed by the Commonwealth and the States at the Loan Council meeting on 12 May. The allocation payable to the States and the Northern Territory is $621m. This is purely a machinery Bill and, as I understand it, the Opposition will support it without amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation gives the Senate the opportunity to debate the Government's housing record. I am sorry to tell the Senate that it is a very sorry record indeed. There are 168,217 Australians on the welfare housing list; the first home owners assistance scheme is being dismantled; home interest rates are now at a record level; the cost of purchasing a home has nearly doubled since the Australian Labor Party came to power in 1983; 40,000 people are permanently homeless and another 60,000 are on the verge of homelessness; the average income does not qualify for the average home loan; and the Government's policy on capital gains tax on investment housing is acting to the detriment of people seeking welfare housing, rental housing or private housing. We have seen the priority given to pushing people into welfare housing and we have all seen a reduction in the quality and size of homes in the last five years. All of this proves unequivocally that this Government's housing policy has been and is in a shambles. It has abandoned thousands of young married couples with young families to high private rental or a three- or four-year wait in housing commission queues. Many of those people will never have the satisfaction or pride of being able to say, `That is our home. We can make improvements, add extensions or pass it on to our children when we go'.

This policy is anathema to the coalition: it is totally against the ethos and philosophy of the National and Liberal parties. If I could draw a difference between those parties and the Government Party it would be the difference in their housing policies. The coalition is committed to seeing all young married couples have a home that they own-not a rented home or one for which they pay rent to welfare housing, but a home in which they can take pride and about which they can say, `This is our little home. We can build on it and extend it where necessary and when money becomes available'. We do not want to see people pushed into welfare housing.

Five or six years ago a young couple with savings could go to a bank or, probably in those times, a building society and take out a modest loan to get a decent home in a reasonable suburb. Around 12 or 13 squares would have been the size of an average worker's home in those days in Queensland. It would probably have had three bedrooms, a dining room and a lounge room, have been on stumps and had car accommodation underneath. As the couple progressed and came into more money as time went on, they would put a cement slab under the house and extend the downstairs area by building a rumpus room and so on. In the end they had a nice, comfortable, probably 15-square home. I am afraid to say that nowadays the same worker's dwelling is around eight or nine squares in size. It is a small brick house on a cement base with little option of improvement or extension. It is probably built on a small lot, is badly serviced and is in an outlying suburb. That is what the worker has been reduced to under this Government's housing policy. Before I became a member of the Senate I was involved in the hardware and housing industry. I know that the standard of workers' dwellings has slipped abysmally over the last five or six years. Many people feel trapped in outer suburbs as they have no or very little transport. What the worker can afford now is certainly inferior to what he was able to obtain four or five years ago.

The Government's housing performance is second to none in the damage inflicted against the 90 per cent of those Australians who work hard to own their own home. Under this Government the cost of buying a home has nearly doubled. In 1983-84 the average monthly loan repayment was $335, based on a loan of $33,000 at 11.5 per cent interest over 25 years. In 1988 the average home loan repayment is $620, based on a home loan of $55,000 at 14.5 per cent interest over 25 years. Home loan repayments have doubled; the standard of living has dropped by about 50 per cent; and the working man is in a far worse housing position than he was when the Labor Party came to office.

I have taken out some figures from the Parliamentary Library which I believe should be read into the record. In New South Wales the repayments on an average housing loan have risen from $472 per month in 1984 to $857 per month in 1988, representing an increase of 82 per cent. In Victoria the average monthly repayment has increased from $405 to $710, an increase of 75 per cent; in South Australia from $415 to $598, an increase of 44 per cent; in Western Australia from $368 to $581, an increase of 58 per cent; in Tasmania from $293 to $475, an increase of 62 per cent; and in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) from $541 to $741, a modest increase of 37 per cent in four years. It is no wonder that the results of the Oxley by-election came out as they did when the working men and women of this nation have to pay such repayments and rents. They feel that they have been cheated. They cannot afford to meet their commitments and, correspondingly, they show their objection in the ballot box. The figures that I have obtained also show an increase in the cost of dwellings. In Sydney the cost rose by 80 per cent in two years; in Melbourne, 20 per cent; Brisbane, 23.7 per cent; Perth, 26.9 per cent; and so on. People just cannot afford to get into their own home.

Let us examine some of the reasons, some of the policies that the Government has enunciated. It has changed its housing policy 23 times. Probably the worst example of why housing in Australia is in a crisis would be the Government's policy on capital gains tax. It has directly contributed to the escalating home price spiral which has led to an 80 per cent price increase in New South Wales in the past 12 months. The capital gains tax has actively discouraged investment in private rental housing. Why would anyone purchase a property to rent when the average return after paying for insurance, repairs, rates and land tax is 4 or 5 per cent and there is the disincentive of a capital gains tax? Therefore all those houses that were on the rental market have now been pulled off the market and sold. That has left a big gap in rental housing. No one in the Labor Party saw that when it introduced a capital gains tax. It did not heed the warnings of the coalition. We told the Labor Party that that is exactly what would have happened. Our worst fears were realised. Hundreds of rental homes were sold. People who relied on that rental housing were pushed into outer suburbs, pushed into welfare housing queues, went to stay with their parents, or paid exorbitant rents.

It is clearly a policy introduced by the Labor Party that has brought this problem forward. Capital that should have gone into land development, subdivision, industrial and commercial property and rental housing, such as flats and units, is to be diverted away because of this Government's capital gains tax. This tax has distorted the natural growth and development of our building infrastructure. Instead of investing in these areas and relieving some of the housing demand pressures, funds have been channelled into expensive personal housing-on many occasions it is far beyond the needs of the owner-to avoid capital gains tax. That is what is firing the cost-spiral on housing in Sydney. People are buying homes that they do not really require and are using them as a tax haven. We warned the Government about that too and it never took any notice. It really turns up the heat on the market, prices escalate wildly and it is denying the low income families, the working class men and women that the Government is supposed to represent, the opportunity to own their own home. I think the Government ought to consider that because it is very important. It is one of the major issues that is pushing up housing in all capital cities in Australia today.

Home ownership is less affordable today than it has ever been in the last five years. The situation is not improving; quite the contrary, it is getting worse as time goes on. The average annual disposable family income is around $34,500. An annual disposable income of $39,000 is needed to qualify for a loan to buy an average house. There are very few people who are on $39,000 a year. What about the process workers? What about the factory workers? These people are all entitled to own their own home. They are workers who normally vote for the Labor Party. They are the people that the Government is supposed to represent in this Parliament. Yet it has denied them the right to have their own home because of its policies that are just not working. A disposable income of $39,500 is required to own a home in a capital city today. If that does not particularly hit home honourable senators should think about the shortfall between the average home loan which the average family cannot afford and the actual median prices for houses in our capital cities today.

I wish to give some figures from the Real Estate Institute of the ACT. These figures shocked me because I thought they were excessive. In Sydney today a home costs $170,500. In Melbourne the average home is $116,000, in Brisbane it is $77,000 and in Adelaide $82,500. Overall, the national average is $103,857. That is for an average home. The Government has reduced the maximum deposit under the first home owners scheme for a family with one child to $2,000. Under the coalition's policy, the Government would meet the cost of mortgage insurance. That would allow people to buy homes without paying a deposit. That policy was welcomed by the Master Builders Federation of Australia Inc. and the Real Estate Institute of Australia as innovative and trying to do something for the average person who wants to buy his own home.

The Government has pushed funds away from private housing into the public sector. In 1981-82, Commonwealth funding was split 46 per cent for purchase assistance and 54 per cent for public housing. In 1986-87, Commonwealth funding was 27 per cent for purchase assistance and 73 per cent for public housing. The first home owners scheme has had its funding cut from $306m in 1984-85 to $222m in 1987-88 with individual grants being cut last May by $1,000. It is becoming increasingly apparent that home purchase assistance is pushing towards welfare housing. A magazine I have states:

Recent studies have shown that greater benefits are arising from providing assistance to home buyers. The benefits include increased levels of employment among the families, a reduced dependency on welfare income, high levels of satisfaction with the housing and enthusiasm for home repairs and improvements which add generally to the quality of Australia's housing stock. More than two-thirds of a group that was surveyed had made some sort of alterations ranging from $1,000 to $10,000. The families reported greater security, independence, privacy and investment potential on their housing. When asked what this housing purchase assistance meant to them one respondent summed it up by saying it is like winning Lotto; own a bit of land, independence, something that will become ours and when we go it goes to the kids. It is basically what you live for, to own you own home and pass it on. All Australians would prefer to own their own home'.

That is the commitment that this coalition gives. When returned to office we are determined that we will make that one of our major commitments. If a family has its own home and enjoys its own home it is clearly shown that their quality of lifestyle rises and they become part of the surrounding areas. They generally find that their kids get jobs and they are totally committed to that style of life. Most Australians have home ownership as their major ambition.

Let us just look at Commonwealth payments to the States for housing and community amenities. These payments also have dropped significantly. There was a decrease of 14.5 per cent in 1987-88. There is a projected decrease of another 8.9 per cent in 1988-89. It does not really matter whether one is seeking welfare housing, rental housing or housing in the private housing market; no matter what sector one is in at present one is worse off since this Government came to power. Housing queues have continued to increase at record rates. In 1982-83 123,707 people were waiting for housing. In 1987-88 the number in those queues had increased to 185,000 people. The number of people on waiting lists for assistance under the home purchase assistance programs stands at 79,000. These intolerably long waiting lists are a direct result of the Government allocating insufficient funds to home ownership.

I turn now to loan repayments as a percentage of family income. The Real Estate Institute found that in the June quarter of last year 31.3 per cent of the median family income was spent on monthly loan repayments. This was a rate of repayment well above the 25 per cent which is generally recognised as the amount a family can afford to allocate. The Australian ratio of average home loan repayments to median family income for loans approved in the June quarter was assessed at 28.4 per cent of the average worker's income.

As I have mentioned, overall it is a sorry state of affairs. Under no circumstances is any sector of the Australian community better off under this Labor Government's housing policy. The Government has failed. It has failed every sector. The coalition rejects the Government's housing policy. We reject the forcing of people into queues. We reject the Government's bankrupting of the pride of hundreds of thousands of Australians who can see no light at the end of the rental tunnel. We reject the high inflation, high taxing and decreasing real wages policies of this Government.

The Housing Industry Association has welcomed the coalition's response to the housing problem. It has described our pro-ownership policy as bold and innovative and a response to mounting housing affordability problems. The coalition policy transfers the emphasis from the provision of public housing by government to the provision of much more support for private home ownership. While the Opposition supports this Bill, let there be no doubt in anyone's mind that we are certainly not happy with the way Australians are being housed under this Government. Once home ownership for our young people is wiped out, there will be very few dreams left for our young married people. We do not support this Government's attitude of pushing people into welfare housing. On our return to government we will support a policy that will see many of our young people able to afford homes that they can call their own.

TALK.START.PARA: —How will you pay for it?

—We will pay for it by increasing productivity, not by increasing taxes as the Government has done in the last five years. The Government has earned the title of the highest taxing government in Australia. That does not allow people to own their own homes. All it does is push people into welfare housing as they are forced to pay increasing taxes and become reliant on welfare housing and welfare benefits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are discussing the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Bill 1988, which, on the face of it, seems fairly inconsequential. The main purpose of this Bill is to obtain the approval of this Parliament for payments in 1988-89 of interest free capital grants to the States of $310,504,000 and loans up to the same amount which the States may nominate for any public housing purpose. It should be noted that this was the same amount of money given in 1987-88, although the grant component has been lifted from one-third to a half. Although the Commonwealth at the Loan Council meeting indicated that the States should apply the additional expenditures to public housing, there is no guarantee that this will occur.

SPEECH.PARA: The criticism of this Bill really rests on the point which I have made on several other occasions this afternoon; that is, the flaws in the basic economic model which this Government is following and, indeed, which the Opposition would be following if it were the government. It is a naked, market-driven type economic model which inevitably leaves the poor at the bottom of the heap and less able to participate either in home ownership or in the taking up of the limited amount of public housing which becomes available. I would like to refer to that point again later.

The relationship between poverty and housing costs in this country has been well documented on a greater number of occasions. It is important to realise that there is a significant difference in the way in which the incidence of poverty is measured before and after people have paid for their housing; that is, if one measures their income before housing and after housing. There has been a rapid rise in poverty in this country from the early 1970s right through to the present time. Poverty among children has increased, as has the poverty among people after housing costs have been paid. The increase is from 6.6 per cent to 11.1 per cent over that time.

There has also been a shift in poverty from the elderly to the young, who are more likely to have children. We have all seen figures indicating that in fact the number of children in families living below the poverty line is now very substantial. It is well over 20 per cent. That is largely because the costs of housing for the young tend to be higher. Elderly people are more likely to own their own homes. Of course, one reason for that is that as populations increase, as cities expand, so the demand for housing, particularly given the speculative nature of the market system which both this Government and the Opposition support, disadvantages those people who enter the market late. It makes the costs of housing for those people much higher, compared with the cost for those people who entered that market system much earlier and who have already paid for their housing.

The need for public housing in this country is indeed urgent. The figures indicate that some 40,000 people are now homeless and that waiting lists for public housing will number some 250,000 households in the year 1990-given the predictions from recent trends. Growing numbers of people cannot afford to rent in the private rental market or gain access to home ownership. I think Senator Boswell has given some of the figures indicating that area of concern. Some 150,000 people live in caravan parks.

This Bill, which directs a significant amount of money to public housing, can only be supported. But if we are to address the problems of housing in this country we must go well beyond simple grants and loans to the States for public housing. We are seeing simply a bandaid approach to what is basically a flawed economic model. I stress again, if one assumes that the way in which the major economic development in this country is to be managed is simply to leave it to naked market forces in the belief, as was said many years ago by a famous economist, that it is an invisible hand, the invisible hand will demonstrably advantage the wealthy and will substantially disadvantage the poor. This is precisely what we have seen in recent years with an increasing gap between the few who are wealthy and becoming wealthier and the majority who are becoming poorer and less able to afford housing.

An example of the operation of this market system was given last week in, I think, Friday's Australian Financial Review. A lead article on the front page suggested that the Government might have to tighten monetary policy, that is, increase home interest rates, to rein in the `overheated housing sector'. The operation of the market and the placing of a higher emphasis on economic indicators than on the welfare of people lead to the conclusion that the overheating of the market sector, which is consequent upon the increased demand, leads to the necessity of increasing interest rates, and that clearly impacts upon the poor rather than on the wealthy. The wealthy, or those above a significant income-Senator Boswell mentioned an income of $39,000 a year-perhaps can afford to pay at the higher interest rates. But if interest rate movements are used as an instrument of economic policy, ignoring the fact that large numbers of people are without housing, or have inadequate housing, in this country, the consequences will be that fewer people will be able to afford to buy housing and more people will be forced into the public housing sector. That is, of course, precisely where this bandaid approach of the Government, as indicated in this Bill, will apply.

The fact that there is a shortage of housing in this country and that 150,000 people live in caravan parks does not seem to have any bearing on the thinking of economists who simply look at market indicators. As I have said, the less well-off are particularly disadvantaged by the increase in home interest rates. So, serving the dictates of economic indicators-and we hear this all the time from the Treasurer (Mr Keating), Senator Walsh and Senator Button, and considerably more often from Opposition spokespersons-does not serve the welfare of ordinary people.

Governments can spend on housing in a number of ways. In 1984-85, $3 billion was spent directly on housing, for the construction of public sector rental housing, for assistance with rents and home purchase, and for special housing programs in the community. Housing subsidies are well targeted to low income groups but tax expenditures mainly benefit home owners and the rich. The average public sector tenant received $1,795 worth of assistance in 1984-85 while the average owner-occupier received $1,250. Private sector tenants, however, obtained benefits worth less than $300 per household. That indicates clearly how the present tax structure advantages, yet again, those who are better off and disadvantages those in the community who are less well off. It is well documented that the highest incidence of poverty is in households that rent on the private market.

Since 1985 the trend has been to increase tax discrimination in favour of owner-occupiers, with the introduction of the capital gains tax on all assets except the dwellings of owner-occupiers. This exemption was worth about $1,500m to owner-occupiers. If this Government were a true Labor government and genuinely considered the needs of the poor and disadvantaged, it would consider a tax on realised capital gains by owner-occupiers, or a tax on net imputed rentals, and use those funds to increase levels of social security payments, especially to families with children. I remind the Government that it promised that no child in Australia would live in poverty by 1990.

Another way in which this could be done would be for the Government to shift the tax burden to a land value tax system, which would substantially remove the speculative element from new land developments, one of those factors which militate heavily against young home owners, the young marrieds as Senator Boswell calls them, who wish to get their foot on the bottom rung of that very steep and difficult ladder leading eventually to home ownership.
The International Year of Shelter for the Homeless report stated:

Because these (ie non taxation of capital gains of owner occupied houses) and other tax concessions lower the cost of home ownership for many wealthy people, they serve to drive up the overall price of housing thus further disadvantaging those who do not benefit from those subsidies.
More than half of the nation's private wealth is in residential property, much of which was accumulated through the generous tax treatments and subsidies for owner-occupiers.

One must remember that this Government removed negative gearing and later reintroduced it on the grounds that it was supposed to provide more housing for low income families. It seems very difficult to collect reliable statistics on this, but there has not been a large increase in housing available at the lower end of the market for people in real need, as a consequence of the reintroduction of negative gearing. In fact, when negative gearing was introduced, it was pointed out that the Treasury White Paper on tax reform before the tax summit-this is when the Labor Government first came into office-in arguing the justice and equity case for the abolition of negative gearing, showed that in 1982-83 14 per cent of individuals with negatively geared property would have taxable incomes of more than $100,000 if negative gearing had then been disallowed, while less than 2 per cent would have had taxable incomes below the then average wage.

It would be useful to merely assert that the reintroduction of negative gearing has disadvantaged the less well off; it has encouraged more speculation throughout the housing market rather than developing new housing; and to the extent that it has caused wealthy property developers to buy up low cost housing and to pull down those buildings and develop those areas for higher cost housing, it has made less lower cost housing available to those in real need.

Another point bearing on Government policy and also on the policy of the Opposition is that infrastructure costs consequent upon the growth model that the Government and Opposition are both following are getting completely out of hand. It is a matter of fact that 80 per cent of the population increase in Australia since the Second World War has occurred in capital cities. It is a matter of fact that the maintenance of the infrastructure for those cities has not been properly allowed for. If one turns to the South Australian Government submission to the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Poverty, one discovers that the infrastructure costs in South Australia for the five-year period from 1985 to 1990 are estimated to be $800m. Yet by 1995 and to the year 2000, because of the ageing of the infrastructure-the sewer pipes, the water pipes, the electricity, the roads, the curbs, the telephones and everything else-the infrastructure costs will amount to $3,000m. Those costs will totally account for all the public sector spending on infrastructure at that time, leaving nothing whatsoever for the expansion of cities and the provision of new services. Yet this Government and the Opposition are apparently committed to a program of increasing the size of cities and of the population, and that again can only disadvantage those who are less well off. Again, it is a matter of fact that the costs of electricity, water, roads and transport are increasing much faster than the inflation rate or the rate of growth of the gross national product. Of course, one might remark in passing that all these costs are added to gross national product. They are counted as benefits in the peculiar system of national accounting which this and most other industrial countries have adopted.

I refer to a letter in the West Australian today pointing to the decrease in rainfall in Western Australia, possibly as a consequence of greenhouse warming. The article points to the need to impose water restrictions in Perth. Again, there will be a further increase in cost as water becomes more scarce, and a further decline in the quality of life. Who benefits from those developments? It is the very few who can afford to pay the higher costs. Who is disadvantaged? It is the poor, who are at the bottom of the heap and who are less able to meet those costs.

It is also of great concern to many Australians-and I have noticed this particularly in Queensland and in Western Australia-that there appears to be increasing foreign ownership of Australian real estate, particularly speculation in real estate in Australia by foreign owners. This again, while it is encouraged by an emphasis on economic indicators rather than the welfare of people, is substantially disadvantaging those who are attempting to enter the housing market. I think it would be very interesting to have both the Government and the Opposition support the Australian Democrats' calls for a register of foreign ownership of Australian real estate so that we would get some indication of just what precisely is going on in that area.

The Australian Democrats will support this Bill as it is, but indicate very forcefully that it and many other measures which this Government brings forward are in the nature of bandaids. A more fundamental approach is required which really would see the adoption of a totally different economic model. It would use different indicators of human welfare rather than the very broad and totally inadequate economic indicators which are not really based on human welfare at all. It must be said that this Bill will go some small way towards addressing very real housing needs of this country, but we believe that there must be this reassessment of taxation policy to ensure that the housing dollar is directed primarily at the poor and especially the families with children. This will ensure that the housing factor in poverty will be minimised.

In conclusion, it is worth drawing attention also to a recent publication titled How Many Australians? and edited by two demographers from the Australian National University. On the matter of housing, if honourable senators would like to refer to that book, they will see that there is a very interesting paper which draws comparisons between Sweden and Australia. Sweden, which has had a substantially stable population for quite a long time and which is doing better both educationally and economically than Australia, is also doing substantially better in the housing area. Instead of simply building more houses, which Australia has been intent on doing, Sweden has been able to concentrate on building better houses and, because it is building better houses, it is able to sell that technology to other countries. So it has established a substantial overseas benefit from its emphasis on quality housing rather than simply building more houses.
