One other remark one might make in reflecting on the economic policies of this Government is that, in a market driven system where the creation of credit is left with the private banks, one sees enormous wealth accumulating in the centres of the major capital cities. If one looks around any of the Australian cities one sees cranes dotting the skyline and banks, insurance companies and other lending institutions building very vigorously. That is not where Australia needs to be building. Australia needs to be building in the suburbs, where people need housing. But the economic structure which this Government is accepting, the economic structure which accepts the dictates of those market forces and does nothing to turn them around, will simply again continue to benefit the wealthy and will progressively produce disbenefits for those less well off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Bill 1988. This Bill will authorise the payments during 1988-89 of capital grants to the States and the Northern Territory for the purpose of public housing. I suppose this is a particularly important Bill because there are so many people out there in Australia who are desperately in need of public housing and who, for one reason or another, are prevented from getting it. I think the great tragedy that we are now seeing is the waiting list. People have to go onto the end of the waiting lists for many months to try to obtain housing. That is made even more serious by the fact that many of these people have children and simply cannot get housing. This Government in its overall record has not assisted home ownership in Australia one iota.
—Nonsense.

—It is not nonsense. The facts that I will give in a moment will prove that it is anything but nonsense. Those people who are on the end of the waiting lists will not believe that is nonsense either. Today in this House we have had a further example as to why there are waiting lists: people who can quite afford to buy a house actually make sure that they occupy a house that those who cannot afford housing could occupy. They refuse to get out of public housing because of their own selfish desires. Despite the protests of people such as Senator Richardson, this Government cannot escape the basic fact that home loan repayments now consume 28 per cent of median family income, compared with 19 per cent when it took office in 1983. That is a dramatic increase when one stops and thinks that wages certainly have not been able to cope with that type of increase.

SPEECH.PARA: There is absolutely no escaping the fact that the cost of housing is rising above the general rate of inflation. In Perth, my home city, we are told, home buyers are fortunate to be looking at purchasing homes, compared with those Sydney. The average price of an established home in Perth has risen 45 per cent over the past year. I do not think that that is any mean increase either. The average three-bedroom brick and tile home in Perth 12 months ago cost about $50,000, and one could get a pretty reasonable place for that. Only 12 months later one will be looking not at $50,000, $60,000 or $70,000, but at $72,500-for a very average brick and tile home. If a person wants a bit more room-and 12 months ago he would have been looking at $70,000-he will now be looking at over $100,000. I think that is a real reflection on what this Government is all about. A house selling for even $60,000 in September of last year would have cost $81,000 in August this year. But the dramatic increase in the last month would have made that $81,000 equivalent to $87,000. This is being felt across the board, with the cost of renting also rising.

Once price rises of this nature occur there will also, of course, be rental increases. There has been an 11 per cent rise in the rental cost of a two bedroom unit in Perth over the last year. The pressure has been put on units particularly because units are now being sought by those who cannot afford the rise in the rental cost of houses. Increases in the cost of renting a unit have certainly outstripped inflation in all major cities except Sydney. I do not think condemning some people to very small, poky units in a high rise complex is necessarily giving them a ride on the gravy train for the rest of their lives.

Statistics of the Real Estate Institute of Australia for the June quarter show a sharp decline in home affordability, reversing the earlier recovery that was evident in the March quarter figures. The ratio of home loan repayments to median family income is 28.4 per cent, up from 27 per cent only 12 months ago. So with the passing of every month the slice of income that is needed to afford housing is getting bigger and bigger. Quite honestly, I would hate to be a young person these days trying to break into the property market to provide security for himself and his family because, in the first instance, where can he raise enough for a deposit and, in the second instance, how can he afford the repayments and the high interest rates? In Western Australia in the June quarter of 1987-88 affordability tightened by 1.2 per cent and the total median price rose by 12.3 per cent, compared with an inflation rate of 6.7 per cent. So the rises are certainly outstripping inflation.

We must bear in mind that the more recent figures I have quoted show that the rise has been far greater since then. From the March quarter to the June quarter the price rise in Western Australia was 5.5 per cent, while the general cost of living rose 1.8 per cent. Again and again the figures tell the story. Yet Senator Richardson can quite calmly sit in this chamber and say that that is not so. The Government's own figures prove it. During the June quarter the average Perth building society home loan increased by a staggering 14 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the first home owners scheme.

—I am glad Senator Richardson has raised the first home owners scheme. I will come to it in a minute. I am thrilled that he raised that because that will be another slap in the moosh for him. A study by the Department of Community Services and Health last August estimated that 700,000 Australians have been forced into poverty by increased housing costs-and Senator Richardson thinks that is a drop in the ocean. There is constant evidence that homelessness and the resort to such substandard accommodation as permanent residence in caravan parks are affecting a far wider range of Australians than previously. It is now estimated that an Australian family needs an annual disposable income of $39,500 to qualify for a loan to buy an average house, when the average annual family disposable income is $34,500. The average family needs $39,500, and we must bear in mind that `average' means that there are a heck of a lot of people earning less than $34,500. No wonder the average family needs to have both parents in the work force. It is a necessity rather than a choice.

SPEECH.PARA: Average monthly repayments have risen from $335 in 1984, when the interest rate was 11.5 per cent, to $620 in 1988, with the interest rate up to 14.5 per cent. We must also remember that interest rates have peaked at even higher levels during this Government's term of office and that it is strongly hinted that they will increase again in the very near future. No Federal government can escape responsibility for interest rates that must inevitably affect housing loans. This Government has relied heavily on monetary policy rather than expenditure restraint to cure our economic ills.

Housing interest rates are up a full percentage point this month, and the trend is ominous for Australian families in the very near future. The main responsibility of a Federal government to assist home affordability is through overall economic policy that restrains interest rates and increases family disposable income. But, no, this Government will not do either. It promised tax cuts this year but, of course, for pragmatic political reasons they have been put off until next year, because that is closer to an election. But heaven only knows whether we will get them next year. The average family certainly needs them now and not just when the Government decides to give them because it is more expedient to do it closer to an election.

There is also a need for direct assistance, and here also the record of this Government is found wanting. I come to the first home owners scheme, about which Senator Richardson quite proudly said a moment ago, `Whacko! Haven't we done a good job?' This is what the Government has done with it: the 1988 Budget has cut another $44m from it. Over the last three years funds under the scheme have been reduced by 42 per cent, equating to $128m. Senator Richardson is deafening in his silence now. By 1991 the Australian Labor Party plans to diminish it by 75 per cent, and he is proud of that. He sits there with his smirking little grin, proud of that. He is not trying to get a grant under the first home owners scheme, is he? No.

TALK.START.PARA: —That makes two of us at least.

—I did not say for one moment that the first home owners scheme was good. No, I am not looking for a grant. The honourable senator is saying that the scheme is wonderful. The Government has almost demolished it. It is seeking to diminish it by 75 per cent by 1991. Despite the fact that the cost of housing is moving inexorably in the other direction, the Government is pushing the first home owners scheme down and out. Federal assistance to the States for housing is down 6 per cent in real terms in 1988-89, while public housing queues have risen from 123,000 to 185,000 since Senator Richardson's Government took office-an increase of 50 per cent. Fifty per cent more people are now in those public housing queues.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that the Government's action in the housing field is simply the result of incompetence and disinterest. Mind you, one is tempted to believe it. Only a Labor government would have entertained the despicable proposal that capital gains taxes or, far worse, a wealth tax should be levied on the family home. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and others who are hostile to home ownership should note that Australia spends 4.7 per cent of gross domestic product on housing while member countries of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development spend 5.3 per cent. We are seriously lagging behind, yet this Government reduces the funds under the first home owners scheme by 20 per cent.

A coalition government is pledged to tackle the overall economic problem of high interest rates and the taxation squeeze on the family that, I reiterate, are the root cause of Australia's housing problems. Any member of this Government could go out and ask anyone in any tax bracket whether he or she has a higher disposable income now than when this Government took office. The answer would be no. Those opposite should talk to people about their grocery bills, their lighting bills and their heating bills, but they would not be game. A coalition government will direct greater assistance to those low income families that this Government has progressively neglected and has been proven to neglect by the results of by-elections all through this year.

Maximum deposit assistance has been reduced from $3,000 in 1985 to $2,000 today. That is another area where the first home buyer has been hit for six. We will assist those with incomes less than $15,000 by a $300m allocation to bridge the deposit gap and meet the cost of mortgage insurance. A far greater proportion of Federal assistance to the States for housing will be allocated to the promotion of home ownership rather than rental accommodation. We believe that the public housing crisis is best tackled by the sale of public housing stock to tenants and the direction of funds to provide accommodation for those in greatest need. Our policy is based on the ideal that home ownership is not just for middle income earners but also for those low income families who are now forced to rely on public housing. Under the policies of this Labor Government even the middle income family finds the cost of a home moving beyond its reach.

There are dramatic differences between where a coalition Government would direct housing and what this Government is doing to diminish the affordability of houses and the chances of people to get public housing. Of course we are not opposing this Bill, because it is desperately needed by people who are in equally desperate straits to get public housing. The people of Australia must be very concerned at their chances and opportunities of ever being able to afford housing under this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —The States (Works and Housing) Assistance Bill 1988 epitomises the continual hypocrisy of this Government in matters such as housing, living standards and the relationship between the two. The message that the electorate sent back to this Labor Government in the Oxley by-election last Saturday, in the by-elections earlier this year and in the referendums has been one which says, `We are not satisfied. This Government is lowering our standards of living'. Housing in the Australian ethos, in the Australian culture, is a most important part of the standard of living as we know it and recognise it. The great Australian dream of owning one's own home is acknowledged, even by the Government, as becoming more and more difficult to achieve. As I said, the message has been continually delivered by the electorate-most recently in the Oxley by-election-that it is dissatisfied with the way the Government is handling its policies.

SPEECH.PARA: The message which came from western Sydney-that area most adversely affected by government policies-was truly sent home to the Labor Party in March when the Unsworth Government was unceremoniously thrown out of office and we won seats in west Sydney for the first time. The Greiner Government in New South Wales is committed to serving that area, where much of its policy initiative is being placed to ensure that those people who have been disadvantaged by having Labor representation for so long finally get an even break.

The home regularly comes in for attention and attack from people that the Government likes to use in a consulting capacity. An example that comes readily to mind is Professor Gruen's continuing wish that we should somehow include the home within the capital gains tax. He makes the point-and there are many in the Government who follow the line-that investment in the home distorts the rest of the investment pattern. This goes towards the line of theory-and many Labor members like to propound the line-that somehow investment in housing is not true investment; that housing is a consumption good as distinct from a valuable investment which they would like to see used in some other way. Recent figures from a study in New South Wales have shown that for each dollar that the Commonwealth invests in housing the combined savings revenue benefit to the Government is $1.30 Very simply, the housing industry-the building of houses and the providing of homes for the people-is a generator of jobs and growth. It is a worthwhile generator of jobs. Housing is an important investment and ought not to be considered, as it is by many, as a consumption item.

Professor Gruen is wrong when he wants to penalise people for investing in their homes and to include the home in the capital gains tax. But that of course is step number one in the march towards the wealth tax which is still on the Labor Party's agenda. Those people who feel that their homes or their savings are in jeopardy should well remember that the statistical research that is to be done by the Australian Bureau of Statistics and that was so hotly debated in Estimates committees only yesterday could be used as a basis for establishing a test for a future wealth tax. The amount of material being sought in that questionnaire could be the basis of working out a scheme by which a wealth tax could be implemented. Of course, Australians who choose to invest a great part of their lifetime earnings in their homes would become prime targets for such a wealth tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least they can rest safely in the knowledge that not even you believe that.

—Indeed, I do believe it. The Labor Party has, fundamentally, in its agenda the march towards such policies. Pragmatists Opposition senators may have been for the last five years but nonetheless the ideological thrust is there. Indeed, the result of the Victorian election means that the Left of the Labor Party is again in some ascendancy in the Victorian Government. It will be interesting to see the policy changes that emerge. It will also be quite significant finally to see whether the successor in the Australian Council of Trade Unions will be Mr Halfpenny. If it is, we will again see a shift and a return to the policies of wealth tax, capital gains tax on housing and taxes that are basically designed to bring people down to the lowest common denominator.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the policies and despite research showing that for each dollar invested by the Commonwealth there is a return in a savings revenue benefit of $1.30, there is nonetheless a very long waiting list of people in need of homes. In New South Wales we have inherited some 75,000 such people from the previous Labor Government. The policy that was implemented by Treasurer Keating of getting rid of negative gearing for a time, until he realised the error of his ways and reinstated it, distorted the providing of rental accommodation and has added to the burden of the need for public housing. Following that period when negative gearing was phased out of the taxation benefits that could be accrued, uncertainty as to whether the Labor Government will adhere to the change that is has now made has meant that the return to the building of rental accommodation has not been quite as speedy as some would like. If there is one thing that upsets the market more than anything else it is uncertainty.

I was interested to hear Senator Devlin's personal explanation today at the end of Question Time. It dealt with the fact that he is living in public housing, subsidised rental accommodation. It highlighted the hypocrisy that I mentioned earlier. We have a member of this chamber whose salary is well known to all of us because we share it--

TALK.START.PARA: —A Labor member.

—A Labor member in Tasmania has been living for 12 years in public housing for which he pays the grand sum of $74 a week. In his personal explanation Senator Devlin said that, having been in this chamber for four years and being paid as a senator, the only reason that he was still in public housing paying $74 a week and keeping some other needy person out of public housing was that the Tasmanian Government would not sell that particular accommodation to him. He said that the Government would not sell the accommodation to him because the title to it was a joint tenancy. Somehow he was asserting that he had a right to buy that apartment. Yet he has been a senator for four years. The article to which his personal explanation drew my attention disclosed that he was employing his wife. There are two incomes coming into that one household from the public purse, which means that for that four-year period he has been rorting the system.

SPEECH.PARA: We hear a lot from Treasurer Keating about people who rort the system. Somehow there seems to be one rule for Labor members of parliament and one rule for everybody else. The rules for Labor members of parliament seem to be these: Treasurer Keating is allowed to rort the system and abuse the travelling allowance system to the extent of some $17,000 per annum. He is also allowed to rort the system by having a special relationship with Mr Boucher. It is no wonder he went to his defence the other day when people had the temerity to attack Mr Boucher for not behaving in accordance with the laws of the land and for putting himself above the Parliament. It is no wonder Mr Keating went to his defence because when Mr Keating's tax return had not been filed he did not get, as any ordinary taxpayer would have got, a notice, a penalty and a fine. He got a nice little note which said, `Please, would you mind awfully if you put in your tax return because we have not had it yet?'.

Now we have Senator Devlin paying $74 a week for public housing in Tasmania when he and his wife are on the public payroll. The only excuse as to why they are still in that accommodation is that the Tasmanian Government will not sell him the accommodation. I have heard from many a Labor politician the argument that goes this way: no public housing should be sold; all public housing should be kept as a reservoir from which those in the community who are needy should be given preference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor stopped selling public housing in Canberra when it was elected in 1983.

—I thank Senator Reid. It is interesting to know that the Askin Government in New South Wales was able to sell housing in the public sector to tenants who had been in that accommodation for a considerable time. But the Wran Administration also ceased to sell public housing when it took office. Yet, we have Senator Devlin claiming that it is his right, that the Government ought to sell him this accommodation. As I said-hypocrisy and duplicity. There is one rule for Labor members of parliament and there is one rule for everybody else. And the two rules are very different.

SPEECH.PARA: I note further that Senator Devlin's accommodation was brought to the attention of the Tasmanian Parliament because a new income related housing rent policy is being introduced during the Tasmanian Parliament's Budget session. It is interesting to note that the Labor Party in opposition in Tasmania has come out and said that this is inequitable, that rental in public housing should not be income related, that some people would have to move out of their homes. Under that new scheme Senator Devlin's rent would go from $74 a week to $450 a week. I do not think he will find that too many of his constituents will think that is inequitable. Yet, once again, the Labor Party in opposition in Tasmania is defending one of its own, saying that it is all right for him to stay there at $74 a week and asking why he should have to pay $450 a week. There is a very good reason, is there not? He and his wife are both being paid very well by the Commonwealth Government and they can afford to pay income related rentals. Those examples of the way in which the Labor Party rorts the system and then stands up and cries and says that it is everybody else who is rorting the system really show how dishonest it is.

It is interesting to look at the message that the electorate is sending to this Labor Government. When I see that the New South Wales Government will make available some $690m for home purchasing programs which will represent nearly 10 per cent of the total volume of anticipated lending throughout the State, I say that there is a strong State Government-the Greiner Liberal Government-which is in office to defend the people and to apply policies for the needs of the people. The west of Sydney has been badly served by years of Labor rule. An article in today's Daily Telegraph deals with the task force of inquiry into the health and housing plight of people in the west-an inherited situation. The article is headed `From country town to pre-planned housing estate' and is written by Jim O'Rourke, a man who was born and bred in the west and who cares for the people of the west. He says that many people in the Macarthur area have lived there on average for only five years. He also says that years of neglect because of health policies, nutrition policies and housing policies under strong Labor administrations have meant that these people are disadvantaged. Well, they are now going to get a fair go. The people of the west deserve a fair go and, under the Greiner Government, they will get it. When a Howard government returns to the Federal treasury bench we will start to see a fair go in economic policy for all the people of Australia that will affect this area of housing.

The rhetoric that we hear about pulling in our belts, the lecturing that we get continually from the Treasurer-the would-be Prime Minister, Mr Keating; the man who thinks that the position of Prime Minister is his mantle and that he should have it before the next election; the man who thinks that Mr Hawke's time is over and he should move over and give Keating a go; the man who rorts the travel allowance system; the man who rorts the tax system--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Bishop, I have not pulled you up before, but standing order 418 says, amongst other things, that all imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on members shall be considered highly disorderly. I think you probably will be able to make your argument without transgressing standing order 418. I ask you to do so.
—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I think the message I want to get across is this: the hypocrisy of the Government is shown up--
—Order! Many Presidents have ruled-and I am only being guided by previous rulings-that `hypocrisy' is not a word that we should use in this chamber. Would you please proceed.
—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I find that an amazing ruling in light of some of the things that are allowed to be said in the chamber--
—Order! Senator Bishop, I invite you to read Australian Senate Practice. If you do you will find that what I am saying is correct. I ask you to proceed.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I will try `duplicity'-it has more syllables in it but I think the meaning is clear. This Government has two standards-one for itself, for its own members, and one for everyone else. The electorate has seen this Government for what it is. This Government has had the message from the electorate, most recently delivered from Oxley. That message says that the Government is not a caring government, that this Government is using its powers not in the interests of the people. When we go forward to the next Federal election, there will undoubtedly be a change of government because the people deserve a fair go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Bill 1988. As the short title is not necessarily indicative of the contents of the Bill, I will read out the long title:

SPEECH.PARA: An Act to grant financial assistance to the States and the Northern Territory in connection with expenditure of a capital nature, to make loans to the States and the Northern Territory for public housing, to authorise the Commonwealth to borrow certain money, and for related purposes.

The question of public housing invites an examination of the balance between public and private housing in Australia today. It seems a fair assumption that if people can afford private housing they will take that option. The very sad fact that we face-and I would allege that this is as a consequence of this Government's policies-is that, as a percentage, fewer and fewer Australians can afford to go into private housing. The great Australian dream that used to become a reality some time in early adulthood is now staying a dream.

I noticed recently an article in the Adelaide Advertiser headed `Land release call to hold down prices' in which the point was made that a recent report indicated that 60 per cent of Australians might soon be unable to afford to buy their own homes. The so-called Australian dream will stay simply that, and no more. It will not become a reality for 60 per cent of the Australian population. Only 40 per cent of Australians, it is predicted at the moment, will be able to shift from the private rental market or public housing, wherever they may be in the early stages of their lives, into private housing. That is certainly a damning indictment of Government policies.

I am surprised to read that, as a consequence of that report, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said that `at this stage' Australia's level of home ownership remained amongst the highest in the world. He continued:
It may be the case that as you go into the future that people will want to make different decisions, different priorities and allocate more of their income to non-residential purposes.

The Prime Minister is saying that he expects Australians may want to shift away from private home ownership. I suggest the reason he says that is that he knows that under this Government only 40 per cent of Australians will be able to go into private home ownership. One does not need to be a gifted bookie or person who knows the figures to see that it is best to go with the 60 per cent-60 per cent of people will not be able to afford private home ownership.

It is a sad statement that, as a consequence of those figures, the Prime Minister is prepared to say that perhaps we should give that away anyway-give away the hope that a lot of Australians have when they get married and want to start a family that they will be able to afford their own home. I take that as an indication of the Government's commitment, or lack thereof, to trying to ensure that young Australians who have that aspiration are able to meet it; in other words, that young Australians who want to get married-or even if they do not-and who want to buy their own home will be able to do so. I see a lack of commitment from this Government towards that goal. The Prime Minister's remarks mean a lack of commitment towards private home ownership and that it is okay for a group of people to own the housing stock and for the majority of people to rent from those people-and the people who own the housing stock are the wealthy.

That invites reference to a genuine concern held by many in the community about the wealthy friends that this Government and senior Cabinet members allegedly have. One does not need to rely on rumours. We all hear the rumours about the Prime Minister and his rich mates and favours alleged to be done or otherwise. One does not need to rely on those to look at the point I am making about this Government's commitment to average Australians being able to afford things. One can go to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The Bureau will indicate that the share of gross income held by the top 10 per cent of the population has increased, while the average income of middle income groups has fallen in real terms. In other words, under this Government the rich are getting richer relatively and the poor are getting poorer.

In those circumstances it is absolutely no surprise that the Prime Minister believes that people may want to shift their priorities and not go into private housing. Because the poor are getting poorer and the rich are getting richer, fewer people can go into private housing. A comment that indicates that Australians should be happy with that situation means that we should all be happy that a limited number of people-not a small closetted group of friends of Cabinet Ministers, but the so-called rich: a very small proportion of the population-should be entitled to own the rental housing stock and that everybody else, every average Australian, can simply rent from those people. That is not what I call a fair vision for the housing situation. It is particularly sad because those income adjustments have been particularly felt by young workers and people in the older section of our community, those least able to accommodate economic changes.

When one considers housing questions and the views of people who are interested in housing and who write about it frequently, one sees that what I am saying is commonly acknowledged: Australians are finding it harder to put a roof over their heads as costs rise. Robert Hadler, in the Australian on 31 May this year, indicated that the fact that people were finding it harder to find the money to put a roof over their heads raised doubts about the effectiveness of government housing assistance.

We have been told that there has been a recent report by the Department of Community Services and Health. I believe that what I have said is the case, as do writers for different journals and daily papers. Now I wish to refer to what the Government believes to be the case on the basis of a report it has had undertaken through that Department. That report shows that a large number of Australians cannot satisfy their housing needs at a price they can afford. At least 60,000 people, the report alleges, are crowded into government accommodation designed for the otherwise homeless which has a capacity for only 11,000. Some 60,000 people are shoved into homes with a capacity for 11,000. It further shows that more than 165,000 applicants were listed on the public housing waiting lists of State authorities as of June last year. Between 200,000 and 400,000 families could have applied for public housing in 1984 but were unaware that they were eligible. Perhaps a speaker on the Government side might indicate what the Government has done about making people who are in a position to obtain government assistance aware of it.

It is not good enough to come into this House and pass laws providing for assistance if the people who are to benefit from those laws are not aware of the assistance that is available: it is just shallow talk in a chamber and shallow words in a Bill. If it does not touch people, if there is a low take-up rate of any sort of benefit offered by the Government, the Government has not done its job. We are told that over 700,000 households at that stage were in a position to apply for assistance but simply did not know they could do so. We are also told that, of those, 400,000 were renting privately, 180,000 were owners or purchasers, and 110,000 were public tenants.

There is probably no need for me to add, so I shall not do so, to the comments of Senator Bishop with respect to a Tasmanian senator in this place who, on a senator's salary and with his wife as a staffer, is still availing himself of a public housing benefit, undoubtedly to the detriment of someone else-just one of the 700,000 households waiting for assistance. Senator Devlin is taking up a space.

However, the situation has got far worse. In July, again in the Australian, Robert Hadler, a journalist obviously interested in this area, told his readers that the public housing waiting list had increased by 60 per cent in the past six years. It is difficult to think of some other indicator that would have risen by 60 per cent in that time. I am not an investor so I cannot say whether the price of diamonds, coffee or something else has risen by that amount, but I am reasonably confident that the consumer price index has not; yet the waiting list has. That information was provided through a draft report to the Economic Planning Advisory Council-EPAC-which states that the number of people unable to find rental accommodation in that period has risen by 65,000 from 97,000 in June 1981 to almost 162,000 in June 1987.

It is abundantly clear that, while the Government seems to have little commitment to private home ownership, the public rental situation is no better; in fact, it is getting worse. If one said, `It might be worse overall but at least we are looking after the poor', one would be telling a lie. A study was done by Professor Cliff Walsh of the University of Adelaide in my State as part of the national priorities project. The findings, which were released in May this year, indicate that the Government's social policy has failed because it effectively discriminates against low income private tenants. That is a very difficult finding for anybody in this chamber to be comfortable with-that Government policy effectively discriminates against low income private tenants. The study revealed that more than 15 per cent or 48,000 of 300,000 families in public housing and 210,000 families in the private rental market were below the poverty line after meeting housing costs.

One can see that this nation's housing problem is not being addressed by the Government. It is clear that it is not doing enough to encourage people into private housing. Numerous authorities have been cited not only by me but also by other speakers earlier in this debate, indicating that 60 per cent of Australians cannot now dream of having their own home. All the authorities say that, in respect of the other 40 per cent, both the private and public rental markets are in a gigantic mess as well. So where does a person go if he wants to put a roof over his head? Young Australians at secondary school, either going straight out to get a job or going to university before getting a job, and planning their lifestyle-how they will be living when they are 50 or 60-will not be planning to have a private home; they will be desperately worried about how they will rent one.

TALK.START.PARA: —They pinch the money out of your pay packet.

—As Senator Newman says, the Government pinches money out of their pay packets. Young people will be worried about how they will get a roof over their head because they will not be able to afford one. The odds are 60 to 40 against them in that respect. If they are in the 40 per cent they will have real trouble sorting themselves out.

SPEECH.PARA: The balance between public and private housing also raises the question of those who do not hope to have a roof over their head; namely, young homeless Australians. Government policy in this area has been universally ineffective. We have reached the stage where a lobby group called the Youth Homeless Allowance Reform Group has been established to put the view to the Government that the youths of Australia are not receiving the youth homeless allowance because the guidelines are peculiarly narrow, and that something has to be done about it. In my State of South Australia an inquiry into homeless children headed by the Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Brian Burdekin, was told a number of things. It was said that there were no simple answers to the growing problem of homeless children in South Australia but that if stopgap solutions were implemented now the problem could be dealt with. But nothing is being done. The narrowness of the Federal Government's job search allowance was said to be inadequate, and the young homeless allowance was said to be difficult to get. In other words, a creditable inquiry into the problem of homeless youth in South Australia indicates that Federal Government policy is not touching the mark. Some comments were made in that respect by the Service to Youth Council Director, Mr Mark Henley, who said that many of South Australia's estimated 500 street kids were missing out on the youth homeless allowance because of the guidelines laid down by the Government and, therefore, were living in poverty.

All of the articles to which I have referred are from earlier this year, but we see that the Government has taken little heed of the warning that has been offered. The Housing Industry Association has warned of yet another crisis for renters. It tells us that the Federal Government is risking the creation of another housing rental crisis in Sydney and Melbourne if it proceeds with a further tightening of monetary policy, and backs up those comments by statistics that it has released. It says that governments need to recognise that Australia is experiencing an unparalleled demand for housing following the buildup of pressure created by the combined effects of the abolition of negative gearing and the downturn in building activity in previous years. A Government speaker following me may care to address whether the Government agrees with the Housing Industry Association that we are facing another crisis for renters or whether the Government alleges that the Housing Industry Association is ill-informed, or perhaps acknowledge the problems raised by the Association and indicate some manner in which the Government is going to respond to the problems.

Having dealt with questions related specifically to housing problems, I conclude by making a few remarks about living standards in this country. Quite obviously, living standards affect people's capacity to go into private housing-that is, home ownership-and whether or not, if they cannot afford to own their own home, they will be in the private rental market or in public housing. Much has been made in recent weeks of the amount of money required to restore Australian families to their real disposable income level as it was in March 1983. This Government has had an increased tax take. That necessarily means less money for Australians to put towards housing. The family allowance and the dependent spouse rebate have fallen by about 40 per cent in real terms, so no assistance has been offered there to compensate for the problems with which Australians are faced.

Average youth unemployment has increased since March 1983 and that necessarily means there are more young Australians still at home, without a job and not paying board. Perhaps if they had a job they would be paying board or, better still, out making their own way in the community. Increased interest rates, home loan repayments and housing waiting lists have all come about since March 1983 and, more particularly, the number of families below the poverty line has increased since that time.

Let me give some figures on unemployment because unemployment levels obviously affect a person's capacity to buy a house and keep up mortgage payments. Under the Fraser Government the average monthly unemployment level was 403,000. Under the Hawke Government it is 631,000-a gigantic jump. If one does not want to look at specific figures but at rates, one sees that under Fraser the average monthly unemployment rate was 6.1 per cent and that under the Hawke Government it is now 8.5 per cent. The average monthly youth unemployment level has risen from 115,000 under Fraser to 130,000 under the Hawke Government. Perhaps we can be grateful that it is a rise of only 15,000, but it ought not be a rise at all: fewer young Australians should be unemployed. The average monthly youth unemployment rate went up from 18.6 per cent under Fraser-an unacceptable level, I admit-to 23.3 per cent under the Hawke Government. The number of people unemployed for more than a year went up from 143,000 in February 1983 to 153,400 this year. These figures indicate what has happened vis-a-vis employment and unemployment under this Government. That necessarily impacts upon the capacity of Australians to buy a house. It impacts upon their capacity to shift into either the private rental market or into the public housing area.

Obviously, the number of people who are employed in a household effects the household income and what can be put towards housing. If those who are unlucky enough to become unemployed think there is an easy way out they might like to consider this figure. If they think they can keep up with the mortgage payments, get a job reasonably soon, get back on the straight and narrow and keep their mortgage payments up they might like to consider that in March 1983 the average duration of unemployment for people seeking full time work was 35 weeks. This is not a good figure in itself. The concept of being unemployed for 35 weeks would be attractive to no-one. What is even less attractive is that in January 1988 under this Government the average duration of unemployment for people seeking full time work has risen to 56.2 weeks. Not only is the unemployment and employment situation a matter of concern, vis-a-vis the capacity to enter different sectors of the housing market, but also the duration of it has got far worse.

If people think the payments have gone down they should consider the figures with respect to home loan repayments. In March 1983 average monthly loan repayments were $545. The repayment, expressed as a percentage of income, was 19.2 per cent. This is quite a substantial amount. But what we see under this Government is that average monthly loan repayments have gone up from $455 in March 1983, when this Government came to office, to $666. The repayment as a percentage of income was 19.2 per cent when the Liberals left office. It has jumped to 27 per cent of income under this Government. Those figures basically tell the story of why there is a crisis in accommodation in this country. It is a sad story.

We hear much of how well our economy is going from the Treasurer (Mr Keating). He takes plenty of time to go overseas and tell people not only how good our economy is but also how they ought to run theirs. He might like to consider that the inflation rate has obviously had an effect on the capacity of people to enter into private housing. The inflation rate in 1987-88 was 7.1 per cent. The lower that gets the better. Anyone in this chamber would undoubtedly applaud the Government's attempts and achievements in reducing the inflation rate. Let us not forget that Australia's inflation rate is nearly double the average of Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries, that average being 3.8 per cent. It is more than double the rate of our major trading partners except for New Zealand While the Treasurer may have much to say about how well he thinks we are doing when we look at the situation on a comparative basis, we certainly have some problems.

We hear much of the Hawke Government's social justice policy and how it is going to take people out of poverty. The Government says, `If you are out of poverty you can afford to enter the private housing market'. What we do not hear from the Government is that the proportion of households living in poverty has risen from 11.5 per cent in 1982-83 when we last had a coalition government to 12.4 per cent in 1985-86. We do not hear the Government telling us that 60,000 people now live on the verge of homelessness and 40,000 people sleep in the open or in refuges. We do not hear it telling us that 28 per cent of people who are living below the poverty line have mortgages. The Government is very keen to tell us the good news but perhaps not so keen to tell us what the reality is.

In summary, what the Hawke Government has done with respect to housing is this: it has driven home ownership beyond the reach of low income families. It has invested heavily in public rental accommodation at the expense of home ownership assistance. It has completely disregarded the plight of low income private renters and it has created financial havoc in the State housing authorities with its incessant demand for more public rental units. On that basis one would have thought there would have been more Government speakers in this debate on the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Bill who would have taken the opportunity to address some of these problems and tell us how the Government is going to resolve them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As previous speakers have said we are debating the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Bill 1988 which follows on from the decisions which were made at the Loan Council meeting on 12 May between the Commonwealth and the States. It will provide $310.5m for capital grants to the States and the Northern Territory as interest free loans and loans with an interest rate of 4 1/2 per cent repayable over 53 years of a similar amount of $310.5m. The concessional loans at the 4 1/2 per cent interest rate must be used for public housing purposes. Whilst the Opposition will not oppose this Bill we must nevertheless take this opportunity to look at the problems that are facing the housing industry in the light of the Government's so far unsuccessful attempts to remedy them.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen 23 changes to the housing policy under this Government. Not only has this caused a lot of anguish and concern amongst young people but also it has provided for a very volatile and unstable situation in the housing area. As has been said by many previous speakers it is obvious to anyone who has examined the matter that there are now fewer young families who are able to afford to enter the private housing market. This has been caused by the rapid escalation of prices Australia-wide and naturally a similar rise in interest rates. The promises of the Keating-Hawke Government have not worked. In June this year housing interest rates rose from 13 1/2 per cent to 14 1/2 per cent. It has been widely agreed that since we have the Victorian election and the Oxley by-election out of the way we will find that that is just the tip of the iceberg and rises to the order of 15 1/2 per cent will soon become apparent. This will place a huge burden on young families who may be contemplating buying their own home at a time when they are rearing a family and having to cope with inflation which is pushing up the cost of living.

It has also been said earlier today that the concept of owning one's own home is not new to Australia. It has been an ambition of the ordinary man and woman in the street. It seems to have been forgotten by this Government. It is not an ambition that is motivated by greed or excessive want for capital possessions. It is merely an expectation of what people can readily believe they should be able to obtain through honest work and endeavours. It is this dream of expectation which is being shattered. When interest rates go up by the amounts which I have specified it will cost the average home owner $9 a week or $40 a month. To some of us that may not seem excessive but to many in the community that is going to be the final nail which will send them to the bankruptcy court and see them being forced to part with their most valuable asset.

There has been a lot of talk about the average family. It has been said that the average family is $56 a week worse off than when the present Government came to power. At the same time as we consider the plight of those who may be wishing to enter the private housing area we must also consider the 170,000 Australians who are now waiting to get onto the public housing lists. They face a wait of at least two years, and in many cases up to five years. They face that wait because they simply cannot afford to enter the private housing market. Amazingly, the Government has chosen to combat this problem by reducing the amount of money which is spent in the private housing market and increasing the amount which is spent on public housing. In 1983-84 we saw 67 per cent of Commonwealth funds spent on public housing and 31 per cent on private housing. By the time we got around to 1986-87, 77 per cent was spent on public housing and 22 per cent on private housing.

It seems to me that the Government is making an ongoing rod for its own back by forcing people to become dependent on government handouts. We have in this community proud, independent Australians who are prepared to support themselves and to be their own masters. Yet they are being forced to become dependent on the Government at a cost which must be borne by the Australian taxpayer. There is a need for public housing. That need will always be there, and the coalition acknowledges that need. What we do question is why that group which needs public housing should be an evergrowing one because of this Government's policies.

I come now to the first home owners scheme, which has been touched on by other speakers in this debate. This is a most worthwhile program. However, here again the Government's record is abysmal. The Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry has ascertained that over the last three years new housing starts have fallen 60,000 to 70,000 homes below the demand for new dwellings. At the same time the latest survey on home ownership affordability by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and the Housing Industry Association shows that the annual disposable income of the average Australian family is now $5,000 below the disposable income needed to qualify for a loan to purchase the average home.

I would now like briefly to take the opportunity to address the housing dilemma as it applies to the people of Tasmania. There has been a lot of discussion here today about one of our colleagues from Tasmania. I would prefer to talk about the situation as it occurs in Tasmania today regarding our Tasmanian Government policy. It is a problem which I am proud to say the Tasmanian Liberal Government has been prepared to face head on. It has bitten the bullet and has introduced a scheme whereby Housing Department rents are now related to income. While there may be many people in public housing homes with a genuine need, circumstances change. The Tasmanian Government, through its initiatives, has sought to ensure that only the most needy receive assistance and that those people who can afford to do so pay market rents. The Tasmanian State Liberal Government also is actively encouraging Tasmanian families to purchase previously rented public housing-as it appears Senator Devlin has tried to do. The Tasmanian Liberal Government is providing every support in that regard. To me it seems ironical that the Tasmanian Labor Party Opposition has been very critical of this scheme. One has to ask why that is so. Those brave measures that our State Government has taken will free up additional funds to assist those people in genuine need. I commend the Tasmanian Government for these decisions because I believe that they are the right ones to make.

It seems peculiar that in Question Time today when I asked Senator Walsh a question about the assistance for rural children in education he said that he felt it was only fit and right to apply an assets test to rural families-I think with assets over $300,000-so that those families would not be seen to be rorting the assistance that was given by the Federal Government. However, on the other hand, we do not hear anything about an assets test for those people who are going into public housing. Under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement the unique nature of Tasmania's situation has been acknowledged previously by an allocation of special funds. This meant that in 1981-82 Tasmania's share was around 6 per cent. Unfortunately, since that time this uncaring Federal Government has introduced funding on a per capita basis. This will culminate in 1991. Therefore, Tasmania's share of funds has been reducing. In 1987-88 it was $26.2m and in 1988-89 it will go down to something like $24.4m. I do not need to remind Tasmanians that over the last 12 months the Federal Government's assistance to them has reduced by something like $424m. The Federal Government has made a lot of bleating noises acknowledging that the per capita basis disadvantages Tasmania, but as far as I am aware it has not been prepared to do anything about it. I would think that it would be up to the Government senators from Tasmania to inquire why that has not happened.

It is about time the Government took into consideration the special needs of Tasmania because its record in that regard is certainly not a proud one. There are now approximately 4,000 people in Tasmania on waiting lists for government housing. Compared with the numbers in some of our larger States, that number does not seem to represent a lot of people. However, let me say that for Tasmania's population this is a very depressing number of people. I know that, since my election to this House, one of the most disturbing aspects of my work has been the ongoing number of people who contact my office seeking housing assistance. I know that my colleague in the other place Bruce Goodluck has nearly 50 per cent of his time taken up with assisting people in public housing as much as he can. Many of these people have been forced out of the private market. Certainly, they would be more than happy to pay their own way if they had the opportunity.

The other day I heard of a person who went into a private bank in Tasmania and asked whether he could make an appointment to discuss borrowing funds to build a house. The bank manager said, `What col- lateral have you got?'. He said, `I have not got any, but I have a very good job'. The manager said, `Where do you work?'. He said, `I do not work. I am on unemployment benefit and have four children, so I pull in something in excess of $500 a fortnight tax free. My wife gets an invalid pension which brings in another $270-odd a fortnight. Of course, that is tax free. Therefore, I think that I am a pretty good risk'. Unfortunately, he did not get the loan. But he went to one of our government institutions and received the money at 8 per cent so that he could go into private housing. That is a ludicrous situation when we have young families on average incomes who cannot raise the extra few dollars to enable them to go into private housing. It must be heartbreaking for them, when they scrimp and save, to see unemployed people, unfortunate unemployed people, who have a very good opportunity to own their own homes, or at least to get a subsidised rental.

Finally, I must say that I am extremely proud to be part of a coalition which has as its housing policy a commitment to assist the many thousands of young Australian families who are prepared to have a go. It is a policy which unashamedly seeks to remove an unnecessary burden from the government coffers by helping those people who need that little bit of assistance to get on their feet. Our policy today has been spelt out very well by Senator Bishop and previously by Senator Vanstone. Our policy is not a sell-out of those people who genuinely need public housing, because our commitment to them remains.
