SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Governor-General Amendment Bill 1988 will increase the salary payable to the Governor-General designate when he takes office in February 1989. That salary has been set in the Bill at $95,000, which will be tax free in accordance with the provisions of the Constitution. It is interesting that in the second reading speech the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) noted that there has been a substantial increase in salary since the first salary was fixed at $30,000 in 1974. In 1977 the salary was amended to $37,000 by the then Fraser Government. It was increased to $70,000 in 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has no complaint about this procedure in the sense that it is necessary by the Constitution to set a salary level in order to provide for the cost of living increases during the term of office of the incoming Governor-General. That means that the salary first decided upon, which is provided in this Bill, must equate with the salary level of the Governor-General at the time his term of office expires, which is some five years hence. Consequently, because of cost of living increases over that period, it is clear that the averaging of that salary requirement must be determined in a way that may seem to be at a level somewhat higher than usual at the outset to meet that constitutional requirement when the contract expires.

On behalf of the Liberal and National parties, I take this opportunity of expressing our appreciation of the service of the present Governor-General, Sir Ninian Stephen, and Lady Stephen in their time in office since early 1983. I am sure that all Australian citizens have been encouraged by the activities of the Governor-General and Lady Stephen since they took up that position. They have travelled this country, made themselves known to citizens at all levels, and have taken a deep interest in the affairs of the nation. It is clear that they have earned the profound respect of all Australians, and by their dignified and yet informal and friendly presence have generated a very deep feeling of warmth from the Australian people. Certainly we here in Canberra, who have some opportunity of coming into personal contact with them on a number of occasions, can testify to the warm regard that people in political circles have for the present Governor-General and Lady Stephen. The Opposition thanks them for their service to Australia in this most important position since 1983. We believe they have established beyond doubt a very high level of behaviour on the part of the Governor-General which all Australians should take as an example and seek to emulate in every possible way.

The future of the Governor-General designate, Mr Bill Hayden, is yet to unfold as he will take office in the early part of 1989. The recent by-election in the seat of Oxley, which was brought about as a result of Mr Hayden's vacation of that seat, bore testimony to the popularity of the Hawke Government and showed a 13 per cent swing in favour of the Liberal candidate and against the Australian Labor Party. I guess that says something about the Government's actions in seeking to take advantage of a political position that existed in order to set down a new set of standards for the appointment of a Governor-General.

There is no doubt that the recently announced trip of the Governor-General designate overseas, at a cost to the Australian taxpayer, of some $80,000, had something to do with the result in the Oxley by-election, but it was probably not the total impact. There is no doubt that the Hawke Government's policies on living standards and driving down real wage levels in this country had a deal more to do with that. Nevertheless, the Opposition would be remiss in its duty if it did not note the widespread concern among the Australian people not only in Oxley but all over the country about the rampant rort, if you like, of granting a taxpayer funded trip to wherever the Governor-General designate may choose to go in the next few months. I am sure many Australians are concerned about that, and that it remains very much in their minds as they think about the political and other activities of this Government.

It is interesting to note that in an article that appeared in today's Sydney Morning Herald the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was reported as having no knowledge of the itinerary that the Governor-General designate was seeking to undertake in his overseas tour in the next few months. Apparently a journalist inquired of the Prime Minister what he thought the Governor-General designate would be doing, and Mr Hawke was unable to provide any details of Mr Hayden's schedule during his seven-country tour. In fact, despite already having had 42 trips overseas as Foreign Minister, he appears to have a personal itinerary, and very few arrangements have been organised by our missions overseas for Mr Hayden to engage in official business. That is something about which Australian concern should be, and is properly being, generated in the light of Mr Hawke's encouragement of Mr Hayden to take this trip, and his granting of it, apparently to satisfy his own feelings of guilt about having stabbed Mr Hayden in the back in 1983 by taking the leadership of the Labor Party from him. I think that remains a very severe doubt in the minds of the Australian people as they see about $80,000 going from the public purse in respect of a trip overseas being engaged upon by the Governor-General designate, Mr Hayden. It is clear from the article today in the Sydney Morning Herald that the Australian High Commission in London has been told that the visit to be undertaken by Mr Hayden is a semi-private one and that, while he will be meeting the Queen as the Governor-General designate, he will be undertaking private matters and functions after that. So there appears to be very little official reason for his undertaking this trip overseas.

I again reiterate our gratitude to the present Governor-General, Sir Ninian Stephen, and Lady Stephen for the service they have given Australia in their 5 1/2 years in office. They have served this country well. We wish them all the best for their retirement after concluding their term of office in February and hope that they enjoy a long and happy time together from there on. We hope and pray that the incoming Governor-General will indeed provide us with the kind of example provided by Sir Ninian and Lady Stephen, and we look forward to a continuing relationship with the Governor-General when he takes up his office in February, as of course we intend to form a government after the next election and will need to cooperate and work with him after that time. The Opposition supports the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Governor-General Amendment Bill, which deals with the salary of the next Governor-General. It must seem somewhat odd to quite a number of people in the community that these types of Bills appear here. It is the case that the Governor-General, in the absence of the Queen overseas, is the head of state and, as the head of state, obviously functions in a way which is quite different from the way that governments, political parties and other people function.

SPEECH.PARA: In that regard I think it is important to note that the Governor-General's salary is set once and once only. Hence, as Senator Messner has already said, it tends to get struck at a level which seems to be somewhat excessive at the beginning but of course at the end tends to look slightly low, particularly for a person such as Sir Ninian Stephen, who has served so long and so well in that office.

The method by which the Governor-General's salary is set is essentially to get some type of parity with that of the Chief Justice. The Chief Justice's salary is set through the Remuneration Tribunal method, in which various items are taken into account, including the cost of living, amongst others, but also the high office that the Chief Justice of the High Court holds. I think it is appropriate, therefore, that the salary for the head of state should be reflective of the office, that is, the highest office in the land.

Looking back over previous increases, since 1974, when the Act originally came in, the salary has been increased three times-the first time, under the Fraser Government in 1977, by 23 per cent. It was next increased in 1983, again by the Fraser Government-an increase of 89 per cent. Now we are dealing with an increase of 35 per cent. The percentage increases are always somewhat staggering in comparison to others, but I think it is important to bear in mind that the Governor-General's salary is increased once and once only.

The Governor-General's salary will be of the order of $95,000. That is slipping somewhat compared with the parity arrangement that was originally intended, because the salary of the Chief Justice of Australia is now in excess of $123,000. We now find ourselves in a situation in which, next time round, there is probably going to have to be another significant increase in the Governor-General's salary.

As Mr Bill Hayden is the Governor-General designate, I think it is probably relevant, certainly to the community, in looking at these matters to note that the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act also comes into play, because the Governor-General is indeed classified as an office of profit under the Crown. Some people may find it somewhat difficult to understand how the Crown ends up as an office of profit under the Crown, but indeed it is, according to the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act. The fact of the matter is that, since the amendments which were made a couple of years ago, the Governor-General has not been able to have the full benefit of the parliamentary pension for the period that he remains in the office. A person who has served as a Minister for as long as Bill Hayden has obviously would be on a fairly high level in terms of the pension he would be able to draw.

This matter has been one of some contention within the general community. It is for that reason that I wanted to outline where this salary has been struck, the reasons it was struck at that particular level, and why my party will be supporting the legislation to enable that salary to be struck at what has to be, in the general community's terms, a high level, but one which surely must be seen to be appropriate for the highest office in the land.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to commence by paying tribute to the outstanding service provided to the nation by Sir Ninian and Lady Valerie Stephen. I entirely endorse the remarks of my colleague Senator Messner. Without doubt, over recent years the nation has been very well served indeed by the fine work that has been undertaken by Sir Ninian and Lady Stephen. In very difficult circumstances, and certainly in almost onerous physically circumstances, I think they have performed wonderfully well.

SPEECH.PARA: The salary of the Governor-General would normally not be a matter of controversy. However, one can only be concerned that the recent behaviour of the Governor-General designate is putting at risk the traditional bipartisan community support for this high office. Indeed, Mr Hayden's indecent pursuit of the perquisites of office and his desperate anxiety to turn a last dollar before next February raise the question of what standards of conduct should accompany such a substantial increase in salary.

It is imperative that the Governor-General, or anyone about to assume that high office, be like Caesar's wife-not only above suspicion, but seen to be so. The office of Governor-General should be occupied only by someone whose conduct and standards of ethical behaviour are beyond reproach. In this context I consider it singularly inappropriate for Mr Hayden to persist in a defamation action which he has recently brought against Wesgo Communications Pty Ltd, the licensees of radio station 4KQ. The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune often assail politicians. Those who have been in the kitchen for almost 30 years, as has Mr Hayden, inevitably get their fair share, not least when they are being remorselessly pursued and denigrated by an aspiring Prime Minister who, in his immortal assessment of his then leader, not only accused Mr Hayden of mendacity, but also predicted a very limited future. This was an accurate assessment of Mr Hayden's prospects of holding onto the office of leader. Perhaps it also led to pangs of guilt sufficient to offer the choicest of plums to a mortally wounded comrade.

But would the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) suggest that the current reputation of Mr Hayden has in any way been tarnished in recent months so as to hold him up to hatred, ridicule or contempt? Could it be seriously suggested that Mr Hayden's reputation needs restoration by an award of damages? Otherwise, presumably, the Government would never have considered appointing a person with a diminished reputation to such an exalted office. I do not for one moment want to debate the merits of the litigation, but Mr Hayden's determination to pursue the matter clearly puts the court and his soon to be assumed office in an impossible situation. Even Mr Hayden's own legal advisers concede that it would be inappropriate for a Governor-General to give evidence in any court of law as the titular head of the judicial system, hence their successful application for a speedy hearing.

It is just as inappropriate for Mr Hayden to put his own credibility on the line shortly before assuming office. It puts the courts in an impossible situation. If a judge disbelieves Mr Hayden or rejects even part of his evidence, Mr Hayden's fitness for office will be fatally undermined. If the judge finds in his favour, there is very real risk that there will be a widespread public perception that the courts had little choice. This is unfair to the litigants, to the judiciary, to the monarchy and to the Australian community. Mr Hayden should, therefore, immediately discontinue this indecent pursuit of one last dollar, as if $95,000 net is not enough. If not, the Prime Minister should order him to do so.

I am also concerned that, instead of undertaking the proper preparation and fam- iliarisation procedures, Mr Hayden is seeking access to sensitive Government documents concerning his terms as a Minister in the Hawke and Whitlam governments, with a view to writing his memoirs. Mr Hayden has given no public undertaking not to publish or use this material during his term of office. Anyone who can jettison deeply held anti-monarchist sentiments of a lifetime for 30 pieces of Yarralumla silver cannot be trusted to resist the temptation to make use of such material, at least in retaliation for real or imagined wrongs. Instead of swanning around the world, Mr Hayden has had the perfect opportunity to spend six months at home putting pen to paper. Instead he has chosen to put his snout in the trough, in a manner so offensive to public sensitivities that he has now been seized upon as a convenient scapegoat by his erstwhile organisational colleagues such as Mr Hogg and Mr Loosley. Indeed, Mr Hogg said last Sunday:

. . . if we are asking for restraint and co-operation from the community, we have to ourselves, as a government and as individuals, behave similarly . . . So I think bluntly, people appearing to be putting their snout in the public trough gets a bit wearying and I think we deserved an element of the response we got this weekend.
Mr Hogg was even driven to concede:
I think there was a lack of sensitivity displayed by the people in even contemplating it.

That is quite clearly a direct reflection on Mr Hawke's judgment because, as we know, a Governor-General or a Governor-General designate is not allowed to leave this country without the express approval of the Prime Minister, and the expenses associated with that travel would similarly need to be approved by the Prime Minister. Mr Hogg, by way of delivering a stinging rebuke and looking for a scapegoat, is suggesting that it was an appalling display of insensitivity on the part of the Prime Minister. Mr Loosley, who no doubt is also regarded as an electoral guru, said that the adverse publicity had `caused us greater damage than anything else'. No doubt that is the classic rationalisation, hoping to find some sort of one-off explanation for a result which is otherwise a devastating indictment of the Labor Government.

The fact remains that these people in senior positions in the Australian Labor Party, and therefore in the party of government, have chosen publicly to bag the Governor-General designate. I regard that as a reflection of the esteem in which he is no longer held and of the concern, even in an electoral sense, that Mr Hayden has become lead in the saddle bags. His outrageous and self-indulgent rort makes Mick Young's Qantas appointment appear a mere peccadillo. We know that a number of officials from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet expressed concern to the Secretary to the Department, but we do not as yet know whether that concern was communicated to the Prime Minister.

The dissembling nonsense that has been used to justify Mr Hayden's trip has, I think, been exposed very graphically in recent days. It is clear from what my colleague Senator Messner had to say about the piece in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald, that there are very many unanswered questions. We do not know, for example, who authorised the detail of the trip. It would seem it is simply an agenda chosen by Mr Hayden at his own instigation. We do not know what proportion of the visit, if any, constitutes official engagements other than, presumably, a cursory visit to Buckingham Palace, which one would have thought could occupy less than a day.

The drover's dog has become a grubby gold digger. The recent Oxley by-election result is a deafening public demonstration of outrage in Mr Hayden's latest savage assault on the public purse. I believe that the Prime Minister's actions in giving carte blanche in this manner are an outrageous abdication of responsibility, a further display of monumental arrogance. This is not just another demonstration of jobs for the boys but, indeed, the ultimate perk. I believe the Government, in allowing Mr Hayden to carry on in the way he has, has done a great disservice to the very high office of Governor-General. The Australian people can only hold their breath in the hope that somehow Mr Hayden is going to reform before it is too late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take only one or two minutes to speak on the Governor-General Amendment Bill 1988. I commence by passing on my gratitude, and that of many South Australians, for the work done by Sir Ninian and Lady Stephen. My heart is warmed by the remarks of Senator Alston, which on those matters I am familiar with I wholeheartedly endorse. We now have the spectre of someone who was a republican jettisoning his views for, as Senator Alston says, 30 pieces of Yarralumla silver, and going a bit further to put his snout in the trough for yet another overseas trip to familiarise himself with that which we assume he is already familiar. In that process he has become a convenient scapegoat for Labor with respect to its loss in Oxley. I believe that the vote in Oxley is in part an indication of what Australians think of this whole tawdry affair.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to draw attention to some historical matters. A similar Bill was debated in this chamber in 1977, when Senator Button, now Leader of the Government in the Senate-and I invite the Minister at the table, the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), when he responds to address these points-had this to say:
My point is that it is a very large sum of money to pay for a figurehead when I, speaking as one member of the Senate, do not really know what he does.
Perhaps Ministers of the Government now do know what the Governor-General does. Senator Button went on to say:
Perhaps the Government had to pay $37,000-
as it then was-

tax free to get the new Governor-General. Perhaps nobody was prepared to accept at the lower salary. It may be an attraction rate, but in terms of cost-benefit consideration, a great deal of the taxpayers' money is being expended to maintain the institution.

Perhaps the Minister would like to respond about whether he thinks that view is now appropriate, or is Labor now prepared to pay more money because one of its mates has the job? Senator Button went even further. He said:
I think that, as a result of the presentation of this legislation which gives a handout-
that was Senator Button's description-
to the office of Governor-General, honourable senators opposite-
that is, my party-
who are so sensitive about decadent institutions in this country, including the office of Governor-General . . .
I invite the Minister now in charge-the tables have turned-to address the remarks made by Senator Button at that time. Do they now represent the view of Government Ministers?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to this debate. Whilst I did not hear Senator Messner's contribution in full, I join with him and other speakers in their sentiments towards the current Governor-General and his spouse for the job they have done in this country in the last seven years. They have brought great distinction to the role they have played and they have made many friends for Australia in their activities in that position over those seven years.

SPEECH.PARA: A few matters have been raised. Senator Alston raised the fact that Governor-General designate Hayden is involved in a defamation case. I do not believe anyone should have to forgo his rights, if he has been defamed, to have his record properly corrected. It is always awkward in circumstances such as this when an appointment is announced well in advance--
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator ROBERT RAY

TALK.START.PARA: —I was reflecting on the comments of Senator Alston about the defamation case. It is never an easy task to say that someone has to forgo all his rights.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Alston-Does he really need the money?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston interjects that he needs the money. That is his assumption, not mine. Senator Alston criticises Mr Hayden on the basis that he might like to do some writing in office. My memory tells me that Sir Paul Hasluck did some writing when he was in office. He was a superb historian. I think the Governor of Western Australia also does writing in office. I hate to see people not occupy what is spare time-not other time-without following those particular pursuits.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator ROBERT RAY

TALK.START.PARA: —When one is as thick as Senator Alston one probably has to work 18 hours a day to keep up with it. Some people can manage to do their work in 12 hours and then, in three or four spare hours before they go to sleep, write a diary or a book. It is a form of relaxation. I accept some of his criticism but I think he is being extreme in some of the criticisms that he has voiced tonight. The Opposition bleats that Bill Hayden has his snout in the trough and that he is swanning around the world. What a load of hypocrisy coming from those opposite! I remember only a year ago the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard)--

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Alston-Are you disowning Bob Hogg's words?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator ROBERT RAY

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am not supporting what Bob Hogg said on this. Clearly I am not; otherwise I would not be on my feet saying this. Senator Alston, as has Senator Vanstone by imputation, has thrown up the snouts in the trough argument. I recall that only last year the instability within the Liberal Party meant Mr Howard had to forgo his trip as Leader. As Minister, what did I get? I got a pleading letter which said, `Please, can I have two trips next year?'. Honourable senators opposite talk about snouts in the trough. What a bunch of mealy mouthed hyprocrites they are. On the basis of precedent, he had the right to take that trip. Senator Alston has the right to criticise it but when he gets to the point of talking about snouts in the trough he ought to look at his own side of politics. I have no idea how he can say it without being red faced.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Alston referred to this job as the ultimate perk. (Quorum formed) Labor governments have, I think, appointed four Governors-General-three of them in controversy. When we appointed Sir Isaac Isaacs as Governor-General our conservative opponents opposite-the Liberal Party's political forebears-bitterly attacked us, saying that we should never have had someone who was Australian born. We set the precedent.
Senator Alston-Are we guilty of the sins of our forefathers?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator ROBERT RAY

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course you are. History repeats itself. I am just pointing out that the conservatives were bitterly critical of Sir Isaac Isaacs, who went on to perform an excellent job. Sure, he was actively involved in politics in the early 1900s and then went to the High Court of Australia.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Hamer-He was not a Liberal.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator ROBERT RAY

TALK.START.PARA: —He was a conservative. He was not particularly liberal in any of his views, not as liberal as Justice Higinbotham. When we then appointed Governor-General McKell--

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Alston-We have not quarrelled with that.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator ROBERT RAY

TALK.START.PARA: —But the then Opposition criticised him at the time. There was another storm when we appointed him. In fact when one looks at Sir William McKell's history as Governor-General, we see that he served this country well. He went by the precedents; he did not embarrass us. All criticism at the time would no longer be heard. We then appointed Sir John Kerr to the position. Honourable senators opposite did not criticise us. We should have known we were wrong when they did not criticise us. We should have woken up at the time. We have now appointed Bill Hayden and again they are critical. They say that this person has been active in politics. He has been no more active than Lord Casey and Paul Hasluck were.

INTERJECT.PARA: People have criticised, to some extent, the salary rise. When Sir John Kerr was appointed he received a 50 per cent pay rise; three years later Sir Zelman Cowan received a 23 per cent increase; five years later Sir Ninian Stephen received an 89 per cent increase; seven years later Mr Hayden is to receive a 35 per cent increase. Of course, there were differential inflation rates in those days thanks to those opposite. That would explain the 35 per cent compared to the 89 per cent
Senator Alston-We have not quarrelled with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston says he does not quarrel with that so I will leave it there. The final point, that raised by Senator Vanstone, was about Senator Button's views. She did not give the date on which he expressed those--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator ROBERT RAY

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the strange thing about politics: honourable senators opposite never change their ideas; we do. We go through a maturation period. It is not a matter of lack of principle: we adapt with the times. Our views on a whole range of matters have changed since 1977. Big surprise! None of their views have changed. At the time Senator Alston was still swanning around dozens of seats looking for preselection. It took him about 10 years because he was not adaptable. He never changed his views. There he is on the side of the chamber where life after death prevails. I do not believe that Senator Button would be embar- rassed by his comments in 1977. He changes his views from time to time. They are not holy writ. I do not hold Senator Alston to his views on McKell or, for that matter, Isaacs. I just point out that when there is controversy in the initial period the results are quite often different. In my view, Bill Hayden is well qualified to be Governor-General.

INTERJECT.PARA: This Bill is necessary. By the Constitution, we must set a salary in advance. We all agree that salaries should not be altered during the term of office. We agree with the rough differential in our salary and that of the Chief Justice of the High Court. We are not disagreeing on much. Honourable senators opposite have just used this debate as a vehicle to have another go at resurrecting the Oxley by-election. I have been sitting in the chamber for a couple of days hearing all about the Oxley by-election but I have never heard about the Victorian State election. Whilst I would like to give honourable senators a long and detailed analysis on the Victorian State election, I would be abusing my position if I did so. I would hate to do that. Maybe I will come back at the end of the four adjournment speeches to give a speech on that.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS BILL 1988INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1988

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering the Industrial Relations Bill 1988 as a whole. Before the Committee reported progress, it was considering an amendment moved by Senator Chapman to clause 264. The question is that that amendment be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I seek leave to withdraw that amendment to clause 264 and substitute an alternative amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; amendment withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 131, after clause 264, insert the following clause:
Liability for arrears

``264a. (1) Where a person has ceased to be eligible to become a member of an organisation and that person has not actively participated in the affairs of the organisation since that time, those circumstances shall be a defence to an action by the organisation for arrears of dues payable from the time when the person ceased to be so eligible.
``(2) Where such a defence is successful, that person shall be deemed to have ceased to be a member from the time that the person ceased to be so eligible.''

This alternative amendment achieves the goal which the Opposition was seeking in the earlier amendment which we were debating when debate was interrupted and progress was reported. I will not reiterate the arguments that I put at that time. They are well established. I simply urge the Committee to support this amendment.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 38, clause 93, line 29, at end of clause add ``but nothing in this section shall prevent the Commission from making such decisions or taking such actions, under this Act, as are necessary to protect females with regard to the lifting or moving, with or without assistance, of heavy weights or things in the course of their employment.''.
Clause 93 provides:

In the performance of its functions, the Commission shall take account of the principles embodied in the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 and the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 relating to discrimination in relation to employment.

Because of the time, I do not propose to go into this matter in any great detail. But honourable senators will recall that I have previously raised in this chamber my concern that the provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act could possibly affect industrial awards and the provisions of State legislation relating to the protection of women in regard to the lifting of weights. At the moment provisions in certain State legislation limit to 16 kilograms the lifting of weights by women. My concern, therefore, is that the new Australian Industrial Relations Commission's awards will not override the Sex Discrimination Act in this regard.

As I said, there are State regulations in respect of the lifting of weights, which provisions protect women. Those regulations exempt that legislation from the provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act. I might say that there is an urgent need for the Government to make this exemption definite in legislation because I think those exemptions operate until only about August of next year.
I was concerned that the new Commission may not be able to award a protective provision for women in respect of the lifting or moving of weights. Therefore, my amendment reads:

Page 38, clause 93, line 29, at end of clause add ``but nothing in this section shall prevent the Commission from making such decisions or taking such actions, under this Act, as are necessary to protect females with regard to the lifting or moving, with or without assistance, of heavy weights or things in the course of their employment.''.
I am now advised-and the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) may well confirm this-that that is not necessary, particularly as this provision is now contained in this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —We note Senator Harradine's concerns about protecting the occupational health and safety of workers. That concern is, of course, both recognised and applauded. The Government is not inclined to support the amendment-in fact, we will oppose it. We believe that the amendment is based on the wrong premise that the provisions in the Act will bind the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The advice that we have, which I can pass on to the Committee, is that the Sex Discrimination Act will not bind the proposed Commission in the carrying out of its primary functions. A number of general obligations set out in clauses 90 to 98 of the Bill provide that the Commission will act, for instance, in the public interest, and take into account State and Territory occupational health and safety legislation and so on. But they do not bind the Commission. The principle the Government is following is to allow the Commission in the fulfilment of its primary functions under clause 89-those functions being of course, to prevent and settle industrial disputes and associated matters-as much flexibility as possible. To that extent, Senator Harradine's concern is not well founded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, in view of the Minister's explanation, I seek leave to withdraw my amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; amendment withdrawn.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1988

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 43, Schedule 2, proposed amendment of the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act 1978, after proposed subsection 53 (2), insert the following new subsection:

`` `(2a) Until provision to the contrary is made by an Act, the powers of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission do not extend to employment in respect of which a tribunal established by an enactment before 1 July 1978 has power to hear and determine disputes, claims or matters relating to the terms and conditions of the employment.'.''.

These amendments, which are of a minor technical nature, are pretty well self-explanatory.

Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bills reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Bills be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the reasons I wish to speak is to find out whether I still have a voice. I also wish to thank Senator Grant Chapman for stepping into the breach and for dealing with the balance of the Bills during the period that I found speaking rather difficult. If I might comment on the position we have now reached, it is clear that we have now concluded our substantive discussions on the industrial relations legislation. It is a matter of regret that the Government refused to accept 40 of the 41 amendments moved by the Opposition. It seemed to me that this was the fairly standard attitude, that the legislature has no role in shaping appropriate laws, in this case industrial relations laws. The basis of the Government's approach was that all wisdom resides in the Government. That attitude clearly is nonsense, although I must say in fairness that history suggests that governments have often taken that view in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian public should be aware that both the Government and the Australian Democrats, in the course of the committee debate, voted against voluntary unionism and an end to the closed shop. They voted against giving the Industrial Relations Commission effective powers to enforce its decisions, yet the Government was even voting against the measures it proposed last year. They voted against preventing the payment of strike pay. They voted against preserving State anti-strike laws. They voted against direct dealing between employers and employees at the enterprise level. They voted against having as an object of the Act the promotion of industrial harmony and cooperation between employees and employers. They voted against having as an object of the Act maintaining the rule of law in industrial relations. They voted against having in the Act provisions that would encourage the promotion of single enterprise bargaining units. They voted against employees having a greater say about the structure of unions which represent them. That is a fairly gloomy list.

If I may say so more cheerfully, I think that pressures on the Australian economy are producing some of the necessary changes to industrial relations. The Opposition amendments would have facilitated the enterprise-based approach which must inevitably emerge and which I believe many Ministers in the present Government understand must emerge. An opportunity for substantial reform has been lost. The Government precluded effective scrutiny by the Senate by threatening the Democrats that the Government would withdraw the Bill if any substantial amendments were carried. It is a pity that the Democrats succumbed to this crude blackmail.

I am sure we shall have further debates on industrial relations in this chamber. There is no matter which is more vital to getting Australia out of its present debt and to ensuring that we can get Australian living standards on the rise again. I regret that the opportunities for substantial reform proposed in the Opposition amendments were lost.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a third time.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Multilateralism-Calder Highway-Duke and Duchess of York-Compensation: Commonwealth Employees

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to talk about multilateralism. I am glad that Senator Chaney is still present in the chamber because I am directing my comments at Senator Chaney-not exclusively at him but also at various of his colleagues who continue to misrepresent my position as a unilateralist. They seem to take delight in calling me by that label, so I want to talk a little about the definitions of multilateralism as opposed to unilateralism. I hope that I can clear this up. If I continue to be misrepresented in this matter, I shall respond with the following explanation in full each time it occurs.

SPEECH.PARA: Multilateralism, so far as I understand it, in the sense of disarmament is about mutual and verifiable reduction of nuclear weapons. That is the position that I support, and what I am working towards. I am not working towards unilateralism, which is an expectation that one side will lay down its arms regardless of what its opponents do. That makes no sense whatever to me, just as it makes no sense whatever to Senator Chaney and his colleagues, so we would have to agree on that. Unilateralism in disarmament is a nonsense. Multilateralism obviously is best dealt with in international fora such as the United Nations, in particular the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva, which is specifically set up for that purpose. It involves the two superpowers, but of course is not exclusively the domain of the nuclear powers. It involves 42 countries, and it is very appropriate that many countries in both the two major power blocs and outside are involved in the multilateral disarmament discussions. It is there that the details are fleshed out and conditions are put upon the various powers as they move towards disarmament.

I am very pleased that the first real nuclear disarmament agreement in history has been signed and is now under way. I refer to the intermediate-range nuclear force agreement. That came about in the Conference on Disarmament, where all those nations were working together for that purpose. Obviously Australia has a role to play in that, and at the Conference on Disarmament the Australian Government is very well represented by its disarmament team. We have been instrumental in helping in that process. That is a very appropriate role for Australia to play. We need to be careful of the two major players in the nuclear stakes-the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the United States-working on disarmament agreements exclusive of all other countries. Even though they have the greatest stake in this or the greatest nuclear arsenals, certainly everybody in every country of the world is involved. There is a real need for other countries to be involved.

There is a place for unilateral initiatives. This is where Senator Chaney and his colleagues need to be very clear. I support some countries taking unilateral initiatives, which is quite different from saying that one supports unilateral disarmament. Unilateral initiatives have been very effective when one side or the other has taken a position and enacted a disarmament procedure and has then been followed by the other side. The best known example would be the United States decision to stop testing in the atmosphere in 1963, which led the Soviets to follow and the partial test ban treaty was put in place. Also, in 1972 President Nixon of the United States decided to stop biological weapons production, and this also was followed by the Soviets. There is a real place for independent initiatives on one side or the other, which often lead to the adversary following suit.

In the case of Great Britain unilateralism makes some sense because British nuclear weapons were originally designed to be a status symbol, largely because the United Kingdom was frozen out of the nuclear weapons development program after World War II. It was much the same with the French. So those countries believe very strongly in their independent nuclear deterrents. In the whole balance of nuclear weapons in the arsenals of East and West, if the French and the British were to decide on unilateral disarmament initiatives it would not make a great deal of difference to the power play between the two major players.

It is also important to note that those two countries are not holding on to their nuclear weapons as a deterrent, because the real deterrence, if one believes in that-and I do not believe in that theory in regard to nuclear weapons-has to be played out between the two major players. Every country could argue, as do the United Kingdom and France, that it has a right to have nuclear weapons. We would see a massive proliferation of nuclear weapons if other countries followed suit. I think that there is an argument in both those countries for those countries to get rid of their nuclear weapons. The problem globally is that the unilateralist position is absolutely nonsensical. So my position is to argue that we must work for step by step verifiable reduction on both sides.

I want to talk for a moment about the regional situation. I am often accused of being anti-American, so I need to talk about ANZUS to clarify that position. ANZUS was designed as a strategy of denial which has been remarkably successful since 1951 in keeping the Soviet Union out of the Pacific, although I do not know whether it had great designs on this region of the world until more recently. The Soviets had no bases in the Pacific until Cam Ranh Bay after 1979, and that would not last 48 hours in a total war as it is surrounded by China, Association of South East Asian Nation countries, ANZUS, the Japanese Maritime Self-Defence Force and the United States Navy. The Soviets test their weapons in the North Pacific at sea, they largely refuel at sea, and their Indian Ocean squadron is moored at sea off Socotra.

Failure to acquire facilities in the Indian Ocean region was not through want of trying. The Soviets certainly tried to get facilities there and ended up with Aden and Dahlak Archipelago in the Red Sea. But there is not anything like the presence in either the Pacific or the Indian oceans, particularly the South Pacific Ocean, as there is with the American presence. So the peace movement is obviously concentrated on the overwhelming United States presence in the region. The same goes for warships and bases in Australia itself. The Australian peace movement calls for the closure of the base at Cam Ranh Bay and we will be joining with the regional peace brigades going to the Philippines in December and January calling for the closure of all foreign bases in the region-that is, the United States bases in the Philippines and the Soviet facilities in Vietnam. The overwhelming object is to remove all foreign bases from the region. No country should have to suffer foreign bases of another country on its soil.

I now turn to the function of peace movements in this whole scenario. I believe that the work of peace movements in any country is to apply pressure domestically on their own government, if that government is involved in nuclear alliances or in providing nuclear facilities to any nuclear nation in any way. That, of course, is the position in Australia. The European nuclear disarmament movement argued for the removal of both the cruise missiles and the SS20s, the Soviet versions. There is evidence in Europe of both of the superpowers having nuclear weapons on various countries' soil. We do not have that situation in Australia. In trying to bring pressure to bear on disarmament talks, the peace movement argued for the removal of both kinds of missiles-the American cruise missiles and the SS20s, the Soviet versions. It is a very slow process indeed, but it needs constant pressure being applied by the peace movements, East and West, and it is absolutely pointless if it is one-sided.

Non-aligned groups in the West worked with and had dialogue with Eastern bloc independent and unofficial peace groups in the 1980s. For the benefit of the Opposition I will mention a few of those groups. Opposition member seem to think that there is no independent peace movement in the Eastern bloc. Of course, it is much more difficult for people there to be part of the peace movement, but they are there and they need our support. To name but a few, the groups included the Moscow Trust Group, the Freedom and Peace Group in Poland, the Dialogue Group and 4-6-0 in Hungary, and Charter 77 and the Independent Peace Association in Czechoslovakia. Particular support is given to those who are gaoled in their countries for having been bold and brave enough-they have to be much bolder and braver than we are-to make criticisms of their governments, given their political situations. Those groups are bitterly attacked by the Soviet Peace Committee and the World Peace Council, so they can hardly be described as pro-Soviet. The fact that they exist at all in some of those countries is quite amazing and, as I have said, they need our support.

It is interesting that a three-day seminar in Prague in June, to which people from all over Eastern and Western Europe were invited, was broken up by the authorities and the participants were expelled. It was just as much a threat to the East as to the West. Those in the East allege that the peace movement is sponsored by the Central Intelligence Agency, just as the conservatives here allege funding from the Soviet Union, as Senator Crichton-Browne intimated in an earlier debate. He would feel quite at home in the Soviet Union, blaming all dissent on outside funding. People such as Senator Crichton-Browne who see everything in black and white never take account of the various shades of grey; in other words, they have a very simplistic philosophy-`If you are not for us, you are against us'. They do not seem to understand that some people can be opposed to nuclear weapons no matter which country holds them. That kind of thinking divides the world's people into enemy and allied categories, which is not very helpful in the process towards peace.

It is important to notice also that War Resistance International, a group of which I am a member, protested in 1968 in the capitals of eastern Europe against the Soviet Union invasion of Czechsolovakia and, at the same time, against the United States war in Vietnam. The eastern European authorities simply could not understand that position, just as the conservatives here are unable to see it the other way round. They were saying, `If you criticise the United States you must be pro-Soviet'. That is what we are told. In the Eastern bloc people were told that, if they criticised the Soviet invasion of Czechsolovakia, they must support the United States war in Vietnam. Of course, War Resistance International opposed all militarism. War Resistance International now actively supports conscientious objection movements in Eastern Europe. A recent conference along those lines was held in Finland with people from Poland, Yugoslavia and Hungary invited and able to be there, which was good.

The European nuclear disarmament movement has the same trouble. Critics found it hard to accept the support for independent groups in the Eastern bloc and meetings and seminars held together. Yet for the non-aligned movement-the principle has always been basic-one cannot expect to get rid of the United States military presence unless one also works to get rid of Soviet occupation forces out of Eastern Europe. That is very much on the agenda of the European peace movement. But we cannot alter geography. The people in Europe see the Soviets in Europe and the Americans over the sea. So recent consideration of defensive defence and civilian-based defence is on the agenda for the peace movement in Europe, rather than what is now emerging in Germany and France-a new concept of a nuclear defence outside the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation, which seems to be a danger sign. Many people, particularly the peace movement, are looking at a new concept of security which is in non-military terms. That goes for some governments in western Europe, including the Swedish and the Dutch. There is even a pocket of people in the French Defence Department looking at non-violent civilian defence as an adjunct to their other defence activities.

Finally, I want to say something about disarming the seas, which is the campaign that is taking up most of the attention of the Australian peace movement at the moment. In the Pacific and Indian Ocean region we must now demand naval arms control and security talks. I commend the Government-in particular, the former Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Hayden-for raising this question in several fora both in Australia and internationally, at the United Nations and with Mr Shultz in June this year. When I attended the United Nations Special Session on Disarmament in New York recently, the United States blocked all mention of the naval arms race at sea. It would not allow it to be included in the document which ultimately fell into the wastepaper basket at that meeting. That the United States would not allow the naval arms race to be mentioned was one of the major stumbling blocks, yet the naval arms race is the most destabilising area of the escalating arms race at the moment.

The danger of submarine launched cruise missiles is a nightmare for arms controllers because they are not counted, are not easily identifiable and are mobile. The United States started the deployment of these cruise missiles in 1984 and the Soviet deployment started in January this year. It is a typical scenario in which one superpower follows the other and we are all put further at risk. A campaign in the Pacific must be directed not just against the United States and the Soviet Union but must involve regional powers such as Canada, Japan, South Korea and China. So the nuclear free and independent Pacific movement and the Pacific campaign to disarm the seas have taken strong stands against not only the overwhelming United States presence but also against Soviet sealaunched cruise missiles and Cam Ranh Bay. It is very important that this international aspect is understood clearly. But the fact remains that in Australia we have only United States bases and mostly United States warship visits, with occasional visits from the Royal Navy and the French.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are joint facilities.

—Senator Newman might call them joint facilities, but I think that they serve the purpose of the United States military command amply. They do not serve our defence arrangements at all; they make nuclear targets out of us. They do nothing for the defence of Australia whatsoever with the one minor exception of the Australian control room at North West Cape. That is the only possible argument that can be made that any of these so-called joint facilities serve Australian defence. The others are nuclear targets and they do not serve our purposes one little bit, but they serve the United States very well.

SPEECH.PARA: It is obvious that the peace movement in Australia is going to be directed against our Government's compliance with the United States military. This is not a unilateralist position but obviously our best efforts can be directed at changing public opinion in this country. That is where our efforts are going to be most effective. That is why we concentrate on Australia's involvement. It is much more sensible for us to concentrate our efforts on Australia's involvement and to try to stop that rather than working on the details of crossing the t's and dotting the i's on the disarmament agreements. That is the job for the people who are involved in the disarmament discussions at the conference on disarmament in Geneva. Our job is to give our governments the push in the direction that we want them to go.

The facts remain: the peace movements internationally support each other in their efforts towards multilateral disarmament. Peace movements obviously concentrate efforts on the foreign affairs and defence policies of their own countries. We have to focus on working to denuclearise and demilitarise our own patches-that is, our own territories. We can affect public attitudes in our own countries, bringing pressure to bear on our own Government's policies. For example, we have seen the Australian peace movement's efforts to extricate Australia from its contribution to the arms race. They are now very well known but they relate to American bases on Australian soil, the constant presence of warships in our harbours and the mining and export of uranium. Those are the things that the Australian peace movement still focuses on but we do have the international aspect of our work which is mostly concentrated on the arms race at sea.

If the Australian Government is pushed by the peace movement and public pressure in this country it will work hard and more effectively in international fora like the United Nations General Assembly and the Conference on Disarmament. Ultimately then individual countries, pushed by their own people, bring pressure to bear on the nuclear powers and then it is appropriate for those countries, working with the other countries in the conference on disarmament, to make sure that it is mutual and verifiable disarmament that takes place. That can hardly be called a unilateralist position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take a few minutes of the Senate's time tonight to support the moves that have been taking place for some considerable time, without success to date but being intensified at the moment by various groups in Victoria, and in particular by the Calder Highway Improvement Committee, to have the Calder Highway between Melbourne and Bendigo upgraded by it being reclassified under the road classification system to a classification of national arterial road. Those members of the Senate who know the Calder Highway will know that it is a very busy road. Indeed, it is the major transport route to the northern part of Victoria and to the increasingly busy areas of regional Victoria around the Bendigo area. It is also very heavily connected with the development in traffic, tourist and otherwise, associated with the growing use and tourist potential of the Tullamarine Airport.

SPEECH.PARA: The highway is one that I have had familiarity with virtually throughout my life. As a boy I grew up in Bendigo and spent a great deal of my time travelling on that highway between Bendigo and Melbourne. As a senator for Victoria in the last four years I have spent a great deal of time travelling the highway as well. One thing that can be said of it with great certainty is that it is a very dangerous road. The accident statistics from the Road Traffic Authority for the last three years show that in 1985 there were 286 accidents on the Calder Highway between Melbourne and Bendigo. In 1986 there were 274 accidents and in 1987 that figure increased by 100 to a figure of 373. Last year alone of those 373 accidents 13 fatalities were involved.

Much of the road is still single lane. There have been some considerable improvements made to it over the last 20 years. But despite those improvements much of it is still single lane and even in the areas where there have been improvements they have been done in a way which has shown that they have suffered from a lack of adequate funding. One of the areas that have recently been made into a double lane highway, resurfaced and had more signposts put up to warn of dangerous curves is the section from the Black Forest through to Ravenswood near Bendigo. The local police figures for road accidents and fatalities show that since that section of the road has been upgraded those accidents and fatalities have declined very sharply.

The record of this Government in terms of road funding is appalling. Under Labor road funding has dropped by more than 20 per cent in real terms. In this year alone the Government slashed $50m from the road funding program on top of the other savage cuts that occurred in recent years. The regional and rural communities bear the brunt of these slashes in road funding. I accept the point that it is certainly not an automatically positive correlation between the condition of roads and the accidents on roads. I think one can draw to simplistic conclusions from that relationship but there is no doubt that there is a relationship. In the case of the Calder Highway, particularly with its increasing usage over recent years, there is no doubt that if the highway is not upgraded and if it does not obtain national arterial road classification, and therefore the eligibility for greater funding, particularly from the State Government then we are going to see many more accidents on that highway. In view of what has happened in recent years I ask the Government how many more accidents and fatalities do we have to have on the Calder Highway before it will sit up and up take the necessary notice which will lead to the upgrading of the highway?

I congratulate the Calder Highway Improvement Committee for the tireless efforts that it has made in recent years in attempting to get governments to take the necessary steps to improve the highway between Melbourne and Bendigo. It has done a mighty job. It has not been successful up to date but I am sure that its efforts certainly deserve to be rewarded and I hope they will be in the very near future. If they do not the effect will be to hold back the development of that region of Victoria which is a very important part of my State. I want to join with those who over a period of time have been seeking to upgrade this highway. It is well overdue and I hope that the efforts of the Committee and others will prove fruitful.

Just before the Victorian State election the new Federal Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support, Mr Bob Brown, visited the area to open a bridge in the Shire of Newstead. But he took the opportunity, so I am told, while he was there to look at the question of upgrading the highway. It seems to me that he had a funny sense of priorities. He got them round the wrong way. It was probably due to the politicking that he was associated with in the State election in Victoria. I hope that that politicking will not mean that now the election is out of the way the apparent interest of the relevant Minister fades away. I am confident that my Labor colleague, the Federal member for Burke, Mr O'Keefe, who has been very active in this area will keep his Minister and the Government up to the mark on it as well. He will certainly have my support and the support of many other people in doing so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am generally known as the `honourable senator for warships', but tonight I am going to take this opportunity to speak on something that I do not speak about very often-that is, royalty. Although I have been a republican since I first fainted at the Sydney showground during the Queen's visit in the early 1950s, I must say that I had a great deal of sympathy for the plight of one of the Queen's youngest offspring, the Duke of York, Prince Andrew, during his recent visit to Australia. His Royal Highness was severely embarrassed and inconvenienced by the breakdown in the hydraulic equipment of the variable pitch propeller of the ship on which he was travelling, the nuclear-armed HMS Edinburgh. As a result, his very busy schedule in the former colony was interrupted on several occasions and his planned meetings with his charming wife, the Duchess of York, were almost disrupted. I imagine he was concerned about the astronomical costs of the extra helicopter flights to and from Lizard Island and, potentially, down to Tasmania and extra costs of the security services that the breakdown of his ship caused, not to mention the blow to the reputation of what was once regarded as the world's finest navy-the Falklands War notwithstanding.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the Duke of York is, like most of his countrymen, a stickler for punctuality. But he seems to be having little success with meeting appointments while in Australia because his ship is running out of steam-not a good sign for what is supposed to be one of the most advanced ships in the British Navy. The failure of Prince Andrew's ship to take him to his royal spouse on time must surely have been a great test of his royal patience. However, His Royal Highness's patience was not the only patience to be tested during the bicentennial naval salute-in regard to the Edinburgh in particular. Certainly the patience of various members of the Federal Government seemed to be tested. Certainly the patience of the New South Wales Premier, Mr Greiner, and various members of his Government was tested. Their irritable remarks yesterday in State Parliament about me and various peace groups are evidence of that.

Interestingly enough, those who had the most reason to complain about the activities and the cargo of the Edinburgh showed most restraint. They confined their activities to peaceful protest, orderly meetings and candlelit vigils. They were the thousands of Sydneysiders who, like Prince Andrew, did not welcome the news that the Edinburgh had to return to Sydney to have its propeller fixed. Neither do I think that the waterside unions in Sydney welcomed the news of the return of the Edinburgh, which was taken straight to the fleet intermediate maintenance base at 23 Woolloomooloo where only navy personnel are permitted to enter. It was probably just as well that the navy divers were able to repair the ship's propeller underwater and to repair it sufficiently to enable the ship to leave Sydney under its own steam. Had it not been able to it would, according to the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, speaking in the lower House yesterday, have been offered dry-docking facilities at Garden Island.

Garden Island has been a very vexatious issue, particularly in relation to the dry-docking which Mr Beazley has offered to the Edinburgh. Dry-docking facilities were requested by the nuclear-armed ship Invincible which also developed propeller troubles on a visit to Australia in 1983. At that time the Minister for Defence, Gordon Scholes, refused it permission to dry-dock on the basis that it was contrary to government policy. He said that nuclear weapons were not allowed on Australian soil and that this included nuclear weapons on board a vessel in dry dock. It seems that government policy has changed since then or, rather, government policy has been changed for the Government. I seek leave, Madam Acting Deputy President, to table a document which shows exactly how this policy was changed and when.
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I would like then to quote from the document.
—That is your choice, Senator Dunn.
—I quote from a statement that the United States Secretary of State, George Shultz, prepared for the Australian Government. Paragraph 2 of that statement reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Visitation by allied vessels is perfectly consistent with our obligations as a sovereign nation that has voluntarily entered into mutual security agreements to protect fundamental interests. The provision of necessary repair facilities is an implicit obligation under these agreements.

The version finally drafted by the Australian Government is remarkably similar, with only sufficient changes to retain some shreds of an appearance of independence. Paragraph 2 of the Australian Government's version states:
Visits by allied vessels are fully consistent with our responsibilities as a sovereign nation which must protect fundamental interests, as is the provision of necessary repair facilities.
Again, paragraph 3 of the Shultz document states:

Regarding the use of Australian repair facilities, further clarification is in order. Whether our facilities would be appropriate for use in a given situation would depend on technical and safety requirements of both the RAN and the allied navy and would vary from ship to ship.
The Australian Government dutifully prepared a statement that is almost an exact paraphrase of the original. It states:

3. (On) the question of an allied or friendly warship possibly needing to dry dock in an Australian port in the future, it was agreed that each request would have to be considered on its merits taking into account technical and safety factors.

Therefore, it seemed that the way was indeed open at that time for the Government to consider a request for dry-docking on its merits. It has now decided that the Edinburgh's request was worthy of merit. On what basis was this done? I wonder whether Mr Beazley is aware that in order to dry-dock a nuclear-armed ship one has first to first take off the weapons. The Edinburgh carries nuclear depth bombs which are launched by two Lynx anti-submarine helicopters. How will the nuclear bombs be lifted off the ship? Will they be lifted off by standard crane or helicopter? Where will they be stored? Will they be stored on the wharf? What about the security surrounding the weapons on the wharf? Does Mr Beazley know that accidents have occurred with the handling of such nuclear weapons? Does he really want to take the risk? It seems that he does. Senator Vallentine has aptly named him the Minister for nuclear risks. I hope that he is not unlucky enough to go down in the history books as such.

There are other questions that have to be answered too. Will Mr Beazley be prepared to allow dry-docking and, therefore, the de-arming of the Edinburgh without first asking the British whether they have their nasty nuclear weapons on board?

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you asking questions in Estimates or just on adjournments?

—These are rhetorical questions. Is Mr Beazley really prepared potentially to breach the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty by having unconfirmed nuclear weapons on Australian soil? How is the attitude of Mr Beazley and the Australian Government different from that of the Opposition, which holds that peace through security and deterrence can be achieved by welcoming nuclear-armed ships to our ports? Like Senator MacGibbon, I condemn the Soviet Union for using nuclear-powered satellites in total disregard of the safety of the citizens of the earth. How is the presence of nuclear-armed ships any different?

SPEECH.PARA: To go back to the subject of Prince Andrew: just think of the royal annoyance if, during the de-arming of his ship, perhaps in Hobart now, one of the nuclear depth bombs were to catch fire or be accidentally dropped. That would truly cause an international scandal and taint the royal reputation somewhat. Therefore, although I am not a royalist, I would certainly seek to protect His Royal Highness from further embarrassment by suggesting that the Australian Government reverse its decision about dry-docking to save the royal son from further inconvenience and allow him to enjoy his married life in peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my practice to speak very often on the adjournment. Certainly, out of consideration for other senators it is not my practice to speak at length on the adjournment-although I think the adjournment is a very important time if an honourable senator has an issue which he needs to raise on behalf of constituents or generally. I make no apology tonight for speaking for the first time in many months on the adjournment. I do so because I wish to raise the question of the discrimination being experienced by injured Commonwealth workers in regard to the expenses they are paid for travelling to and from places of treatment. I say `discrimination' because they are severely discriminated against in comparison with workers covered by State workers compensation legislation. I shall refer to the provisions of legislation relating to the reimbursement of costs incurred. I refer specifically to section 37 (7) of the Compensation (Australian Government Employees) Act 1971-1973, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where compensation in respect of the cost of medical treatment is payable by the Commonwealth under this section, the Commonwealth is liable to pay compensation to the employee of an amount equal to the amount of the expenditure reasonably incurred by the employee in making a necessary journey in connexion with the obtaining of that medical treatment or in remaining, for the purpose of obtaining that medical treatment, at a place to which he has made a journey for that purpose.

Until 1 July of this year the payment made for the use of a private motor vehicle with an engine capacity of 1501 to 2000 cc was 11.01c a kilometre. But from 1 July this year that was slashed to 6c a kilometre, which caused a great deal of concern to injured workers, many of whom are already under considerable stress. That rate was announced in circular 1988/3 from Comcare dated 3 June 1988.

Tonight I shall provide an example of how this problem is impinging upon, and is a burden to, injured Commonwealth workers. I refer to a constituent of mine, Mr John Glynn of 30 Hinsby Road, Taroona in Tasmania. Mr Glynn works for Australia Post, and is an injured Commonwealth worker. He was required to have daily treatment for an injury sustained in his place of employment. He was required to travel daily from his place of residence to the Dockside Clinic, a return trip of 22 kilometres a day. He made 66 daily trips and was reimbursed at the rate of 11.01c down to 6c a kilometre, which was a dramatic reduction. Actually, Mr Glynn sought information about it, and was informed that by using his own mode of transport he would be paid 30c a kilometre. Subsequently he made a claim for reimbursement for the period 19 April 1988 to 8 August 1988, a total of 66 days, at 22 kilometres a day. Mr Glynn was reimbursed for 42 days, that is, from 19 April 1988 to 30 June 1988 at 22 kilometres a day, or a total of 924 kilometres at 11.01c a kilometre, which amounted to $101.73. But from 1 July 1988 he was paid for 24 days at 22 kilometres a day, a total of 528 kilometres, at the rate of 6c a kilometre, which was a mere $31.68, for an approximate total of $134.

This gentleman could not use public transport because of medical reasons. Had he been able to use public transport for the same period he would have been paid $2.40 a day for 66 days in bus fares, which would have totalled $158.40. However, he was unable to use public transport. If he had used a taxi for that period, the cost would have been $20 a day for a return trip, so the cost to Comcare for 66 days would have been $1,320. In using his own mode of transport because of medical reasons, he is being discriminated against, especially if one compares injured workers covered by State workers compensation legislation.

Incidentally, Mr Glynn received a further cheque for approximately $25. Although the reason is not mentioned in my documentation, I presume that was a reimbursement for the equivalent bus fares. The point is that Mr Glynn had been told he would be reimbursed at a much higher rate-that he would be paid 30c a kilometre for using his car. Mr Glynn used his vehicle, but the amount that has been paid to him is insufficient to cover the running costs and petrol used by his motor vehicle.

It is most unfair that this situation should have arisen, with the kilometre rate being slashed from a low 11.01c a kilometre to 6c a kilometre. That is a disgrace. It is something that the Government should examine and rectify. I also understand that another change to the rate will occur on 1 December this year which will further exacerbate this problem. It is important that the Government respond to this matter in the interests of Commonwealth workers who are injured on the job.

Over many years as a trade union officer I have dealt with persons who have had serious injuries and have had to have treatment. I think it is very important that those of us who represent these persons in this chamber-and I suggest that all of us represent these people because we are to oversight the activities of the Government, for whom these persons are working-take the responsibility for ensuring that these people get a fair deal. They are not getting a fair deal now. I submit this particular example to the Senate for two reasons: firstly, to give honourable senators an example of the difficulties experienced by injured Commonwealth workers and the discrimination that is suffered by them by comparison to injured workers in private employment who are covered by State workers compensation legislation; and, secondly, for something to be done for Mr Glynn, who was given to understand that he would be receiving a certain reimbursement but is now out of pocket because of that advice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I sat here listening to the adjournment debate, it suddenly occurred to me that Senators Vallentine and Dunn have turned the adjournment debate into the pacifists half-hour. I wonder whether they realise that pacifism is hardly attractive on an empty stomach, and certainly the force of their arguments, if any, becomes less and less attractive as the hours progress. They are not old enough to remember what previous pacifists did to the world in the 1930s with disarmament. They certainly have not learned from the history books what happened to the world after those people, their predecessors, saw that the democracies of the world were disarmed just in time for World War II.

SPEECH.PARA: I wanted to speak only briefly, because in Senator Vallentine's speech she made much of the criticism of unilateral initiatives that she has been attracting. I think that Senator Vallentine, Senator Dunn and their colleagues have got to be judged by their actions, not by their words. They clearly spend their considerable efforts on unilateral initiatives against our friend and ally, the United States. That, as we all know, includes stunts; and in Senator Vallentine's case it includes gaol. I think that the Senate should be aware of Senator Vallentine's conduct in Estimates Committee D, which deals with the Department of Defence, where she appears briefly every time the United States is mentioned in the explanatory notes and, having asked her question, then disappears.

She is not at all interested in the defence of Australia; she is simply concerned to see that the joint facilities in Australia are closed and that the bases in the Philippines are closed to our ally. She has no care for or appreciation of the need that this country has for strong friends. She and her colleagues pay practically no attention at all to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the need to deal even handedly with the United States and the USSR. For all their protestations, we have to look at the conduct of Senators Vallentine and Dunn and their colleagues.

We on this side of the chamber-and also I, acknowledge now, the Government-believe that Australia and the world will stay at peace only through having strength against aggressors. That is now accepted by both the major parties in this country. It is the dangerous naivety, or even worse, of Senators Vallentine and Dunn that could lead us to war.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 8.45 p.m.
