QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Would the Treasurer advise what definition is being used by the Australian Taxation Office for the terms `Religious Orders' and `Minister of Religion' under the Fringe Benefits Assessment Act 1986.
(2) Will `Religious Orders' be regarded as a broad general and descriptive term to embrace `denominations', `societies', `ministries' etc. of a religious nature.
(3) Will individual religious institutions be allowed to nominate those they regard as `ministers'.
(4) Must such `ministers of religion' be limited to those who are formally ordained by a particular denomination.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The fringe benefits tax law exempts benefits provided by religious institutions in respect of the religious duties of employees who are ministers of religion or full-time members of a religious order. The exemption also applies to employees who are in training to become ministers or members of a religious order.

The intention is to exempt benefits provided to clergy and other members of a religious order by reason of their membership of the religious order, but not benefits provided principally in respect of employment activities that are not religious duties. For that purpose, religious duties are taken to be pastoral duties or other duties or activities directly related to the practice, study, teaching or propagation of religious benefits.

`Religious order' and `minister of religion' are not defined in the fringe benefits tax law. They are, nevertheless, terms that are generally well understood in the community, and the Commissioner of Taxation has advised that they will be interpreted in that light, having regard to relevant judicial decisions.

He would see the term ``minister of religion'', for example, as including priests, pastors, rabbis or other persons recognised by a religion as having authority in matters of doctrine or religious practice, but not the ordinary adherents of a religion.

In the Commissioner's view, a person who belongs to a religious order, whether known as a nun, brother, monk or by some other title, would generally be one of a community of persons sharing the same religious beliefs and bound by vows to live according to the rules and discipline of the order.

(3) The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act requires each employer to determine the annual liability to fringe benefits tax, and to lodge a return with the Commissioner disclosing taxable fringe benefits and declaring the amount of fringe benefits tax payable. For that purpose, each religious institution would need to determine those of its employees who qualify as ministers of religion or members of religious orders. Taxation officers are available to assist any such institution that is in need of advice as to whether the exemption should apply in a particular case.

(4) The question whether a person is a minister of religion is one of fact which needs to be determined according to whether, on the one hand, the particular religion requires a minister to be formally ordained or, on the other hand, authorises a person to carry out the duties of a minister based on a specified level of theological or other relevant training or experience.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What rules apply for each country with which Australia has an international tax agreement or the equivalent in (a) Australia; and (b) the source country, to the taxation of pensions paid by a country to former residents of that country now living in Australia.

(2) Where there is no international tax agreement or equivalent between Australia and a source country, what rules apply in (a) Australia; and (b) the source country, to the taxation of pensions paid by a country to former residents of that country now living in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia has concluded twenty two comprehensive taxation agreements with other countries. Such agreements contain rules to avoid the double taxation of income flowing between Australia and its treaty partners and also allocate taxation rights in relation to certain classes of income. The attached table outlines the taxation position with respect to the taxation of pension income under each of these agreements. The general principle, subject to the listed variations, is that pensions derived from sources within one country by a resident of the other country are taxable only by the latter country. (However, where Australia, as the country of residence, has the sole right to tax a pension, certain pensions such as foreign war invalidity pensions may nevertheless be exempt in Australia under specific provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936).

(2) Under Australian income tax law, where an Australian resident receives a pension from a country with which Australia does not have a comprehensive taxation agreement, the gross amount of that pension income is included in the recipient's assessable income for Australian income tax purposes. A credit, up to the amount of the Australian tax attributable to the pension income, is allowed against that tax for foreign tax paid on the pension income. The foreign income tax treatment of a pension received by an Australian resident from a country with which Australia does not have a comprehensive taxation agreement would depend upon that country's domestic income tax law.
Pensions other than those referred to in Columns 2, 3 or 4
+ The agreement with Austria enters into force on 1 September 1988 and will apply in Australia in respect of pensions derived on or after 1 July 1989.
* ``Government service pensions'' are generally pensions paid in respect of services rendered to a government (including a State or local government).
R : Taxable only in country of residence of pension recipient.
S : Taxable only in country of source (i.e. country from which pension is paid)
R & S : May be taxed in both the country of source and the country of residence with the latter country giving a tax credit for the source country tax on the pension.
D : Government pensions paid to retired Government officials are expressly excluded from the agreement and are taxable in accordance with the respective domestic laws.
E : Exempt from tax in country of residence as long as exempt in country of source.
(1) Taxable only in the country of source where the pension recipient is a citizen/national of that country.

(2) The source country tax is limited to the lesser of 15 per cent of the pension received in the year, and the tax that would be payable in respect of the pension received in the year if the recipient were a resident of the source country.
(3) May be taxed in the country of source where the pension recipient is a citizen/national of that country.
(4) Australia exercises, with effect from 1 July 1987, its right under the convention to tax Australian residents on Italian pension payments.
(5) Pensions paid by a Philippine enterprise under a pension plan not registered under Philippine law may be taxed in the Philippines.

(6) The treaty with the United States allows for the continued operation of United States domestic law taxing rights over certain income, including pensions other than government service and social security pensions, derived by United States citizens. Where this right is exercised in respect of a pension derived by a United States citizen who is a resident of Australia, the United States is required to give a credit against its tax for any tax imposed by Australia as the country of residence of the pension recipient.
(7) However, pensions paid in respect of services rendered in connection with any trade or business carried on by one of the countries are taxable only in the country of residence of the recipient.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Sanitarium product `So Good', described as a non-dairy soy drink, attract sales tax; if so, why and at what rate is sales tax applied.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The product `So Good' is considered to be soy milk for sales tax purposes.
Prior to the 1988-89 Budget all soy milk was subject to wholesale Sales tax at the `general' rate of 20 per cent. This was consistent with the sales tax treatment of other fruit and vegetable juices.

The Government reviewed the sales tax treatment of soy milk in the lead-up to the 1988-89 Budget. After taking into consideration the fact that soy milk had come to be regarded as a substitute for dairy milk and was frequently chosen for medical reasons the Government announced in the 1988-89 Budget that, with effect from 8.00 pm 23 August 1988, plain soy milk would be exempt from sales tax (as is dairy milk) and flavoured soy milk would be taxable at the concessional rate of 10 per cent.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 25 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Can the Minister outline the various procedures that surround so called `joint funding' arrangements between the Federal and State Governments in respect of the following: (a) roads; (b) welfare housing; (c) health facilities; and (d) employment creation projects with respect to financial years 1986-87 and 87-88.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In 1986-87 and 1987-88 the Commonwealth provided financial assistance to the States and local government for construction and maintenance of roads under the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act 1982 and the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Act 1985.

Under this legislation the Commonwealth accepts full financial responsibility for funding maintenance and construction of the declared 16,000km National Highway System. It also provides significant base grants to State and local government to assist in meeting their responsibilities for arterial and local roads. In 1986-87 and 1987-88 Commonwealth assistance to the States for the three categories of roads totalled $1245 million and $1244.5 million respectively. Commonwealth road funding accounted for around one third of annual expenditure on roads by all levels of government.

Responsibility for Commonwealth road funding legislation rests with the Minister for Transport and Communications. The administrative procedures relating to the two Acts are set out in more detail in Notes of Administration, which are available from the Department of Transport and Communications.
Under the terms of the 1984 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement (CSHA), the States and the Northern Territory are required to match, on a $ for $ basis:
Commonwealth funding provided under the untied component of the CSHA (for general rental and home purchase assistance); and
Commonwealth funding provided for the Mortgage and Rent Relief Scheme (MRRS) a special purpose program funded through the CSHA.
In 1988-89 $530.6 million will be provided for the Commonwealth as untied CSHA funds to be matched by States, and $26.4 million under MRRS.
Sources of funds eligible for States matching expenditure under the 1984 CSHA are:
surpluses from rental programs and revolving funds from home purchase assistance programs;

allocations for housing from State consolidated revenue funds, loan funds, trust funds and other special accounts, borrowings by State instrumentalities and appropriations from State Authority and instrumentality surpluses;
amounts agreed between the Federal Minister and State Minister.

Provision of Hospital services is a State responsibility, but Commonwealth funding is provided. In 1986-87 and 1987-88 this was in the form of Medicare Compensation Grants (which reimbursed the States for revenue forgone by providing free public hospital treatment to Medicare patients) paid by DCSH and Identified Health Grants (general revenue assistance to the States) paid by Treasury.
Commencing in 1988-89, new specific purpose hospital funding grants are to be made to the States over five years. A total of $3036 million was provided in the 1988-89 budget.
The Commonwealth and the States/Territories assist the Red Cross Transfusion Services on the following basis:
Red Cross, 10% of appeals and donations

Under the terms of the Commonwealth/State Agreement, the States/Territories are responsible (in conjunction with the Red Cross) for determining the level and extent of operation of their respective Blood Transfusion Services.

Each year the Red Cross submits an operating budget to its State health authority, which in turn vets it, adjusts it if necessary and submits an endorsed revision to the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth will then make advances to the State during the year and acquit at the end of the year on the basis of meeting its designated share of those final costs accepted by the State/Territory.

An itemised capital program is jointly approved by the Commonwealth and each State/Territory each year. In practice the State/Territories submit endorsed programs for the Commonwealth's consideration. After vetting and adjusting it if necessary to accord with the Commonwealth's health and financial priorities, the Commonwealth advises the program it has approved and the level of funds it will provide. Under current arrangements the Commonwealth reserves the right to restrict its level of funding in any year.
The Commonwealth and the States/Territories assist the Royal Flying Doctor Service (RFDS) on the following basis:
the Commonwealth matches the States/Territories up to a maximum of 90% of net operating costs. The RFDS meets the balance
the RFDS and the Commonwealth each meet 50% of an agreed program.

The States/Territories are only involved with the Commonwealth in funding the recurrent costs of the RFDS. To this extent the States/Territories have primary responsibility for determining the level and extent of RFDS operations, within a general constraint imposed by the Commonwealth to the effect that a sustained and significant increase in the level of operations over the 1985-86 level of operations requires prior Commonwealth approval.

The individual RFDS Sections submit the proposed annual operating budgets to their respective State/Territory health authorities for approval. Capital budgets are also referred to State/Territory authorities for comment in relation to the possible effects on recurrent costs. These are vetted by the States/Territories, adjusted if necessary to accord with the States/Territories health and financial priorities and submitted to the Commonwealth through the Federal Council of the RFDS.
Advances made during the year are acquitted at the end of the year and adjusted if necessary in accordance with the agreed formula.

For the period 1986-87 and 1987-88 two employment creation projects were in place with ``joint funding'' arrangements between Commonwealth and State/Territory governments. These were the Community Employment Program (CEP) and the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme (NEIS).

The CEP, which was formally abolished on 13 May 1987, was jointly administered by State and Commonwealth officers, with the majority of funding from the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth provided all the program funding and an administrative subsidy to the States/Territories. The State financial contribution was that part of the administration not covered by that subsidy.

The procedures surrounding the joint project involved formal agreements between the Commonwealth and each State/Territory specifying the division of responsibilities, financial arrangements and project management procedures.

The procedure for the conduct of the program was that the State/Territory was responsible for administration of program funds, entering agreements with program sponsors, obtaining audited accounts and providing financial information to the Commonwealth. The State/Territory and Commonwealth were jointly responsible for monitoring progress in the project. The Commonwealth, in conjunction with a State/Territory committee was responsible for the approval, variation and rescheduling of projects.

The object of the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme is to create new employment opportunities by providing income support, capital assistance, access to small business advisory services and training to persons who have the capacity to establish and conduct small businesses.

The NEIS is jointly funded, in that the Commonwealth provides funds for both income support and training, while the State/Territory provide loans for the setting up of small business enterprises. Both the State/Territory and the Commonwealth contribute staff to the project.

The scheme is arranged through a ``Memorandum of Arrangement'' signed by the Commonwealth Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs, and the relevant State/Territory Minister. The memorandum outlines the operation of the program, the contributions to be made by the State/Territory and by the Commonwealth, and the necessary exchange of information.
The allocation of tasks between the Commonwealth and State/Territory is complex, as the project is jointly administered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April 1988 (Hansard, page 2062), Senator Panizza asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the obligations on banks or finance companies to disclose the full cost of various forms of borrowings to their customers. I undertook to seek an answer from the Treasurer. The Treasurer supplied the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: For the lending of banks and finance companies which is subject to the State Government Credit Acts, disclosure of loan contract details is required. Borrowers must be given copies of contracts or proposed contracts at all relevant stages. Similar protection is given to guarantors and proposed guarantors. Special emphasis is places on the disclosure of the interest costs of the loan on the basis that cost comparisons should be made as easy as practicable for the borrower.

The members of the Australian Bankers' Association (ABA) have recently agreed to a disclosure standard to govern the provision to customers of information on interest rates and charges for both bank loans and bank deposits. The disclosure standard has emerged from prolonged discussions among the banks and follows a survey initiated by the ABA at the end of 1987 to ascertain consumers' information needs.
In the case of loan contracts, the disclosure standard identified three distinct stages where the consumer would be provided with specific information. These are:

(i) prior to the loan being made-at which time the consumer will receive information which would enable a full comparison of all elements of the cost, and other terms and conditions, of loans from competing institutions;
(ii) at the time the loan is made-when much of the information previously disclosed will be repeated, and the picture completed by the consumer receiving information on:
any additional charges to apply to pre-payments of loans or full clearance of loans;
any charges to apply in relation to arrears; and
any provision for the contract's terms and conditions (including the interest rate) to be varied; and
(iii) during the term of the loan-when consumers will receive appropriate notification in the event that the interest rate varies.

The ABA has indicated that for competitive reasons some aspects of the proposed disclosure standards would not be introduced unless competing non-bank financial institutions were also willing to adopt similar practices.

The development of the disclosure standard is a positive step by the banking industry, notwithstanding that some aspects (eg enforcement) remain to be clarified. The Government supports efforts to improve the information disclosed to consumers to allow them to make more informed comparisons and choices, and thereby benefit from competition among financial institutions.
